CONTENT: I agree. When the light on Sunset and Bienveneda went out, it made it really challenging to evacuate the school, with parents braving the busy intersection on foot to direct traffic. That light went out previously during high winds just before Christmas and it made the intersection very dangerous.
LLM_SUMMARY: Broken traffic light at Sunset/Bienveneda created dangerous conditions during evacuation, with parents forced to direct traffic. This recurring issue during high winds puts our community at risk.

CONTENT: Listen. To. The. Insurance. Companies. When a business is reliant on predicting a property's risk of fire damage, and they charge exorbitantly to insure it (or don't insure it AT ALL), people should not be permitted to build housing there. Period.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies' risk assessments should determine where housing is allowed. If they won't insure or charge extreme rates due to fire risk, building shouldn't be permitted there.

CONTENT: ADUs may allow homeowners to recover an economic loss, but more residents will add to the evacuation problem.   It is not practical or safe to keep adding residence to a community that only has two roads in and out.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned that allowing ADUs for economic recovery will worsen evacuation challenges in our area, which already has limited road access. Adding more residents isn't safe.

CONTENT: The Palisades community had been asking about evacuation routes for many years and none was made clear. We are all very fortunate that Palisades High was not in session on the day of the fire as the City had issues evacuating the number of people in the Palisades without having 1000s of students also in session. There seemed to be a lack of coordination with traffic control once evacuation orders were given leading to residents abandoning their cars on Sunset. What and how traffic control plans will look like in future evacuations is a significant question.
LLM_SUMMARY: Lack of clear evacuation routes caused chaos during the fire. Traffic control was poor, leading to abandoned cars. With school in session, it could've been worse. Better evacuation planning is urg

CONTENT: Stop building in all fire-prone areas!
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to completely halt development in areas vulnerable to wildfires.

CONTENT: There should be zoning, codes, permitting and other policies that limit or eliminate building in fire-prone areas unless customers are willing to pay for the materials to be fire resilient and willing to forego the protection from standard services in the case of an emergency.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building in fire-prone areas should be restricted unless homeowners use fire-resistant materials and accept limited emergency services. Current policies need to reflect these risks.

CONTENT: I think this is already pretty good.  The room for improvement is in updating zoning-permitting especially for smaller, affordable starter homes. and Zero parking spaces for new construction within 1.5 miles of light-rail stations.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want better climate resilience through updated zoning - especially for affordable starter homes and reduced parking requirements near transit stations.

CONTENT: The size of the homeless population in LA County is a direct reflection of the cost of housing. It would be a missed opportunity if Altadena became a city of expensive single-family homes. Lots tend to be big. Models for multi-family "compounds" for intergenerational families, or friends who want to live together would maximize space and build community. Could include shared garden areas or other features that create opportunities for contact with nature.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should use rebuilding as a chance to create multi-family housing with shared spaces, not just expensive single homes. This could help address affordability while building community connections.

CONTENT: I should not have to shoulder Palisades folks rebuilding in such a high risk area.
LLM_SUMMARY: Don't want my tax dollars supporting rebuilds in high-risk fire zones like Pacific Palisades.

CONTENT: Access needs to be improved to these neighborhoods, a bus that comes every hour is not helpful if people want to evacuate if they do not have a vehicle. BBB and Metro bus services being increased to a minimum of every 10-15 minutes can greatly improve access and lower the risk of gridlock during evacuations.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need more frequent bus service in at-risk areas - current hourly schedule isn't enough for safe evacuation. Increasing to every 10-15 minutes would improve access and reduce evacuation

CONTENT: Housing has been incredibly tough, expensive, and hard to find. Then the fires happened. Now we need housing more than ever and we need housing here so people don’t have to move away and they can still stay in the general area while trying to pick up where they left off. People need to rebuild and live in their homes and sell to families, not corporations. We need to remove barriers to rebuild but also ensure that people don’t get ripped off by bad contractors and that the new houses they build are safe, strong, and resilient, and some properties that were immediately above Eaton Canyon should consider not rebuilding because it is just a matter of time.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need affordable local housing so fire victims can stay in the area while rebuilding. Want homes sold to families, not corporations. Concerned about contractor fraud and safety. Some canyon properties too risky to

CONTENT:
Exactly. ADUs should not be allowed in fire prone areas unless there is parking on property and there is a large enough lot to allow a wide buffer of space between the ADU and other structures.
In areas where the roads are narrow and it is already difficult to evacuate there should be a total ban on additional density. It is irresponsible to put more people in harms way and increase the danger to those already living there!
LLM_SUMMARY: Strongly oppose ADUs in fire-prone areas without adequate parking and spacing. Adding density where evacuation is already difficult puts more lives at risk and endangers existing residents.

CONTENT: I do not think the community should become more dense. ADUs should only be teporary
LLM_SUMMARY: Don't want increased housing density in our community. Accessory dwelling units should only be allowed as temporary structures.

CONTENT: We need more housing not less. We should pull out all the stops to build back with more units not less.
LLM_SUMMARY: Strongly advocate for increasing housing density during rebuilding efforts, rather than simply replacing what was lost in the fire.

CONTENT: people had a hard time getting out of the Palisades. I'm not sure how these could be improved
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about evacuation difficulties during the Palisades Fire. Not clear on potential solutions for improving emergency exit routes.

CONTENT: Offer incentives to homeowners to make existing aDU’s available and ease the way for building additional ADUs to supplement housing.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want officials to incentivize homeowners to rent out existing ADUs and make it easier to build new ones to help address housing shortages after the fire.

CONTENT: Allow for higher density housing along the primary corridors of Fair Oaks and Lake Avenues
LLM_SUMMARY: Want higher density housing development permitted along major roads like Fair Oaks and Lake Avenues to support rebuilding efforts.

CONTENT: Let the market take care of the buildings! The government is inefficient. Reduce red tape, allow more and denser buildings, give more buildings permit. It is supply-demand! It will decrease prices for everyone. If Houston can do it, so can we!
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with government inefficiency and red tape. Want market-driven rebuilding with increased density and easier building permits. Believe this approach, like Houston's, would lower housing costs.

CONTENT: Should consider flexible housing the tiny home communities in these areas as permanent additions. These communities are often transportable so could be an option for future fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want permanent tiny home communities in fire-prone areas since they're transportable and could serve as flexible housing solutions for future wildfire displacement.

CONTENT: Restrict subdivisions in very high and high fire zones.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to stop allowing new housing developments in high-risk fire areas - it's that simple.

CONTENT: Undergrounding/hardening infrastructure. Encouraging development in existing urban areas rather than expanding into wildland interface.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want utilities underground and infrastructure hardened against fires. Development should stay in urban areas instead of pushing into wildfire-prone zones.

CONTENT: ADUs have destroyed neighborhoods and contributed to dense communities and they have not alleviated rising rents or 'housing shortages'. If a homeowner is faced with a catastrophe and have lost their home, the government must not implement harsh and costly upgrades if the homeowner wants to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Oppose ADUs for increasing density without solving housing issues. Government shouldn't burden homeowners with expensive upgrade requirements when rebuilding after losing homes to disaster.

CONTENT: We should buy out homeowners in these areas and turn unsafe zones back into wilderness. If they want to stay, they should have to pay for the true cost.
LLM_SUMMARY: Advocate for buying out homeowners in high-risk areas to restore wilderness, or make residents pay actual costs if they choose to stay in fire-prone zones.

CONTENT: not necessary to widen roads nor restrict parking in the alphabet streets, no fire for 100 years, emergency vehicles went up and down our streets without issue for the 30 years we lived there, Hartzell is a wider street and cars would fly up and down the street creating safety issues, will be too expensive to widen the streets, will slow down construction to widen the streets that only benefits those with ample resources to wait to build their homes for 4-5 years.
LLM_SUMMARY: Widening roads is unnecessary and problematic - emergency vehicles managed fine for decades. It would be expensive, delay reconstruction, and create new safety issues with faster traffic.

CONTENT: Please start encouraging developers/business owners to expand there operations, more units will decrease the price, more business will stimulate the economy
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to attract more developers and businesses to build here - more housing units and commercial activity will help lower costs and boost our local economy.

CONTENT: We all know what we would prefer our communities "look" like, but recognizing the hazards of where we live and HOW we need to build in preparation for those hazards is more important than our cultural ideal of a neighborhood. People should be willing to accept some change in how we construct buildings and develop larger settlements/communities so that fire protection can take priority.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must prioritize fire-safe construction and community development over traditional neighborhood aesthetics. Our cultural preferences should adapt to address the real hazards we face living here.

CONTENT: ADUs are a way to get people living on their properties sooner than later. Make the permitting process quick and easy for ADU and I may consider living there while I rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to live in an ADU while rebuilding my home, but need faster, simpler permitting. This could help people return to their properties sooner during reconstruction.

CONTENT: I will not commit to rebuilding until I see a plan from DWP that includes Chautauqua Blvd, North of Bestor, in underground utility installation. This area has been severely neglected by the City: road in poor shape and not paved for about 30 years, power lines transversing my property from the pole to connect to neighbor and has not been updated for decades. Bad system for a known high fire prone/high wind prone area.
LLM_SUMMARY: Won't rebuild until DWP commits to underground utilities on Chautauqua Blvd. Area's neglected infrastructure and outdated power lines are dangerous in this fire-prone

CONTENT: This is a hard one but, I think the homeowners, communities and the state need to reconsider rebuilding in areas that are known to burn over and over. Some areas have burnt multiple times and people just rebuild. Isn't this the definition of insanity?
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to stop rebuilding homes in areas that repeatedly burn. It's insane that we keep reconstructing in the same high-risk fire zones over and over again.

CONTENT:
And the cellular/wifi system needs to have local power backup, and redundancy in case nodes go down.

We need fire shelters in every at risk area... and these might as well be ultra fast track permitted little unit ADUs - affordable housing and fire shelters in one solution. With pressurized air. Also could serve as wifi/cel backup nodes to be in communications. Accessible to first responders and especially to residents in conditions that move to fast... 

Places like Topanga in the 'urban-wilderness interface' were considered high risk. As we just learned, any neighborhood with trees - at least HALF of LA - is now as higher or higher risk because closer structures are susceptible to conflagration
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about unreliable emergency communications during fires. We need backup power for cell/wifi systems and multi-purpose fire shelters that could serve as communication nodes in all at-risk neighborhoods.

CONTENT: Easy access to fire-safe building plans would help people tremendously, I think. I know some homeowners will struggle because they want to rebuild THE house, but many of those houses had outdated materials that are no longer up to code. But helping people see how they can rebuild with the proper materials will get some people over that hump quickly. Additionally, ADUs are a great way to help people earn extra income to cover their mortgages/insurance -- or to bring loved ones in when they need housing. This should be something that can be fast-tracked immediately. Long-term we all know that affordable housing is a challenge -- I'm not sure how we ever overcome the NIMBY mentality and make room for those who can't afford $3000 studio apts.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need easier access to fire-safe building plans and fast-tracked ADU permits. People want to rebuild exactly what they had, but updated materials are crucial. Affordable housing remains a major challenge.

CONTENT: It is illogical to put more people in these fire areas particularly those who cannot afford insurance or the cost of rebuilding and replacing everything.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building in fire-prone areas is unwise, especially for those who can't afford insurance or recovery costs after losing everything.

CONTENT: Climate change has made all natural events, including wild fires, more intense. We have to come to grips with the fact that there are places where NO homes should be.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must acknowledge that climate change intensifies wildfires, and accept that some areas are simply too dangerous for residential development.

CONTENT: Immediately clear the properties on PCH on reopen the road. Cal Trans wants to put in bike lanes and sidewalks before opening. We do not need that. We need a wider road for safety, not narrower lanes. We also need an emergency permit for a sewer in east Malibu to handle the rebuilds.  600 or more new individual septic systems makes no sense whatsoever.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with CalTrans prioritizing bike lanes over road reopening after fire. Want wider roads for safety and emergency access. Also need centralized sewer system instead of individual septics for rebuil

CONTENT: should not be assessed for ADU will assist folks to move back to neighborhood faster and/or could assist housing some of the trades needed to rebuild
LLM_SUMMARY: Want ADU permit fees waived to speed up neighborhood recovery - could help both returning residents and house workers needed for rebuilding efforts.

CONTENT: The state needs to plan for car-free evacuation options for every community. Cars are not a reliable way to get out of a canyon when a fire is coming. Run public shuttles or give people ebikes.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need alternatives to car evacuations during fires - they're unreliable in canyons. The state should provide public shuttles or ebikes as backup evacuation options.

CONTENT: The State needs to stop requiring jurisdictions to allow buildings in the very high fire zones in LA county. There is no buffer like other counties between woodlands and urban areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to stop allowing new construction in high-risk fire zones and create proper buffer zones between urban areas and woodlands, like other counties do.

CONTENT: What warning systems?  Palisades had evacuation routes, only there weren't nearly enough of them.  It is shocking to me that there weren't hundreds of people killed in the Palisades.  And yet development continued on, knowing full well that the routes were grossly inadequate to carry the people out fast enough.  Criminal.
LLM_SUMMARY: Outraged that limited evacuation routes put lives at risk during Palisades Fire. Despite known safety issues, development continued without addressing inadequate escape routes for residents.

CONTENT: My grandmother had a hard time getting out on Palisades Dr. There needs to be more than one way in and out of fire-affected areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about limited evacuation routes during the fire. One access road on Palisades Drive wasn't enough - grandmother struggled to evacuate. Multiple escape routes are needed.

CONTENT: It would be nice if Altadena were rebuilt to be more walkable and accessible via bike and public transportation. Let's do this right!
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to see Altadena rebuilt with better walkability, bike paths, and public transit options - let's use this opportunity to improve infrastructure.

CONTENT: The state & many cities are planning for more growth & density, w/o paying attention to flood plains & fire prone areas. Even if the area is a "high opportunity area" if it's a flood plain per FEMA, it's highly irresponsible to put more people in the path of danger. We're now having more 100-year and 500-year storms and we must adapt to climate change, not ignore it. Same goes for tsunami zones, sea level rise & erosion, we should stop advocating for false solutions like sea walls & advocate for managed retreat instead. The city must have real community engagement and conduct drills so residents can be prepared for natural disasters. Language access is crucial, not only simple to understand, but translate messages to languages people speak.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to stop building in hazardous areas and focus on real climate adaptation. Cities must engage communities in disaster preparedness with accessible, multilingual emergency planning and drills.

CONTENT: Need to have realistic evacuation routes and communications given the densities of people or restrict building to reduce the density.  Mandatory training drills might be useful.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about overcrowding affecting evacuations. Want better evacuation planning that accounts for population density, plus mandatory drills. Consider limiting new development to manage risk.

CONTENT: Insurance and Government agencies and should cover the costs and issue a public apology for their ineptness. It isn't about politics and constituencies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fed up with agencies passing blame - insurance companies and government need to take responsibility, pay for damages, and apologize for their poor handling of wildfire prevention.

CONTENT: California needs to call in Federal assistance to manage the entire state. Too much of the forest is left unkept. Need to increase logging of old forest so that areas can be managed with planting of new growth. Open it up the private companies to manage.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need federal intervention and private companies to manage California's forests through increased logging and replanting - the current overgrown forest conditions are too dangerous to maintain.

CONTENT: Please put as many power lines underground as possible.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to prioritize undergrounding power lines to prevent fires - this should be a key focus of prevention efforts.

CONTENT: Others have mentioned the elephant in the room - home owners insurance in CA. This is going to continue to be a massive problem unless a sustainable solution is found. The reality is that most of the people I grew up will not be able to afford to return to the Palisades because they were massively underinsured. This is heartbreaking.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance costs are making it impossible for many to return to the Palisades after the fire. Without a sustainable solution, underinsured residents can't afford to rebuild here.

CONTENT: I cannot tell you what a nightmare it has been for those of us who have homes still standing to navigate insurance. Most of the information at town halls and webinars was for total loss, which is a more clearly defined insurance process. The rest of us were basically expected to go back into our toxic homes and had to fight like hell for every ounce of ALE and smoke remediation to be covered. We are so grateful for Ricardo Lara and his staff for their help putting pressure on the insurance companies, but it would be great if the agents had the capacity to offer more guidance and support
LLM_SUMMARY: Dealing with insurance for smoke-damaged homes has been a nightmare - we've had to fight for coverage and support. While state officials helped pressure insurers, we need better guidance for partial damage cases

CONTENT: All debris must be cleared from all properties. It can be done privately but if anyone refuses or abandons their lot it must be removed even if a lean must be implemented against the owner and property. We can't have toxic waste that's both dangerous and unsightly to remain. Also, all the utilities must be buried underground. MUST. No exceptions.
LLM_SUMMARY: Toxic debris must be cleared from all properties, even if liens are needed to force uncooperative owners. Underground utilities are essential. No exceptions for either requirement.

CONTENT: Bury all the utility lines!
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to put utility lines underground to prevent future fire risks and outages.

CONTENT: We should be considering discontinuing natural gas lines to neighborhoods that opt in for that.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to phase out natural gas infrastructure in willing neighborhoods as part of post-fire rebuilding, rather than automatically restoring gas service everywhere.

CONTENT: The money to do this should already be a part of all the money that is being paid into the state, county and city.  Why there is almost no funds or action in the past in this area does not make any sense.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that existing tax revenue isn't being properly allocated for wildfire prevention. Can't understand why there's been such limited funding and action despite the clear need.

CONTENT:
Regarding insurance claims and premiums, no one should have any issues at all with insurance claims. Insurance companies should be lowering cost and premiums vs. raising them. When it's a known fact that insurance companies have more money than banks and are collecting around the clock; I find it hard to believe that they are somehow living paycheck to paycheck. Besides, this is the business they chose. If insurance companies want to raise cost, they should be required to provide something more like free legal assistance for tenants and undocumented immigrants. 

New requirements before permitting building of homes and buildings, fire prevention methods and materials required before issuing any permits. City, County, and State level.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should lower premiums instead of raising them since they're extremely profitable. They should provide free legal help to tenants and immigrants if they increase costs.

CONTENT:
WATER. ALL THE WATER REFORM. Make the improvements. 
(Doesn’t somebody at DWP make like $700+K/yr? —> Found some funding to get you started with.)
LLM_SUMMARY: Demanding water infrastructure improvements and reforms, suggesting funding could come from high DWP executive salaries rather than additional public costs.

CONTENT: Government at all levels should be held accountable for fire prevention along with what is being required of homeowners.
LLM_SUMMARY: Officials need to be held just as responsible as residents are for fire prevention measures - it shouldn't just fall on homeowners to meet requirements.

CONTENT: We need transparency and accountability from insurance companies, as well as from oil and gas companies. Insurance claims need to be met. Politicians must stand up to extractive capitalism. Yet we also do need to recognise that disasters are going to increase in number and scale. Life is uncertain and responsibility and accountability start with individuals. There is no magic bullet, just a hundred and one acts of daily accountability and learning to do more with less. Asking for specific ideas is great and thank you for doing so, yet what we are faced with is changing mindsets and learning to address our issues systemically. Corporations AND their shareholders need to stop driving the 'growth and increasing profits are forever' mentality.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies must be held accountable for claims, while we all need to shift away from profit-driven mindsets and accept that disasters will increase, requiring systemic changes.

CONTENT: MUST have underground power lines!  Its 2025 for goodness sakes.  The water systems are also archaic and are long overdue for an overhaul
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that power lines aren't underground yet in 2025. Water infrastructure is outdated too - both systems desperately need modernization to prevent future disasters.

CONTENT: All the departments (local and state) need to work together. Hold utility companies fully accountable
LLM_SUMMARY: We need better coordination between government agencies at all levels, and utilities must be held responsible for their role in fire prevention.

CONTENT: Local residential electric lines should never have been above ground.  They should have been below ground from the start.  The literature on this is 50 years old.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines could have prevented outages. Above-ground lines are outdated and dangerous - we've known this for decades but nothing was done about it.

CONTENT: More regulation of insurance and insurance companies. Too many people can no longer afford it
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance costs are too high and need stricter regulation - many residents can't afford coverage anymore.

CONTENT: The insurance landscape in California needs to be addressed. The FAIR plan is terrible, and private insurance companies take to long to process claims. There need to be faster ways for survivors to get access to funds after their home is destroyed.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance system is broken - FAIR plan is inadequate and private claims are too slow. We need faster ways to get money to wildfire survivors who've lost everything.

CONTENT: Most everything now burned already!  What's more neeeded is making Edison and DWP publicly owned and managed.
LLM_SUMMARY: Believes prevention focus is too late since area already burned. Advocates for public ownership of Edison and DWP utilities instead of current management structure.

CONTENT: This really equires the Mayor and Supervisors to create a list of projects and see which they can partner with the State and Federal Gov to reduce or eliminate corporate gouging and unfairness.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need local leaders to work with state and federal government on specific projects to prevent corporate price gouging during our recovery efforts.

CONTENT: Don’t just throw this on the residents trying to rebuild manage the land that is prone to fire better
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that burden falls on residents - authorities need to take more responsibility for managing fire-prone land rather than leaving it to homeowners during recovery.

CONTENT: Underground power lines are a necessity
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to move power lines underground to prevent future fire risks.

CONTENT: *The first thing I would advise is to ensure that the CPUC requires AT&T to maintain its "carrier of last resort" status, which generally also requires them to maintain landlines. We have pitiful cell service in the Canyons-and 5G can't/won't fix that, as its intense network infrastructure is generally incompatible with rural-mountain topography and economics.
LLM_SUMMARY: Worried about poor cell coverage in canyon areas. Critical to maintain AT&T landlines as backup since 5G infrastructure isn't feasible in our mountain terrain.

CONTENT: Codes need to be updated to maintain vegetation perimeters, so the fires can't spread from vegetation to houses.  If the home owner can't afford tree-trimming and so forth, the cities must help pay for this, because the cost of neighborhoods burning down is far worse.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need updated vegetation codes and city support for homeowners who can't afford maintenance. Preventing fires through proper clearance is cheaper than rebuilding burned neighborhoods.

CONTENT: Power lines should be UNDERGROUND
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are essential - this needs to happen to prevent future fires.

CONTENT: I should not have to shoulder Palisades folks rebuilding in such a high risk area.
LLM_SUMMARY: Don't want my tax dollars supporting rebuilds in high-risk fire zones like Pacific Palisades.

CONTENT: Power lines under ground please
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are needed to prevent future fire risks.

CONTENT: I am very skeptical about how all these insurance companies happened to back out 3 months before these "wildfires" happened. I also had issues with State Farm auto insurance around this time.
LLM_SUMMARY: Suspicious about insurance companies withdrawing coverage just before wildfires occurred. Had personal issues with State Farm auto insurance during this period too.

CONTENT: Every home with a pool should have a pump that will allow pool water to be accessed! In Rancho Santa Fe it is required. Insurance companies should offer incentives.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need accessible pool water for firefighting. Make it mandatory like in Rancho Santa Fe and have insurance companies incentivize this through their policies.

CONTENT:
Admittedly don't know enough here. Eaton fire started well outside of normal pedestrian infrastructure.  Only thing I can add here is that given that good fraction of the community has to start from scratch, now is a good time to revisit infra related issues such as underground power and better broadband.

The water utilities I have less info on. They seem to have bounced back pretty quickly but obviously lessons learned from this one should be considered.
LLM_SUMMARY: Since we're rebuilding from scratch, it's a perfect opportunity to improve infrastructure like underground power lines and better broadband. Water utilities recovered quickly, but we should learn from this experience.

CONTENT: I would like to see several well-publicized and documented rapid pilot programs in various communities in LA that help Angelenos understand the scope and disruption related to retrofitting old systems. Everyone wants to DWP, etc to "do it", and they absolutely must, but it would be great to understand what that looks like, how we as citizens need to willingly participate in the process when it's our neighborhood's turn, how this affects our bottom line and what kind of ecological and safety improvements this brings to our communities.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to see pilot programs showing what utility infrastructure upgrades actually look like in neighborhoods - the disruption, costs, and benefits - so residents understand and can better support these necessary improvements.

CONTENT: All important to a functioning community. As usual, the question begs - who pays for this?  Should the folks in Etna, CA be taxed for the folly of building so many high-dollar homes in an obvious fire zone? Should Modesto be on the hook for wealthy home owners in Marin or Sonoma or LA?
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about fairness in funding infrastructure repairs after fires. Questions why taxpayers across California should subsidize rebuilding in wealthy, high-risk fire zones.

CONTENT: Bury the power lines. Put in sidewalks.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need underground power lines and proper sidewalks installed - these basic infrastructure improvements are essential.

CONTENT: It is important that government provide assistance to protect individual people from illegal or unfair actions taken against them by insurance companies and/or landlords. Government should simplify the regulatory process of rebuilding but should not be using tax-payer money to issue grants for home building or for bringing existing buildings into compliance with new code requirements. Government should not be using tax-payer money to provide legal aid to undocumented residents; this should be a service provided by the private sector.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should protect us from unfair insurance companies and landlords, but shouldn't use taxpayer money for rebuilding grants, code compliance, or legal aid for undocumented residents.

CONTENT: We need to be proactive and clear brush/trash, bring back the brush eating goats and allow those that owe parking tickets to clean the freeways, like they used to. It should be illegal to start fires on the streets, public parks/forests (unless allowed to BBQ). Taxpayers should NOT be paying for the infrastructure upgrades of for profit electrical companies. When new communities are built, require power lines to be underground or have other safety measures in place that will prevent fires. Electrical companies can also educated the public and if they see something off with a powerline to say something.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need proactive brush clearing, stricter fire regulations, and underground power lines in new developments. Utility companies should fund their own infrastructure and help educate the public about fire prevention.

CONTENT: Ensure power companies are being responsible and maintaining their lines.
LLM_SUMMARY: Power companies need to be held accountable for proper maintenance of their electrical lines to prevent fires.

CONTENT: The general public has no idea how emergency communications work, much less how ECC's & EM's are staffed, much less how easily overwhelmed 9-1-1 centers (with understaffed centers) are with floods of calls during events like this; and I could go on.  Clearly, there were failures in both the LA City and LA County responses in notifying the public.  Many fell back onto the Watch Duty app, which is privately funded and operated.  It proved itself to be a MORE reliable method of getting notification than from our paid city/county employees. LA should enter into a public/private partnership with Watch Duty, making it the single app to rely on.  For connecting with residents for resources, have your websites pre-made, ready to go prior launching.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with unreliable official emergency alerts during the fire. Watch Duty app proved more effective than city/county notifications. Suggests making it the official platform through public-private partnership.

CONTENT: The experts in the insurance industry who assess fire risk need to share their information publicly.  A coordinated effort between the insurance industry, the emergence response planners in the government, and the builders could result in a much better system for everyone.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should share their fire risk data openly - better coordination between insurers, emergency planners, and builders would create a more effective system for protecting communities.

CONTENT: For those neighborhoods zoned as "very high fire risk", the city and/or utilities needs to also be held accountable on underground transmission lines, along with reviewing all city trees which are highly flammable and replace them (regardless if tress are "protected" or not), along with ensuring overgrown vegetation are trimmed back on our hillsides/mountain areas close to residents.
LLM_SUMMARY: City and utilities must take responsibility by undergrounding power lines, removing hazardous trees regardless of protected status, and managing overgrown vegetation near homes in high-risk fire zones.

CONTENT: Army Corp and LA County systems need to be in sync. There have been many ROE's lost in the system, leaving us calling daily for status without answers. Also, lets be clear on who will be paying for debris removal, insurance or "free" as what many people are being told.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by lost Right of Entry forms and confusion between agencies. Need better coordination between Army Corps and County, plus clarity on whether insurance or government covers debris removal costs.

CONTENT: Businesses are critical to providing goods to the community. Without 3rd places, a community cannot thrive. Also, set backs should be increased like after the Paradise fire, reduces spread rate of fires AND entices fire insurance companies to return.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses are vital for community wellbeing, but we need larger setbacks like Paradise implemented to reduce fire spread and bring back insurance companies.

CONTENT: Power lines should be underground.  People have been urging Edison to do this for decades.  Edison has become expert at deflection when asked about this, but no progress has been made.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that Edison hasn't moved power lines underground despite decades of community requests. They keep deflecting instead of making needed infrastructure changes to prevent fires.

CONTENT:
Renters were the most badly hurt while landlords claimed insurance money.  

More education about need for renters insurance is needed.  Earthquake policy is available from the state for homes (landlords). Loss of use policy should be offered to all renters.
LLM_SUMMARY: Renters suffered most financially while landlords had insurance coverage. We need better education about renter's insurance and state-backed coverage options for renters, similar to earthquake policies.

CONTENT: Insurance companies are not going to insure anyone in the Palisades if there is not an explanation for the 1.7.25 failure to address the fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned that insurance companies will deny coverage in Palisades area unless authorities explain and address the failures in responding to the January 7th fire incident.

CONTENT: Provide aid to all infected. Homeowners and renters, total loss and uninhabitables. You pay into insurance to be covered for emergencies and if there are no emergencies, there's no reason for rates to increase. Even where there is an emergency, rates shouldn't increase. The system needs to be overhauled, along with FEMA. The lack of financial support has caused so many to be homeless.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance and FEMA systems are failing us - rates keep rising despite paying for coverage, and insufficient aid is leaving both homeowners and renters homeless after fire damage.

CONTENT: Insurance is difficult to navigate and because it is a business, companies are doing everything they can to not pay out on claims. People who lost homes and were underinsured need assistance to close those financial gaps beyond additional loans. People need cash in hand to help with rebuilding. We saw the government response to supporting businesses during COVID with PLP loans that were forgiven. The people of Altadena need a similar benefit.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with insurance companies avoiding payouts. We need direct government financial assistance for rebuilding, similar to COVID business relief, not just loans. Insurance gaps are leaving homeowners struggling.

CONTENT: Where to start - a lot of people were being dropped by their insurance, and had a hard time getting other insurance. Some are uninsured or underinsured. People are having a hard time dealing with insurance. People need resources to know what proper fire related insurance coverage should look like and literally a how-to of navigating insurance if you have a full loss, partial loss, smoke.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are dropping coverage and people struggle to get new policies. We need guidance on proper fire coverage and help navigating insurance claims for different types of losses.

CONTENT: Attention to contaminants should be a priority for the county's environmental health department. Not left up to individual homeowners. The long-term consequences are a community concern. Funding should exist for remediation if needed. Partnerships with research institutions. Programs to make whole house water purification systems cost effective. If building density increases to fill housing needs, standards for open space on lots. The county or city could buy lots put on the market to create publicly-owned green space.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need county-led contamination cleanup, not individual efforts. Long-term environmental impacts affect everyone. Create partnerships and programs for water purification, while preserving open spaces through public land acquisition.

CONTENT: Make insurance a non-profit industry. Nobody should be profiting off of disasters. Grants should go to ALL homeowners and not just to single family residents or people who didn't pay for insurance. Why limit legal aid just to tenants & undocumented residents? Everybody else needs legal aid to deal with the insurance companies. Plus, we could all use some free financial planning to know how we are going to pay for this perfect storm of  failed infrastructure.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies shouldn't profit from disasters. Financial and legal assistance should be available to everyone affected, not just specific groups. We all need help dealing with insurance and recovery costs.

CONTENT: Bury the power lines. DO NOT make the citizens pay for it.
LLM_SUMMARY: Demanding utilities bury power lines but opposing passing those costs to residents through fees or rate increases.

CONTENT: How much longer must the public die at the hands of private corporations? Enough is enough. Create public utility systems now. It will create more jobs and will (hopefully) be updated and cared for better than private corporations ever have. Also, make internet access a human right and also a public utility. To only have one option in an area means these private corporations can charge whatever they want. It's 2025 - the internet should be accessible to all. For managing our water systems - look to Tucson, AZ. They sequester more than enough rain water to last them all year. As droughts get worse, we must sequester as much water as possible, instead of having it wash away into the ocean. There are solutions, we just need to implement them.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fed up with private utilities' failures during fires. Want public control of power, internet, and water systems. Need better infrastructure like Tucson's water management to prepare for worsening droughts

CONTENT: For profit utility companies must be required to adapt their equipment to prevent wildfires, especially where human life is at risk in urban or populated areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utility companies need to be forced to upgrade their equipment to prevent fires, particularly in populated areas where lives are at stake.

CONTENT: Eliminate the need for personal property inventory to get one’s entire personal property coverage! Studies show creating that list is the most traumatic part of recovery. We didn’t pay 75% of our insurance premium, why do we only get 75% of our coverage without being forced to do something so traumatic?!
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that insurance requires traumatic itemized inventory of lost belongings to receive full coverage. Want automatic full payout since we paid premiums - the current 75% default isn't fair.

CONTENT: For those who are under insured, the gap to rebuild relative to insurance proceeds is very large. There needs to be some form of assistance for those who are on the CA Fair Plan.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance coverage through CA Fair Plan falls far short of actual rebuilding costs. We desperately need financial assistance programs to help underinsured homeowners bridge this massive gap.

CONTENT: Require SCE to bury ALL power lines. Make utilities publicly owned.
LLM_SUMMARY: Strongly advocate for underground power lines and public ownership of utilities to prevent future fire risks and service disruptions.

CONTENT: Underground, underground power lines! 100%
LLM_SUMMARY: Strongly advocate for underground power lines as the solution for infrastructure protection and fire prevention.

CONTENT: Bury the power lines… seems like fires often start with exposed lines
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to bury power lines underground since they're frequently the source of wildfires when exposed above ground.

CONTENT:
New homes to be built, could be solar equipped,  landscaping planted to minimize danger to structures, environmentally safe etc…
We need to lessen our reliance on power companies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want new construction to require solar power and fire-resistant landscaping to reduce both wildfire risks and dependence on utility companies.

CONTENT: Underground authority needs to be given to the County/City so that there is not a statewide/utility/personal property owner fight over where these lines go. The political cost of comprimising will be prohibitively expensive and too slow to make a lasting difference. Reducing future risk of and to infrastructure should be priority #1.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need local control over underground utility placement, not state/utility battles. The current political compromises are too costly and slow. Prioritize infrastructure risk reduction.

CONTENT: Utilities need to move fast. Should be incentivized with a reduced lawsuit if they move fast.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need utilities to act quickly after fires. Give them legal protection as motivation to restore services faster.

CONTENT: Lets be honesto, insurance companies Will not be on the side for most of their clients. The new innovative residential-commercial structures, Will be Accord with the actual building regulations,
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies won't truly support most clients. New buildings will at least meet current regulations, but that's the bare minimum we can expect.

CONTENT:
Private insurers are leaving the state. Fair plan is already at risk of insolvency. We cannot afford to have to rebuild whole towns - and DESTROY whole communities and culture. Insurers, the state and especially RE-INSURANCE co's have every reason to invest substantially to reduce the risk to near zero of fires that spread to any residential area in LA County. 

Every home at the perimeter should have subsidized water and retardant systems, detectors and a wide boundary around these residential areas should have thorough brush clearance (Goats, sheep, fairly paid incarcerated) to inhibit the spread of fire from starting conflagration - where hot burning homes ignite homes from high infrared, not even sparks needed. 

HUGE VALUE & ROI
LLM_SUMMARY: We need insurers and the state to invest in prevention - subsidized home protection systems and proper brush clearance around communities. It's cheaper than rebuilding entire towns after fires.

CONTENT: Reduce red tape.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need less bureaucracy and paperwork to get help.

CONTENT:
Power companies should be required, to keep us informed, truly informed about the state of, equipment they are responsible for.
Consumers are hardly informed, regarding critical information, about the state of the infrastructure we rely on.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need power companies to be more transparent about their equipment's condition and infrastructure status - we're kept in the dark about critical information that affects us.

CONTENT: let's work to ensure these communities meet the strictest of standards for fire resistance.  government needs to use taxpayer money to invest in our communities.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need strict fire safety standards in our communities, and government must invest taxpayer money to make this happen.

CONTENT: Citizens are intelligent and will be empowered if government steps aside. They will find sources without government marketing.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should let citizens take charge of finding their own emergency information sources rather than controlling the flow of communication.

CONTENT: Again, this would be great, but I predict it would get so tied up by various interest groups I almost would rather you not bother. Please just slash regulations, stop trying to control prices, and let people get to work.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by bureaucracy, I'd prefer less government intervention. Just reduce regulations and price controls so businesses can operate freely and recover naturally.

CONTENT:
Insurance companies had been moving out of this market, cancelling policies and raising the cost of premiums to the point of being unaffordable.

Rebuilding with fire, earthquake and storm resistant materials along with structure strengthening measures should be promoted as one way to help reduce insurance costs.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are abandoning our market and making coverage unaffordable. We need incentives for fire-resistant rebuilding to help lower insurance costs.

CONTENT: Hold utilities and energy companies accountable and make them pay if they want to do business in this city. Build more affordable public housing with the purpose of ensuring everyone in the city has a safe dwelling and to reduce housing costs across the city. Protect our migrant community from violent federal deportation initiatives. Fund and platform grassroots campaigns (not non-profits and private businesses) that are speaking out on the pain working class Angelenos are facing every day.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to hold utilities accountable, build affordable housing, protect migrants, and support grassroots campaigns that represent working-class voices - not just corporations and non-profits.

CONTENT: Protect tax payers with services and systems that they expect to exist as a mandate
LLM_SUMMARY: We deserve the wildfire prevention services and systems we pay for through our taxes - it should be a guaranteed mandate.

CONTENT: The economic penalty must be severe so that utilities. invest in prevention.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need harsh financial penalties to force utility companies to properly invest in wildfire prevention measures.

CONTENT:
We need you to extend the mandate that insurance companies not drop us. We have always paid our premiums and this loss had nothing to do with any of the insureds. But we risk having fully uninsured homes due to the fires. 

People with standing homes need clear guidance on the safety of living amongst and near burned structures. We need financial assistance- so many people not within the burn map boundary are just as displaced and have lost just as much but cannot access aid because of the map boundaries which weren’t drawn to facilitate aid, but that’s how it’s being used.
LLM_SUMMARY: Urgently need extended insurance protection and clear safety guidance for living near burned areas. Aid shouldn't be restricted by burn map boundaries - many affected people outside those lines need help too.

CONTENT: I will not commit to rebuilding until I see a plan from DWP that includes Chautauqua Blvd, North of Bestor, in underground utility installation. This area has been severely neglected by the City: road in poor shape and not paved for about 30 years, power lines transversing my property from the pole to connect to neighbor and has not been updated for decades. Bad system for a known high fire prone/high wind prone area.
LLM_SUMMARY: Refusing to rebuild until DWP commits to underground utilities on Chautauqua Blvd. Current overhead power lines and neglected infrastructure are dangerous in this fire-prone,

CONTENT: Many people's insurances pulled out and now they are left with nothing. Steps need to be taken to ensure that people can get the money they deserve to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies abandoning us left many with nothing. We need measures to guarantee people receive proper compensation to rebuild after losing everything.

CONTENT: I'd want to see more of a push to get electrical utility owners to prevent their equipment for starting fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need stronger pressure on utility companies to maintain their equipment and prevent it from causing fires. They must be held accountable.

CONTENT:
When a person calls their insurance company after a fire - you'd expect they'd receive an A-Z step by step "Here's how to file and complete your claim." Instead, they get "You're in a dark room, find the light switch"

The insurance piece of this is very complicated. But the claims part need not be. This is something where the Dept can make quick and substantive changes overnight. Force guidelines for claims to be clear and easy to follow.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance claims after fires are needlessly complicated and confusing. The Department should require insurance companies to provide clear, step-by-step guidelines for filing claims.

CONTENT: It's essential that we have a water system capable of fighting wildfires and an electric system that doesn't spark them, but the costs shouldn't be borne by utility customers in safer areas. Pay for wildfire upgrades to this infrastructure using higher property taxes on the homeowners who chose to buy and build in dangerous areas. If you want to take the risk by choosing to live in wildfire zones, you'd better pay for it. That would also help people better understand the tradeoffs they're making.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need better water and power systems for wildfires, but high-risk area residents should pay for upgrades through property taxes, not all utility customers. Make people understand the cost of their choices

CONTENT: Force Insurance Companies to cover toxin testing inside smoke damaged homes. If the health department says we should be concerned about this why does insurance refuse to cover it? How can we feel safe moving back in our homes. The testing is very expensive…$5-$10 thousand depending on tests necessary. We paid close to $7000.00 out of pocket and are awaiting results. Many do not have the resources to pay for this themselves.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should be required to cover indoor toxin testing after smoke damage. The high cost ($5-10K) prevents many from confirming their homes are safe to reoccupy.

CONTENT: The insurance market is a disaster. I was told days before the fire that my insurance carrier no longer met the rating requirements of my mortgage lender so I cancelled my insurance policy effective 1/10/25 while my wife and I were getting quotes with other companies. We were going to be underwritten on 1/10/25 but the moratorium after the fires stopped that process and we couldn’t reinstate our previous policy because I cancelled it before the fires but it wouldn’t fulfill my mortgage requirements anyways. After 10 days of no insurance immediately after the fires, we joined the FAIR plan and then got charged an insane amount from our lender for the lapse in insurance coverage. My house didn’t burn and still no word from other insurers!
LLM_SUMMARY: Caught in insurance limbo when switching carriers right before the fire. Couldn't get new coverage due to fire moratorium, got stuck with expensive FAIR plan, and hit with penalties for coverage

CONTENT: The power lines MUST be buried, and the cost should be absorbed by the power companies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities should be forced to pay for undergrounding power lines to prevent future fires. This isn't something residents should have to fund.

CONTENT:
Holding agencies accountable should be a given. Public or private sector must pay the price of their failure, poor decision, negligence, or plain recklessness.
How about transparency too: known system weaknesses should be communicated truthfully to the community so we can better prepare in the event of a fire: no water in hydrants when the power is shut down, no remote emergency shut-off for gas are 2 that come to mind
LLM_SUMMARY: Agencies must face consequences for failures and negligence. We need transparency about infrastructure weaknesses like powerless hydrants and gas shutoffs so communities can properly prepare for fires.

CONTENT: Except majority of this disaster recovery, for example, was in the form of private donations redistributed to individuals, and in federal support like FEMA and ACE.  What we need is local govt funds to go towards infrastructures that are severely lacking (when was the last time you drove LA and didn't dodge a massive pothole?) and without raising taxes on individuals.  We already pay plenty to keep this all running smoothly.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that recovery relied on private donations and federal aid. Want local government to fix infrastructure using existing tax revenue instead of raising taxes on residents.

CONTENT: We know why there wasn't enough water. DWP never built the water system to fight a wildfire. Now we know we have to rebuild the water system to support delivering more water faster. Make the communities who chose to live in the high risk areas pay for the upgrades.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that inadequate water infrastructure failed during fire. Believes high-risk communities should bear costs of necessary water system upgrades for future wildfire response.

CONTENT: I don't understand why we have above ground power lines in fire prone areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that power lines remain above ground in fire-prone areas, putting our community at unnecessary risk.

CONTENT: If I rebuild, I want a guarantee I can acquire the necessary fire insurance to cover my loss.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need assurance that I can get fire insurance coverage before committing to rebuilding my home after the wildfire damage.

CONTENT: Unground power lines. Pay for it  DO NOT make the citizens pay for it. Use new technology ie drones to asses fire risk on windy Santa Ana days. Pre deploy the Fire Dept. Brush Clearance on city, county, and state land is a MUST.
LLM_SUMMARY: Demanding utilities pay for underground power lines, not residents. Want drone monitoring during Santa Ana winds, proactive fire department deployment, and mandatory brush clearance on government lands.

CONTENT: Don't outsource our emergency warning systems to private companies who put peoples lives in the hands of an AI model. Competent human beings able to talk to all emergency services and make good decisions please.
LLM_SUMMARY: Strongly oppose using AI and private companies for emergency warnings. We need qualified humans who can coordinate directly with emergency services to make critical decisions.

CONTENT: Underground utilities!
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to move power lines underground to prevent future fire risks.

CONTENT: Ensure existing homeowners near affected areas won’t have their insurance skyrocket when their renewals come due.
LLM_SUMMARY: Worried about insurance rates spiking during policy renewals for those living near the burn areas. Need protection from excessive premium increases.

CONTENT: Bury power lines underground! Prevent damage from the wind every year, and extra wear-and-tear by being exposed to the elements all year long.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are needed to prevent wind damage and reduce wear from weather exposure - this would help avoid outages during fires.

CONTENT:
Insurance is the main financial driver in recovery. our insurance department, in the last decade has done very little to refine and make the claims process better for citizens.

Making claims more transparent, making policies which make more sense, it isn't rocket science.

90% of folks end up underinsured. Not an accident. A failed system.

When HO3 policies are approved in this state - the Dept should force companies to reveal their claims process and then hold them to it after a disaster.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with insurance system's lack of transparency and reform. Claims process is difficult, policies are confusing, and most people are underinsured. Insurance companies need more oversight and accountability.

CONTENT: L.A. County provides broadband coverage in all inhabited areas. More revenue for restoration and less money for the Spectrums of the world.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want county to prioritize public broadband infrastructure funding over private providers like Spectrum, especially for post-fire restoration efforts.

CONTENT: Why are electrical lines above ground?
LLM_SUMMARY: Questioning why power lines aren't underground, suggesting this as an obvious fire prevention measure that hasn't been implemented.

CONTENT: All of LADWP’s/SCE’s power lines should be buried. Access in and out of mountain communities needs to be improved, driving should not be the only option (the problem with driving being the only option for evacuation can be seen by all the abandoned cars on sunset). The state/federal govt funded a Santa Monica mountains bus service back in the 70s that snaked around mountains for a summer season, bringing that back will help alleviate congestion and can provide more evacuation alternatives.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need buried power lines and better evacuation options beyond just driving. A mountain bus service like we had in the 70s would help reduce congestion and provide alternative escape routes.

CONTENT: The entire insurance system in California should be completely reimagined. There must be a system that is accessible, cannot be canceled or reduced based on statewide costs and mandates and is sustainable over time.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance system needs total overhaul to be more accessible, stable and sustainable. Current system isn't working for California wildfire victims with constant cancellations and coverage reductions.

CONTENT: ADU shall not be a requirement regardless of CA housing shortage.
LLM_SUMMARY: ADUs shouldn't be forced on us during rebuilding, even with California's housing crisis. This is about restoring our homes, not solving state housing issues.

CONTENT: I am wary to putting resources in one place because of a lack of redundancy and crowding.  It would make sense to bundle like resources together, but spread it out so people can get to it.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about concentrating emergency resources in a single location. While grouping similar resources makes sense, they should be distributed across multiple sites to ensure accessibility and avoid overcrowding.

CONTENT: Allowing more flexibility with adding ADUs will support our entire community. Can this be incentivized in some way.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want more flexible ADU policies and incentives to help rebuild our community after the fire. This could benefit everyone in the neighborhood.

CONTENT: Don't need tax relief as much as streamlining approvals to get businesses back open, and densifying neighborhoods to make small businesses more profitable. Best way to assist local businesses is to get them back open again and as easily accessible as possible.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need faster business reopening approvals and denser neighborhoods to help small businesses recover and become profitable again. Quick reopening and accessibility are more important than tax relief.

CONTENT:
Infrastructural changes are necessary. They are also incredibly expensive. Burying power lines throughout the city is incredibly expensive... who is going to pay for it? You need a more robust, dense tax base. 

These analyses of different cities have been done by Urban3, which reveals how tax revenue/acre increases with density. Greater density would easily help to fund the necessary infrastructure improvements.
LLM_SUMMARY: Burying power lines is crucial but expensive. We need higher population density to create a stronger tax base that can fund these essential infrastructure improvements.

CONTENT: Housing policies must change--it's why California loses close to ~100k people annually. Allow density--ADUs, small apartment buildings, big apartment buildings. Less public comments where elderly homeowners of multi-million dollar properties get to gripe about more people living in their neighborhood. This problem will not be remedied without embracing density.
LLM_SUMMARY: Housing density restrictions must be loosened to allow ADUs and apartments. Current policies let wealthy homeowners block development, driving people out of California and worsening our problems.

CONTENT: It seems like a misnomer and false lead to say that wildfire, rather than wildfire risk reduction, can be prevented in the current way we build infrastructure, where land uses are sited, or how humans behave. Effective approaches such as managed retreat and undergrounding of electrical infrastructure are either too costly, too politically charged, or other "too" that prevents long-term effective change. It takes some strong political will along with a growth plan (with growth limits) to say that some areas, like repeated burn communities, are off limits to development.
LLM_SUMMARY: We can't truly prevent wildfires without addressing development in high-risk areas and making costly infrastructure changes. Political will is needed to limit growth in repeatedly burned communities.

CONTENT: Insurance companies make their money on being able to predict risk. I think if an insurer says it's too risky to live somewhere, we should listen.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies know how to assess risk - if they're refusing coverage in certain areas, that's a clear warning sign we need to take seriously.

CONTENT: Warehousing of resources is easy with more responsible developmental practices. More people living more densely = more dense collection of resources.
LLM_SUMMARY: Dense urban development could help concentrate emergency resources where they're needed most, making them easier to manage and distribute during disasters.

CONTENT: The evacuation notice came ridiculously late. It should’ve come immediately when the fire department first knew that the fire was out of control and could not be contained. Serious consideration should be given to putting in an interchange at the sunset and Pacific Coast Highway intersection that eliminates the traffic light there for traffic getting onto the PCH South. The Chautauqua PCH intersection is another bottleneck, and evacuation needs to be prioritized immediately during an emergency event.
LLM_SUMMARY: Evacuation notice was unacceptably delayed. We need faster alerts when fires become uncontrollable. Traffic bottlenecks at PCH intersections must be fixed to improve evacuation

CONTENT: People need places to live, but I don't think it should be in high-risk fire zones if we can help it. Pay the people who lost their homes, but rebuild high-density housing in urban areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should compensate those who lost homes but stop rebuilding in fire-prone areas. Instead, focus on developing high-density housing in safer urban locations.

CONTENT: In high-risk areas, further development must be tied to adequate evacuation routes
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to ensure any new construction in fire-prone areas includes proper evacuation planning - it's critical for community safety.

CONTENT: These individually are complex and under performing. While ADU are touted as providing low income housing, this is not necessarily true. Many in my area are lucrative sources of income. ADU units also do not accommodate families.  Long term housing is more than a notion it means establishing the family home and social structure. The most recent disaster should not be a basis to justify reinventing neighborhoods to the image of concrete jungles and multi family rentals.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned that ADUs aren't truly solving low-income housing needs and worried that post-fire rebuilding could transform neighborhoods away from traditional family homes into dense rental developments.

CONTENT: should not waste time and money widening roads, not necessary and not feasible; could put power lines underground if this does not delay construction and if it is feasible; need to work 24/7 to meet building demands and lesson congestion
LLM_SUMMARY: Opposed to road widening as unnecessary. Support underground power lines if feasible and quick. Want round-the-clock construction work to meet demands and reduce congestion.

CONTENT: I think the ADU units are a good idea the city should allow more people to build them with less restrictions.  Allow contractors to build more apartment building in restricted residential areas
LLM_SUMMARY: Want fewer restrictions on ADUs and apartment construction in residential areas - would help with housing needs after the fire devastated so many homes.

CONTENT: There should always be multiple ways out of a community.  LA Board of Supervisors should not approve developments that have only one way in and out of a canyon.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need multiple evacuation routes - it's dangerous that supervisors allow developments with only one way in and out of canyons.

CONTENT: Pre-permitted ADU designs. Most folks are not picky about how an ADU looks- they want fast build and understandable regulations- so they can earn rent.... which creates more housing in LA.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want pre-approved ADU designs to speed up rebuilding and create rental income. Don't care much about aesthetics - just need clear rules and quick construction to add housing.

CONTENT: REALLY speed up the approval process. Also, strongly encourage bungalow courts for multi-family housing-- basically groupings of 4 to 10 ADU-type buildings. They suit the Alta/Pasadena aesthetic, are affordable, are much better looking than flat, generic boxes, and will help bring renters to our community.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want faster building approvals and support for bungalow court-style housing developments. These match our neighborhood's character, remain affordable, and help attract renters to rebuild our community.

CONTENT: Upzone the burned areas to increase the value of the land so that the homeowners can be made whole.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want burned areas upzoned to increase land value and help homeowners recover their losses through higher property values.

CONTENT:
We know from scientific experts that the buildings were the fuel for the fire NOT the trees and bushes. Create pocket parks on lots that homeowners wish to sell. These parks will provide fuel breaks for future fires and also enhance the neighborhoods. 
Plant oak trees!! Oaks catch flying embers and can protect structures.
Do NOT add housing density to this area. It is a high fire zone and cannot carry the density nor can the infrastructure.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about fire safety, I want pocket parks as fuel breaks and oak trees to catch embers. Adding housing density here is dangerous - the infrastructure can't support it.

CONTENT: Have you seen what's happening with rent lately? Of course we need more housing. Otherwise rent is going to keep going up up up. We've got to build somewhere, and since homeowners have been opposing density in safer areas for decades, communities grew outwards instead. That's how we ended up with so many people in fire zones like Altadena and the Palisades. But yeah, we've got to have better sewer, road, power, and water planning too.
LLM_SUMMARY: Housing shortages pushed development into fire-prone areas. While we need more housing to control rent costs, it must come with proper infrastructure planning for utilities and services.

CONTENT: The agencies Hazard planning as part of the General plans are a joke. Bike lanes and roadway reductions with no plan to evacuate. Most say shelter in place.  Overbuilding and no plan to evacuate.  Big tragedy and then the problem is ignored.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that hazard planning prioritizes bike lanes over evacuation routes. Concerned about overdevelopment without adequate emergency exit plans, while officials default to "shelter in place" recommendations.

CONTENT: The entire state's infrastructure is falling apart. Why were laws passed to allow a massive increase in housing density with no planning for sewers, roads, power, water etc.   This question is a joke even before the fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that state laws allow increased housing density without adequate infrastructure planning for basic utilities and services - these systemic problems existed even before fire damage.

CONTENT: Many schools in the surrounding areas have closed down. Consider buying those lots and building affordable housing, like little communities around green spaces for those impacted by fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Suggests converting closed school properties into affordable housing developments with green spaces to help those displaced by wildfires rebuild their communities.

CONTENT: The city should also make it easier to turn single family homes into duplexes and triplexes.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need the city to streamline the process of converting single-family homes into multi-unit properties to address housing needs.

CONTENT: In addition to the clear failures in both fires, both locations, for notifications, I personally watched an area of Hollywood evacuated by emergency alert, then watched as approximately 10,000 cars all attempted to exit out of the area at exactly the same time; leading to some being stuck in their garages up to 2 hours after the initial evacuation notice went out, because of the massive log-jam of traffic. This was a complete failure in terms of communication/notification.  There was NO traffic control in advance of this notification which should have been required before sending it, especially for a high-density area.  There's no identified evacuation routes for these types of situations.
LLM_SUMMARY: Poor evacuation planning led to massive traffic jams, with thousands stuck trying to leave at once. No traffic control or designated routes made the situation dangerous and chaotic.

CONTENT: Building back the same houses in the same spaces without adjustments just means our town will burn in the same way in 20 years. Also, all those ADUs people will be living in just mean no parking and a lack of safe roads in another emergency.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned that rebuilding without changes will lead to future fire risks. Additional housing units create parking issues and compromise emergency access routes.

CONTENT: We're already in a rent crisis, and the wildfires are just fanning the flames. Everyone is being exploited; not just residents, but also small business owners! (You want to know why tacos are so expensive? RENT! Why doctors are so expensive? RENT! Why so few community spaces exist? RENT!) If we want our economy to recover from COVID and the fire, we need high-density housing, and we need LOTS of it FAST. Even if it's not financially sensible for developers. We ought to stop pouring money into subsidies that just make the housing market rise even faster; let's build high quality public housing and roll back our ridiculous zoning laws. Let's do whatever it takes; even give a housing agency right of first refusal on all real estate sales.
LLM_SUMMARY: High rents were already crushing our community before the fire. We desperately need more high-density and public housing, with less restrictive zoning laws, to help our area truly recover.

CONTENT: Ensure long-term rebuilding is climate-smart, denser, resilient to future fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want rebuilding efforts to prioritize climate-resilient, higher-density housing that can better withstand future wildfires.

CONTENT: Build more multi-family dwellings, eliminate the restrictions on duplex and triplex in single family zoning, build more and build everywhere.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to eliminate single-family zoning restrictions and allow more multi-family housing development across all areas to increase housing density and availability.

CONTENT: If we insist that neighborhoods have to be nothing but single family homes, we're never going to solve the housing crisis. I'd rather have a concrete jungle than see my neighbors sleeping on hard cement.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to allow more than just single-family homes to address the housing crisis - dense development is better than having people homeless on the streets.

CONTENT: The city needs to build more public affordable housing and change zoning restrictions to allow for more multi-use properties. Those affected by the fires and those already facing housing insecurity are facing price gouging of rents and over-inflated property values making it impossible to live in this city, even before the fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that high rents and property values, worsened by the fires, make living here impossible. Want city to create affordable housing and change zoning laws for more housing options.

CONTENT: More transit-oriented development, prioritization of ecosystem health and fire resistant construction materials/design.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to focus on transit-oriented development while using fire-resistant building materials and protecting the ecosystem as we rebuild our communities.

CONTENT: Modify zoning in the impacted areas to rebuild in a sustainable way, while also keeping the characters of the neighborhood still intact. Streamline the process for building.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to rebuild sustainably while preserving neighborhood character, but need simpler zoning and permitting processes to make it happen efficiently.

CONTENT: Build SROs
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to see more single room occupancy housing built to help those displaced by fires.

CONTENT: We need new ways of evacuating that don't rely on cars.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need alternative evacuation methods beyond just driving, since roads get too congested during emergencies.

CONTENT: Quit building structures in places in fire prone areas.  The state and Weiner specifically have gone gun-ho in encouraging building in stupid places and passed laws which leave the local agencies powerless to design their own communities.   The population is barely growing yet there is a housing crisis. First thing OUTLAW Short Term Rental Airbnb's, tax the heck out of second/vacation homes, tax the wealthy so they cannot afford 3 and 4 homes while the rest of us are forced to rent.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by state overriding local control to build in fire-prone areas. Believes housing crisis could be solved by restricting short-term rentals, taxing vacation homes, and limiting

CONTENT: Relax Malibu overprotectiveness and overreach; allow small ADU’s with less code restriction, but with fire resistant materials.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want less restrictive building codes to allow ADUs, while still requiring fire-resistant materials. Current Malibu regulations are too protective and limiting.

CONTENT: I think it's really important to consider where to rebuild, and where not to rebuild. My grandmother's home burned down, and everyone in her community wants to rebuild in the same place. But does it really make sense when we know that the Palisades Highlands is in an extremely high fire risk area? To the extent that folks want to rebuild in high risk areas, should the entire state of California shoulder that risk through our tax dollars and insurance payments?
LLM_SUMMARY: Questioning whether rebuilding in high-risk fire zones like Palisades Highlands makes sense, especially when the financial burden falls on all California taxpayers and insurance holders.
