CONTENT: Home owners should be able to use Natural gas. It's more reliable and affordable than all electric mandates. Not allowing apartments in single family areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with electric mandates, I want natural gas options for reliability and affordability. Keep single-family zoning intact.

CONTENT: Efforts to streamline the housing re-permitting process for fire victims should be expanded to include everyone else. By making this process more efficient we could increase the supply of housing, reducing cost.
LLM_SUMMARY: The permitting process for rebuilding after fires should be made more efficient and expanded beyond just fire victims to help increase overall housing supply and affordability.

CONTENT:
Regarding evac routes: like Paradise, CA, my town has only one road that leads into and out of the area. It's a narrow, winding two-lane road, making evacuation slow. It's essential that people be able to leave well before evacuation becomes mandatory (see my earlier note about temporary housing coverage gaps), so that we aren't all trying to navigate that route at the same time under duress. 

There are two other potential evac routes--an unpaved route through a State Forest and a paved road that's half collapsed due to erosion. Both are currently impassable and essentially death traps, but they could be turned into functional evacuation routes if funds were made available. I'm sure similar opportunities exist in other communities.
LLM_SUMMARY: Limited evacuation options are dangerous - our only viable route is a narrow two-lane road. Other potential escape routes exist but need funding to become usable alternatives for community safety.

CONTENT: We need deregulation and free permitting. building Codes are great and needed for public safety but then why is government penalizing citizens, owners and builders by charging them to implement safety codes. Makes no sense! Property taxes are already excessive and should already cover this expense and service to promote safety and avoid the need for people to dodge code or safety requirements.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that building permit fees discourage safety code compliance. Government shouldn't charge us to implement required safety measures - property taxes should cover these costs instead.

CONTENT:
The government's attacking insurance, as someone from the southeast US, is strange. Governmental agencies let the city of LA develop and sprawl into high fire-risk areas. Insurance companies, like when people build beachfront homes in hurricane country, jacked up the insurance rates. When an insurance company says an area is dangerous, believe them.

Forcing other taxpayers to supplement a "wood home in a tinderbox" is ludicrous. Saying it's the homeowners' fault for having a home in a tinderbox is likewise insane; they aren't fire experts.

The blame for the Palisades fire's destruction lays at the feet of the negligent county, city, and state level officials who allowed people to build/buy homes and root their lives in the line of fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government officials are responsible for letting development occur in high-risk fire zones, then blaming insurance companies and homeowners when fires destroy properties. We shouldn't have been allowed to build here.

CONTENT:
Infrastructural changes are necessary. They are also incredibly expensive. Burying power lines throughout the city is incredibly expensive... who is going to pay for it? You need a more robust, dense tax base. 

These analyses of different cities have been done by Urban3, which reveals how tax revenue/acre increases with density. Greater density would easily help to fund the necessary infrastructure improvements.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need buried power lines for safety, but it's too expensive without increasing population density to generate more tax revenue per acre to fund these improvements.

CONTENT:
Over the last few years, as a private property owner, I have received Brush Clearance notices for my property. At one point, I was substantially fined - although I had documentation my lot was clear. No matter what had been happening in my life (a parent passing, Covid, a sick child) I was required to clear brush on my property. Why isn’t the City, County, State held to these same requirements? 

I also think basic services that prioritize the safety of our communities - the police, fire department, schools, infrastructure - need to be funded first. We pay too high of taxes in LA and CA for these services not be available to residents when they are needed (ie; firefighters to put out fires, fire hydrants that work, etc)
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that private property owners face strict brush clearance enforcement and fines while government entities seem exempt. Our high taxes should prioritize funding basic safety services and infrastructure first.

CONTENT: The behavior of the California Fair Plan to deny smoke damage claims is unacceptable and the lack of other choices for insurance is not ok. What can be done to bring insurance companies back to CA?
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by California Fair Plan denying smoke damage claims and lack of insurance options. Want solutions to bring more insurance companies back to California.

CONTENT: The Army Corps of Engineers is doing a great job.  After the ACE has done it's job, there should be an additional step of testing for soil and water quality.  If the city can't pay for it, then it should be covered under the California Fair Plan "Ordinance of Law" line item.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want ACE's debris removal work followed up with soil and water quality testing. If city can't fund these essential tests, they should be covered under California Fair Plan's Ordinance provisions.

CONTENT: We have specific questions about the California Fair Plan.  What construction features are covered under the "Ordinance or Law" item in the CFP policy?  At one point I heard Steve Soboroff say that everyone should hire an attorney.  I don't think that everyone should have to hire an attorney to get the fair benefit of their fire insurance policy.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with California Fair Plan's unclear coverage terms and concerned about needing lawyers just to get fair insurance benefits. Shouldn't have to hire attorneys to understand policy details.

CONTENT: Underground utilities without delay
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to move utilities underground immediately to prevent future fire damage.

CONTENT: I agree with the idea that there is corporate gouging and unfairness going on, because we all know this is happening, it's just the state doesn't want to put money into audits to catch and stop it from happening.  But I don't think the government elects (Mayor and Supervisors) need to manage something like this.  It would be like allowing the fox to watch over the hen house.  They already don't do a good job at their jobs, which is why we are in the state we are in.  So why give them more authority to come up with more projects, to give away more of our taxpayers money that will go more to waste?   I agree with the prior statement, let charities take this on if they feel the need to.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government shouldn't manage economic recovery - they already mismanage taxpayer money. Let charities handle support instead of giving officials more control over funds that might be wasted.

CONTENT: Power lines should be below ground
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are needed to prevent future fires and outages.

CONTENT: I've never understood why there are above ground electric wires in Angeles National Forest and Eaton Canyon specifically. The area is prone to fires! Get those underground or out of the park!
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that above-ground power lines still exist in fire-prone Angeles National Forest and Eaton Canyon. Strongly believe these should be buried underground or removed entirely.

CONTENT: Underinsured homeowners can't afford the new code requirements.  Grants and tax relief should be provided to ease that burden.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that underinsurance leaves homeowners unable to meet new building codes. Want government to provide financial relief through grants and tax breaks to help cover costs.

CONTENT: We must not, under ANY circumstances, bail out SoCal Edison the way Newsom bailed out his buddies at PG&E after Paradise. Enough is enough!
LLM_SUMMARY: Strongly opposed to government bailouts for utility companies like SoCal Edison, drawing parallels to PG&E's Paradise fire bailout. Demands accountability from power companies.

CONTENT:
Underground power lines, holding Edison corporate accountable, not letting Edison pass on their mistakes onto the cost of their customers. Every time they go into litigation or bills go up. 

When they need to shut off power due to weather - my husband can’t work. So he doesn’t get paid. 

The way palisades and Altadena need to be rebuilt needs to be smart. All street lights need to be solar, solar cross walks, a better environment and a safer environment for kids.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with Edison's accountability and costs passed to customers during outages. Want smarter rebuilding with underground power lines and solar infrastructure for a safer community.

CONTENT: Both our electric systems and water systems should make more use of local supplies -- micro-grids for the electric system and water capture and grey water for the water systems.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to shift toward localized utility systems - using micro-grids for electricity and local water capture/grey water systems to make our infrastructure more resilient.

CONTENT: What is wildfire adaptation? Fire-resistant design and preparedness training are not the City's role; let Angelenos, their architects, and private organizations do this.
LLM_SUMMARY: City should stay out of wildfire adaptation efforts like fire-resistant design and preparedness. These should be handled by residents, architects, and private organizations, not government.

CONTENT: Bury the utilities and mandate solar
LLM_SUMMARY: We need underground power lines and required solar panels to prevent future fire risks and outages.

CONTENT: Insurance is a key lever that needs to be addressed here, in service to the whole of the economy.  Insurance providers have known for DECADES about the risks they face with respect to climate, and as an industry, they have not acted with enough innovative approaches to changing incentives for more regenerative decisions.  They have not faced the truth of what is facing all of us with respect to climate risk, and they are brittle and wholly unprepared from a business model perspective to respond to the realities of what they are facing.  We need to redesign business models, incentives, and policies to face the realities of the calamities that we are facing as a community.  There is only going to be more of the same in the future.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies have failed to innovate or adapt their business models to address climate risks, despite knowing about them for decades. We need complete redesign of policies and incentives.

CONTENT: This is essential and should be done by private enterprise to the extent feasible. Large infrastructure contractors can do this much faster than Public Works or LADWP and likely more cost-effectively. This is not the time for political egos to eye ad opportunities for the next election; move out of the way and let the city rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Bring in private contractors instead of public agencies - they'll restore infrastructure faster and more efficiently. Government needs to step aside and let experts handle rebuilding without political interference.

CONTENT: The CA Department of Insurance has put a number of excellent laws and regulations together that make dealing with the insurance providers somewhat easier for a homeowner customer. However the industry wide marketing of disaster (Homeowner)’insurance has led to virtually no polices promising to rebuild “no matter what” and substituting coverages that seem to fully protect and do not, leaving most homeowners underinsured which means they can’t afford to rebuild and can’t stay in their home because it has burned to the ground. This needs to be worked out with the insurance providers and the Dept of Insurance and the homeowners needing and wanting the protection of a policy that will help them in a catastrophe, rather than add to it.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance regulations help, but misleading coverage marketing leaves most homeowners underinsured. We need better collaboration between insurers and regulators to create policies that truly protect homeowners during disasters.

CONTENT: California's insurance system requires a complete overhaul—it is currently more complicated than the tax code. This issue must be addressed in clear, straightforward terms before any funds are allocated. Otherwise, the same problems will arise during the next disaster.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance system is too complex and needs major reform before allocating disaster funds. Current complications will only create more problems during future wildfires.

CONTENT: We could rethink home insurance entirely. Maybe it should not be managed by private companies, but by a government agencies. Natural disasters ARE different from an individual fire in a resident's home.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance for natural disasters should be handled by government, not private companies - it's fundamentally different from regular home fires and needs a complete system overhaul.

CONTENT: Now is the time for Altadena to get sidewalks.  Let's future proof this community so that people can come back.  And while at it, bury the powerlines.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should use this recovery period to modernize Altadena with sidewalks and underground power lines, making our community more resilient and attractive for returning residents.

CONTENT: It's clear that an inability to quickly shut down power contributed to the severity of the fire, along with exposed power lines. With the areas so devastated, it seems prudent for us to explore buried power lines to expand fire safety.
LLM_SUMMARY: Slow power shutoff procedures and exposed lines worsened the fire's impact. We should consider underground power lines to better protect our community from future disasters.

CONTENT: Insurance assistance in layman terms would be essential. We shouldn't require a lawyer to understand our insurance policies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need insurance policies explained in simple terms without requiring legal help. The language is too complex for regular people to understand their coverage.

CONTENT: Let the market take care of the buildings! The government is inefficient. Reduce red tape, allow more and denser buildings, give more buildings permit. It is supply-demand! It will decrease prices for everyone. If Houston can do it, so can we!
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with government inefficiency and red tape in rebuilding. Advocates for market-driven solutions, reduced regulations, and increased density permits - similar to Houston's approach - to address housing supply issues

CONTENT: On the one hand I'm finding it easy to trust the army core. But on the other the reality of toxic ash covering the area it does leads me to believe that more can be done for testing. Insurance has basically refused it from that I can tell, and it's fallen on individuals to do testing to feel confident.  Still, the broad population with concerns about areas near schools (etc) means there is still a hearts and mind problem the government needs to solve for if they want people aligned with their stance on safety.
LLM_SUMMARY: While I trust the Army Corps, more comprehensive toxic ash testing is needed, especially near schools. Insurance won't cover it, leaving individuals to pay. Government must address public safety concerns.

CONTENT: Insurance companies leaving the state is scary. Especially those able to drop coverage so quickly!
LLM_SUMMARY: Deeply concerned about insurance companies abandoning California and their ability to rapidly terminate coverage, leaving residents vulnerable to wildfire losses.

CONTENT: This right here. What am I investing this time and money in, if the property is then uninsurable?
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated about investing in property that may become uninsurable after wildfires, questioning the financial logic of rebuilding or maintaining homes in high-risk areas.

CONTENT:
Allow to build in an Off the Grid type of solar or wind power supply for a residential 
That way in case of emergency or heavy winds power can be shutdown without affecting a lot of customer.
Edison doesn't allow to be off the grid in the city that my understanding?
Allows us to build of the grid with a hybrid system not to depends so much on the grid.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to install off-grid solar/wind power systems at home for backup during emergencies, but Edison restricts this. A hybrid system would reduce grid dependence during outages.

CONTENT: Edison should be responsible for this. Residents of Altadena should not have to pay.
LLM_SUMMARY: Edison should be held financially responsible for debris removal and cleanup - it shouldn't fall on Altadena residents to cover these costs.

CONTENT: The government did not do their job yet they require all of us to jump through hoops to get back on the land that they let burn. Fire hydrants didn’t work, why do we need fire sprinklers and the extra permit for that when they wouldn’t have save our homes anyway.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that officials failed to maintain basic fire infrastructure like hydrants, yet now burden us with costly sprinkler requirements and permits to rebuild on our own property.

CONTENT: undergrounding power lines is not the answer.  want to see our rates go up by 3x with little benefit?  we need to realize that living in a high fire hazard zone means more power outages during high wind events.  We should be shutting off major power lines during these events.  back-up power should be widespread via dual fuel homes.
LLM_SUMMARY: Accept more frequent power shutoffs during high winds as part of living in fire zones. Focus on backup power and dual fuel homes instead of costly undergrounding projects.

CONTENT:
The power lines in Altadena MUST BE BURIED. The transmission lines that run along the foothills must be rerouted. 

This Eaton Fire distaster cannot be allowed to happen again because a utility failed to de-energize the transmission lines.  That is no longer a tolerable scenario.  

The County, State and Federal Government must support this.
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines along Altadena foothills need to be buried or rerouted to prevent another disaster. Utility companies' failure to de-energize lines is unacceptable.

CONTENT: in general, the state needs to investigate the impact private equity companies have had on emergency vehicles and response. they own fire trucks and make it extremely difficult and expensive for fire departments to get modern trucks and comply with repairs. this was a huge reason the fleet was smaller than it should have been. their monopoly is ILLEGAL. but if the state won't enforce it then the laws mean nothing.
LLM_SUMMARY: Private equity companies' monopoly on fire trucks is hurting our emergency response capabilities by making vehicles too expensive and repairs difficult. The state needs to investigate and take action.

CONTENT: Homes that survived the fires, but with smoke damage, fall into this gray area for $ coverage from insurance. There is no enforcement arm from the Department of Insurance to make carriers do anything. We have little guidance on knowing when it is safe to return to our homes or our neighborhood. Dept. of Health seems to be the only agency addressing this but again, no enforcement pathway from them to the insurance carriers who more or less want us back in our homes as soon as possible.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies provide no clear guidance on smoke damage coverage and when it's safe to return home. There's no agency enforcement to make them help, leaving us in limbo.

CONTENT: This is the perfect opportunity to bury all power lines. The cost of this should be shouldered by the utility companies and not by increasing fees to the consumer.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want utility companies to take responsibility and bury power lines while rebuilding, but don't pass those costs onto customers through higher rates.

CONTENT: Bury ALL power lines. No overheads. Ensure future safety.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to bury all overhead power lines underground to prevent future fire risks and ensure community safety.

CONTENT: Our infrastructure has been rotting for decades. It is absolutely essential that all power lines be grounded, reservoirs need to be doubled in sized and actually have water in them at all times!! Also the DWP needs to be liable for such failure. It is criminal
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that aging infrastructure contributed to fire risk. Demands underground power lines, larger water reservoirs, and DWP accountability for infrastructure failures.

CONTENT: We should buy out homeowners in these areas and turn unsafe zones back into wilderness. If they want to stay, they should have to pay for the true cost.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to either buy out homeowners in high-risk areas to restore wilderness, or make them pay the real costs of living in fire-prone zones.

CONTENT: It's expensive to live in a wildfire prone zone. Either that expense is paid by the people who live there (such as through insurance premiums) or by everyone else who doesn't live there (via taxes). We shouldn't accept unfair increases in insurance premiums, but it's hard to tell what is really fair.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about the high costs of living in fire-prone areas and how these expenses are distributed between residents and taxpayers. Questioning what constitutes fair insurance premium increases.

CONTENT: Must be open and transparent process with competitive bidding.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to ensure economic recovery happens through transparent processes and fair competitive bidding for contracts and support.

CONTENT: Edison must underground power lines
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines need to be moved underground by Edison to prevent future fires.

CONTENT: Kill all lawns. We must change the culture of turf lawns and instead normalize the use of California native plants. They save on water, are already adapted to the environment, provide wildfire resilience, and support local ecology. It is scientific fact that a diverse population thrives - therefore a more biodiverse environment is more resilient to threats. Yes - brush clearance is needed, but education and implementation of native landscapes comes hand-in-hand. In terms of accountability - hold the utility companies accountable. Do not let them get away with their negligence. They must pay.
LLM_SUMMARY: Native plants should replace lawns for fire resilience and water conservation. Utilities must be held accountable for fire prevention, while proper brush management and education remain essential.

CONTENT:
Unfortunately, we are due for another one anytime.  
This is surely part of the reason insurance companies are fleeing the state.
LLM_SUMMARY: Worried about inevitable future fires and their impact on insurance availability in California, as companies abandon coverage due to increasing wildfire risks.

CONTENT: We've got to take care of our neighbors, especially the ones who had their insurance dropped in the months leading up to the fires with no good alternative. But for anyone who could get insurance and decided not to, knowing they were in a fire zone? They should be on the hook for that bad decision, not the rest of us.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance coverage is critical for fire zone residents - we should help those who lost coverage through no fault of their own, but not those who chose to go uninsured.

CONTENT: Privately owned utilities need to be held accountable.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities companies must be held responsible for their role in wildfire prevention and safety.

CONTENT: I see prior comments on all these proposed regulations-  at what cost?
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about the financial burden of new housing regulations and rebuilding requirements being proposed after the fire.

CONTENT: We have to hold power companies accountable
LLM_SUMMARY: Power companies must be held responsible for their role in wildfire prevention and safety.

CONTENT: We must have a more robust infrastructure that includes a publicly funded Watch Duty, up to date water systems, a reliable Emergency Response System, an accountable public utility that takes a People First vs profits first POV (undergrounding power lines)
LLM_SUMMARY: We need stronger public infrastructure - Watch Duty funding, updated water systems, better emergency response, and utilities that prioritize safety over profits by undergrounding power lines.

CONTENT: The free market can and will resolve personal and business financial and employment issues. Government should allow general liberty to work naturally.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government intervention isn't needed - let the free market handle business recovery and employment naturally through individual liberty and choice.

CONTENT: If insurance wants to do any business in the state, they need to provide fire insurance.  However,  if a utility causes the fire, then the utility needs to reimburse the insurance provider.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies operating in California should be required to provide fire coverage, but utilities should reimburse insurers when they're responsible for causing fires.

CONTENT: I'm so sorry you have to deal with that. Truly, my heart is breaking for you. Though I would ask you investigate the actual reason you have lost your coverage. Start by reading about the fact that California does not allow insurers to raise premiums by more than x%. This sounds nice in theory, but in reality what happens is insurance companies are left with no choice but to cancel coverage, as it is not economically realistic for them to continue providing coverage in increasingly high fire-risk areas without raising premiums.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are canceling coverage because California's premium increase caps make it financially impossible to insure high-risk fire areas, rather than simply raising rates to match risk.

CONTENT: They can pay a bigger portion of their profits to fund the rebuilding of homes and maintenance of high-risk areas. Also Southern California Edison has two lawsuits filed against them "alleging faulty power lines may have sparked the Eaton Fire" -NPR
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that Edison should use more profits to fund rebuilding and maintain high-risk areas. Referenced lawsuits claiming their faulty power lines may have caused the Eaton Fire.

CONTENT: I'd like to see public support/subsidies for roofing and building materials that resist fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want government help to make homes more fire-resistant through subsidies for protective building materials and roofing upgrades.

CONTENT: The State must ensure that property owners can obtain home insurance that offers full coverage as compared to the Fair Plan
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies keep abandoning California, leaving us with inadequate Fair Plan coverage. The state needs to step in and ensure we can get proper home insurance.

CONTENT: I'm not sure how much difference fire-resistant design would have made.  If fire-resistant design means infusing building materials with toxic substances that will go up in smoke if the fire is strong enough, then I think that is misguided.  At least in this case, much more effort should have been put into putting the power lines underground.  People have been urging Edison to do this for decades.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines should have been the priority, not toxic fire-resistant materials. Edison ignored community requests for this basic safety measure for years.

CONTENT: California should compete with all forms of insurance in the state with a public option.  What we currently have are companies who effectively subsidize TV and other media with endless advertising yet will do everything in their power to delay and then deny your claims.  If the Federal Govt. is going to be less likely to pay-out (for one reason or another) in what would've previously been considered a disaster, we may have no other choice.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with insurance companies spending on ads while denying claims. Want California to offer public insurance option, especially since federal disaster assistance becoming less reliable.

CONTENT: I was in a fire recovery support group, and hearing the stories of people waiting in lines for vouchers for 8 hours is a joke. Working class people don't have the time for that. Older people shouldn't have to stand in a line for that long. And the people waiting in that line weren't even all guaranteed relief! The whole day passed and people after the 400th person were denied. Also - of the people who received relief vouchers, they then had to go to a Walmart to cash them (which some employees didn't even know how to do). There is one too many steps involved. A relief voucher should be minimal steps. What if people don't have easy access to transportation? And why is the government relying on private corporations? It's just so dystopic.
LLM_SUMMARY: The voucher system for fire relief is broken - long wait times, limited availability, and complex redemption processes at Walmart create unnecessary barriers for working people and seniors seeking assistance.

CONTENT: Deregulate the insurance market, CA politicians caused this problem! Stand up for property owners.  It’s inexcusable that people can stay in rentals for years w/o paying and landlords have limited recourse. Businesses and families are fleeing our state
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with California's regulated insurance market and tenant-friendly laws. Believes political decisions hurt property owners and drive businesses away. Wants more landlord protections and insurance market freedom.

CONTENT:
If all of the homes that will be rebuilt are required to have sprinklers and water systems, then the State of California needs to subsidize the added cost of that for rebuilding survivors of the fires.  

Or, waivers need to be given so that the County of LA can allow its communities to rebuild many of the historic homes that were lost, without adding to the burden of the rebuild.  

This can be addressed in many ways, via grants, tax rebates and tax amnesty programs.
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuilding costs are too high with new fire safety requirements. The state needs to help fire survivors through subsidies, waivers, grants, or tax programs to make rebuilding affordable.

CONTENT: This is a reality of California whether you believe in climate change or not.  Home owners should build back better. But also we need to hold utilities accountable.  In Altadena the brush near the power lines fueled the destruction. How that was allowed to happen is truly baffling.  Homeowners alone should not bear the brunt of being responsible for wildfire preparation.
LLM_SUMMARY: Wildfires are inevitable in California, but responsibility shouldn't fall solely on homeowners. Utilities must be held accountable for poor maintenance, like the overgrown brush near power lines that

CONTENT: Yes on Firebreaks. Yes, fund community fire prevention programs that fire audit every single property and help property owners meet code -not punitively but to help them not loose their homes-. As for holding government accountable, they can start by answering why a for profit monopoly backed by taxpayer insurance is allowed to be the sole provider of a necessary service such as electricity and not have to upgrade their equipment, invest in monitoring tech, hire more employees and still run hi power lines over bone dry, inaccessible wilderness that borders one of the most densely populated mega cities in the country while being seemingly unprepared for well forecasted red flag events.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need funded fire prevention programs and property audits to help homeowners, not punish them. It's unacceptable that utility companies can operate unsafe equipment in high-risk areas without accountability

CONTENT: We have learned, the hard way, that the California insurance industry to irretrievably broken.  Something has to change.  Homeowners insurance is a scam, it is too complicated, no one understands what their policies mean until it is too late, the carriers have inadequate resources to meet a huge crisis like this.  As best I can tell, the carriers are using the money that we paid them in premiums to hire people whose job it is to deny claims.  Some people need to go to jail to wake up this industry.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are running a scam, using premiums to deny claims rather than help. The system is too complex, under-resourced, and broken. Major reform and accountability are needed.

CONTENT: We have given them billions in subsidies and tax breaks. It's time they bury all the lines since we have paid for them to do it but they always get out of actually doing it because it's expensive. You know what's far more expensive? Getting sued by every resident because the root cause was their power lines.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fed up with utilities getting subsidies but avoiding power line burial. They need to be held accountable - the cost of lawsuits from fire damage far exceeds infrastructure upgrades.

CONTENT: We need help with insurance claims. State Farm and other insurance companies are blatantly violating the law by issuing blanket denials of many types of claims. We shouldn't all need to hire attorneys to get the insurance companies to honor our policies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are wrongfully denying wildfire claims en masse, forcing us to hire lawyers just to get our rightful coverage. We need support dealing with these unfair practices.

CONTENT: Let's put civil engineers and public servants in charge of our utilities, not wealthy business executives with MBAs.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fed up with profit-driven utility management. Want qualified engineers and public servants making decisions about our infrastructure instead of corporate executives focused on money.

CONTENT: Update systems, water reclamation, underground power, solar powered street lights, break up the monopoly of the utilities. SCE is irresponsible and has shown a considerable lack of care for its customers and the land.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with SCE's poor service and environmental neglect. Want modernized infrastructure with underground power lines, sustainable utilities, and an end to SCE's monopoly control.

CONTENT: Require insurance companies to issue 100% of personal property coverage for completely destroyed homes and 75% for standing homes within the burn zone without inventory lists.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should automatically pay out full coverage for destroyed homes and 75% for damaged homes in burn zones, without requiring detailed inventory documentation.

CONTENT: Watch Duty should be publicly funded
LLM_SUMMARY: We need public funding for Watch Duty - it's an essential emergency communication tool that everyone relies on during fires.

CONTENT:
Insurance companies should be held responsible for paying the claims on the policies that they willingly sold to residents in the affected areas.  But we also have to acknowledge that they are beholden to their shareholders and will non-renew or exit CA if they can't make a profit.

It could help to require insurance companies to offer incentives for more fire-resistant construction.  Loosening regulations on the insurance industry is something I'm hesitant to support, but if insurance rates are determined by market forces and not a government commission, it could lead to more companies entering the market which would keep prices in check.  Rates will still be higher, but CA rates are lower than many other states with lower disaster risk.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies must honor policies but need profit to stay in California. Market-driven rates and incentives for fire-resistant construction could help maintain coverage availability, despite higher costs.

CONTENT: De-regulate, regarding insurance the insurance commissioner needs to meet with Ins companies, reinsurers, city/state/federal officials to propose a plan where residents are able to obtain proper coverage at a reasonable price and insurers/reinsurers are able to make a reasonable profit.  Insurance companies should be required to offer renewals. Insurance is one of the oldest businesses in existence, it has worked well for 100’s of years.  Adjustment obviously need to be made
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance regulations need reform. The commissioner should work with insurers and government to ensure residents get affordable coverage while companies maintain profits. Companies must offer renewals like they historically have.

CONTENT: I'm happy to chip in my share of taxes towards rebuilding, especially in Altadena where the residents are not nearly as rich as in the Palisades. But the lion's share of the costs need to be paid by the people who want to live in these dangerous fire zones.
LLM_SUMMARY: Willing to contribute tax money for rebuilding, especially in less wealthy Altadena, but believe primary financial responsibility should fall on those choosing to live in high-risk fire areas.

CONTENT: Given the common occurrence of high winds in the area, it is irresponsible that any utility lines are still allowed above ground. Power and other utilities should not have to be shut off to protect people during storm events when they may be the most needed. Companies which have chosen to allow their infrastructure to grow so out of date should not be allowed to pass the high cost of now updating them to customers.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that outdated above-ground utility lines require shutoffs during storms when most needed. Utility companies should bear costs of underground conversion rather than passing expenses to customers.

CONTENT: In the Eaton fire, the cause appears to be from the utility. The press has outlined a number of issues known to be high risk that went unattended for years.  If the Government cannot hold utilities accountable and set higher standards, they will default to decisions that benefit profit over public safety.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that utilities prioritize profits over safety. Government must enforce stricter standards and hold them accountable, as known risks were ignored before the Eaton fire.

CONTENT: Insurance companies must be held accountable for claims. They are in the insurance business. That is a risk reward business. Extreme profit at the expense of people is unacceptable.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are making excessive profits while avoiding their responsibility to pay claims. They need to be held accountable since risk and payouts are part of their business model.

CONTENT: the insurance commissioner needs to step up their game and work with the legislature to change some rules.  If an insurance company offers homeowners insurance in another state but cancels it here in california, all of their other lines of insurance (renters, auto, life, motorcycle) should not be allowed in the state either. insurance commissioner needs to be certain that premiums are fair, insurance language is exceedingly clear leaving no wiggle room, and that collecting on insurance sure be an automatic and smooth process for the consumer.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies canceling California coverage should lose rights to sell all insurance types here. Need stronger oversight for fair rates and clearer policies that pay claims smoothly.

CONTENT: Insurance companies need to make it easier to access ALE while it is unsafe to live in standing homes in the impacted area.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that insurance companies make it too difficult to get temporary living expenses coverage when homes are unsafe but still standing after the fire.

CONTENT:
1. create a public utilities system, delivering traditional and alternative forms.
2. High speed wifi should be a public utility - not a Verizon over here, AT&T over there, Spectrum in this area... all with different cables and methods of delivery and cost.  enough already.
3. move powerlines underground; zero overhead power lines. make it a law
4.invest in robust water collection and reserve methods
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with fragmented utilities, I want underground power lines, unified public internet service, and better water systems. Current infrastructure is inefficient and needs complete overhaul for safety.

CONTENT:
The coper in the powerlines are constantly getting robbed and now thieves have turned to robbing the water hydrants. This is so infuriating and makes the county look deteriorated. Either you start building infrastructure and make it impossible for thieves to rob copper or implement very harsh punishments for those stealing and purchasing stolen copper, wires, or anything pertaining to city infrastructure. 
Also stop taxing us each and every time we need a new road, water dam, etc. Voters have passed plenty of bond measurements for these projects. Start managing the money better!
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by copper theft from power lines and hydrants. Want better infrastructure security and harsher penalties for thieves. Tired of new taxes when bonds already passed for infrastructure projects.

CONTENT:
Insurance company made a lot of $$$$$ now they are leaving, asking for any nonsense or single bs details about any property even a shadow of a roof is a denial for them.
We need more effort from the insurance commissioner
Not just for Homeowners 
Bussines Owners, Worker's Compensation and all those insurance we normally paid e every single day/month.
We need a specific rule for these and everything about the insurance Bussines network..
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with insurance companies abandoning area and denying claims over minor details. Want stronger oversight from insurance commissioner to protect homeowners and businesses through better regulations.

CONTENT: These items are proper local & state government functions and we've already tacitly agreed to fund them through reasonable taxation. Whatever is needed to fund these projects should come from unneeded political pet projects (Unneeded political pet projects is redundant).
LLM_SUMMARY: Restore infrastructure using existing tax funds by redirecting money from unnecessary political projects. Government should fulfill its basic responsibilities with the resources already provided.

CONTENT:
It is especially concerning for people who are of retirement age and/or elderly.

For a company to abandon a customer of so many years like you have been must almost feel like getting caught up in a Ponzi scheme.

We can all understand, the risk/reward profile is not favorable for them and why they want to divest themselves of California policies.

Special consideration should be made for those who have been loyal customers and are past the age where they can start over.
LLM_SUMMARY: Deeply worried about elderly residents being abandoned by insurance companies after years of loyalty. At our age, starting over is extremely difficult - we deserve special consideration as long-term customers.

CONTENT: You have the bury the power lines.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to put power lines underground to prevent future fire risks.

CONTENT: Underground power lines!
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to put power lines underground to prevent fires and make our community more resilient.

CONTENT: Let's bury electrical lines (and internet and other wired infrastructure) underground, to avoid the wires being snapped and sparking in the regular wind storms we have.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to put power lines and other utilities underground to prevent them from causing fires when they break during our frequent wind storms.

CONTENT: My own grandmother lost her home in the Palisades Fire, so this is hard to say. But if people decide to rebuild in the exact spot their house burned down, the financial risk of repeat fire should should be borne by communities who rebuild in high risk areas. Skyrocketing insurance rates should not be distributed throughout the state to areas that have very low risk of wildfire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuilding in high-risk fire areas should come with higher personal insurance costs, not spread across low-risk areas statewide. Despite my grandmother losing her home, responsibility lies with those choosing

CONTENT: Edison should make underground system for Altadena.  It will be costly, but it is necessary.  We cannot make another town like second Altadena.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are essential for Altadena's safety, despite high costs. We can't risk creating another similar community vulnerable to fires.

CONTENT: Have all power lines put underground
LLM_SUMMARY: Want power lines moved underground to prevent future fire risks and outages.

CONTENT: One massive issue we had here in Northern CA is that insurance coverage for temporary housing only kicks in when the evacuation order is mandatory. This means that people with fewer financial resources (including seniors) are forced to wait until the very last minute to leave--putting themselves in great danger and making the situation more difficult and dangerous for first responders, as well. And because lodging coverage stops as soon as evac orders are lifted, people here were forced to return to unsafe situations, with no running water, no power and no internet (at a time when kids were still doing remote learning due to COVID). The state needs to be aware of this issue and work with insurance providers to resolve it.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance only covers temporary housing during mandatory evacuations, forcing low-income residents and seniors to delay leaving until the last minute. This puts lives at risk and rushes people back to unsafe conditions.

CONTENT: All power should be underground AND not at the expense of the rate payer.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are essential for safety, but utility companies should bear the costs rather than passing them on to customers through rate increases.

CONTENT: I think companies should have a green house tax. The more the company produces green house gases, methane or hazardous waste the higher the tax. And cost should not be passed on to consumer..perhaps out of profits before bonuses and salary raises and stock options are allowed
LLM_SUMMARY: Companies should pay higher taxes based on their greenhouse gas emissions and hazardous waste, with costs coming from profits before executive compensation, not passed to consumers.

CONTENT: 6 of the 10 most costly fires in California have been caused by power lines. Its way overdue to put them underground. If Europe can do it, so can we.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that power lines cause major fires in California. Underground power lines, like in Europe, are long overdue and would prevent these disasters.

CONTENT: I would see this as an area where state and federal monies, along with $$$ from the utilities,  can be used to rebuild smartly.  Roads and sidewalks can be rethought to increase the probability of being able to leave in time.  Unsafe, above ground lines can be eliminated.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want government and utility funding used to rebuild infrastructure intelligently - focusing on evacuation-friendly roads and putting power lines underground for better safety.

CONTENT:
I prefer to stay focused on where we go from here, rather than debate why stuff didn't happen in the past. We know what we need to do (e.g, utility under-grounding, firebreaks, fire prevention, fire hardening when (re)building, etc.). It will cost money (private, government). We know we have not had basic* transparency in past on government action (including our IOU monopolies), so let's design that differently from hereon too, perhaps leveraging 311 that we already use. All this can be piloted/tested in LA, but needs to be designed for statewide rollout, adapted for situations elsewhere. 

*basic in sense of: clear, accessible, responsive, and timely to average citizen - not in terms of endless dense reports commissioned by CPUC etc.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to focus on implementing known solutions like utility undergrounding and fire prevention, with better transparency. Let's pilot these in LA and then scale statewide, rather than dwelling on past failures

CONTENT: Insurance and Government agencies and should cover the costs and issue a public apology for their ineptness. It isn't about politics and constituencies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fed up with agencies passing blame - insurance companies and government need to take responsibility, apologize for poor prevention efforts, and cover the costs instead of playing politics.

CONTENT: Helping everyone impacted with a plan and financial assistance will go a long way to supporting mental health
LLM_SUMMARY: Need concrete support like financial aid and recovery planning to help people cope mentally with wildfire impacts - money problems make emotional stress worse.

CONTENT: Aid to help navigate the system and assist when neceassary is welcome
LLM_SUMMARY: Need help understanding and accessing available assistance programs - any guidance through the complex aid system would be appreciated.

CONTENT: The Mayor of LA needs to be held accountable for the poor management of funds and water distribution. California needs to improve relations with federal government for assistance and come up with a joint plan to mitigate future occurrences. Use AI to determine hot spots and forest Management.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need better accountability from LA's mayor on fund management, improved federal cooperation for wildfire planning, and should utilize AI technology for prevention and forest management.

CONTENT: Insurance claims, grants for home rebuilding is essential if we are to be able to rebuild while we continue to pay our mortgage and extremely high rents.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need insurance payouts and rebuilding grants to cover both temporary rent and mortgage payments - impossible to manage both expenses while trying to rebuild our home.

CONTENT: Allowing more flexibility with adding ADUs will support our entire community. Can this be incentivized in some way.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want more flexibility and incentives for building ADUs - it would help our whole community recover and rebuild after the fire.

CONTENT: An online system to report my insurance company for not following their own guidelines and policies for covering our losses that are clearly outlined in our contract.  I have to drive 46 miles from home to work post-fire when I had less than one mile drive pre-fire. My insurance adjuster says my wife and I should ride together when we work different jobs at different start and end time. They also state that we should not be eating out so much since we rented a place with a kitchen...we leave before the sun comes up and return home at dark and dont have time or energy to cook meals at home. This is not being a good neighbor as their tagline says.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with insurance company ignoring policy terms and making unrealistic demands about commuting and meals. They're not honoring their contract or understanding our post-fire hardships with temporary housing far from

CONTENT: It would be extremely helpful for ongoing grants to be available for folks that are rebuilding Altadena. Continuing to pay mortgage and rent is extremely difficult.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need ongoing grants to help with rebuilding while managing both mortgage and rent payments - the financial burden is overwhelming for those of us affected in Altadena.

CONTENT: Others have mentioned the elephant in the room - home owners insurance in CA. This is going to continue to be a massive problem unless a sustainable solution is found. The reality is that most of the people I grew up will not be able to afford to return to the Palisades because they were massively underinsured. This is heartbreaking.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance costs are making it impossible for many to return and rebuild in the Palisades. Without a sustainable solution, underinsured residents can't afford to come back home.

CONTENT: I'm so worried for the local businesses. I don't know how any of them will survive this.
LLM_SUMMARY: Deeply concerned about local businesses' survival prospects in the aftermath of the wildfire devastation.

CONTENT: Aside from grants and loans, consideration might be given to a tax relief program for the wildfire area.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need more than just standard financial aid - a tax relief program for our wildfire-affected area would really help businesses recover and get back on their feet.

CONTENT: Engage all fire victims so they can help create their community. Offer support, listen. Allow them to build a temporary shelter if they want or need to live on their property while rebuilding.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need more community engagement and emotional support for fire victims. Want the option to stay on our property in temporary housing while rebuilding - it helps with healing.

CONTENT: Incentives like grants for prior businesses and tax free status for a period of time
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to see grants and temporary tax exemptions offered to help businesses that were here before rebuild and get back on their feet.

CONTENT: Rebuilding assistance should take into account what we know about fire and other disasters to guide "smart" rebuilding
LLM_SUMMARY: We need rebuilding assistance that incorporates lessons learned from past fires and disasters to ensure smarter, more resilient reconstruction approaches.

CONTENT: Can't we make it easy for folks to get their questions answered, know of a place to go for information, get help?
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by lack of centralized information during emergency - we need a clear, accessible source where people can get answers and assistance.

CONTENT: The Army Corps of Engineers is doing a great job.  After the ACE has done it's job, there should be an additional step of testing for soil and water quality.  If the city can't pay for it, then it should be covered under the California Fair Plan "Ordinance of Law" line item.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want soil and water quality testing after Army Corps finishes debris removal. If city can't fund it, it should be covered under California Fair Plan's Ordinance of Law provision.

CONTENT: Accessible grants for homeowners too. **There’s an underserved middle between those who qualify for aid and those who don’t need it.** Please help us with grants to rebuild. I’m begging you. I can’t give up the plot where my long gone grandparents held me and I took my first steps.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by falling between aid qualification thresholds. Desperately need grants to rebuild on family property with deep emotional significance - can't afford it alone.

CONTENT: We need transparency for how government and private sector funds are being spent on the recovery
LLM_SUMMARY: Demanding clarity on how both government and private recovery funds are being allocated and spent in our community's rebuilding efforts.

CONTENT: Please simplify all of this. I never wanted to figure out how to build a home. This needs to be overhauled for all the people you failed. Waive all the fees. Why are we paying you more? What does it go towards? Fire protection lol?? (Sorry to be spicy, but dude.)
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by complex rebuilding process and fees. Don't understand why we must pay more to the same system that failed to protect us from fire damage.

CONTENT: The government has not done enough with the billions of dollars collected for “homeless” housing along with the billions collected for mental illness. Don’t want the same to happen in this area too.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned that government mismanages housing funds for homeless and mental health services. Worried similar ineffective spending will occur with wildfire recovery resources.

CONTENT: Yes to deprioritising anyone with a second home. Prioritise the most severely in need and avoid patronising behaviours please - there but for the grace of god goes any one of us! Long term housing solutions must be addressed systemically.
LLM_SUMMARY: Housing aid should prioritize those most in need, not second homeowners. Treat us with respect - anyone could end up in this situation. We need systematic solutions for long-term housing.

CONTENT: stop blanket support and giving to those who already have more than they need and prioritise aid to those who are really struggling, without patronising and making them feel like second class citizens.
LLM_SUMMARY: Aid should be targeted to those truly in need, not given broadly to wealthy residents. Support must be provided respectfully, treating struggling recipients with dignity.

CONTENT: I agree with the idea that there is corporate gouging and unfairness going on, because we all know this is happening, it's just the state doesn't want to put money into audits to catch and stop it from happening.  But I don't think the government elects (Mayor and Supervisors) need to manage something like this.  It would be like allowing the fox to watch over the hen house.  They already don't do a good job at their jobs, which is why we are in the state we are in.  So why give them more authority to come up with more projects, to give away more of our taxpayers money that will go more to waste?   I agree with the prior statement, let charities take this on if they feel the need to.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government shouldn't manage price gouging prevention - they already mismanage taxpayer money. Let charities handle economic support instead of giving officials more control over recovery funds.

CONTENT: People need places to live, but I don't think it should be in high-risk fire zones if we can help it. Pay the people who lost their homes, but rebuild high-density housing in urban areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should compensate fire victims but discourage rebuilding in fire-prone areas. Instead, focus on developing high-density housing in safer urban locations.

CONTENT: Underinsured homeowners can't afford the new code requirements.  Grants and tax relief should be provided to ease that burden.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building code upgrades are too expensive for underinsured homeowners like us. We need financial help through grants and tax breaks to afford these mandatory improvements.

CONTENT: Rather than temporary housing, a priority should be placed in Accessory Dwelling Units (ADUs), home rebuilding, long-term housing solutions
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to focus on permanent housing solutions like ADUs and home rebuilding instead of temporary fixes - that should be our main priority.

CONTENT: We are not able to proceed with retaining a contractor and rebuild when our insurance company is holding out paying what they owe us, which are the limits we paid for.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that insurance company won't pay policy limits we're entitled to, preventing us from hiring contractors and starting rebuild process.

CONTENT: Subsidize local, small businesses
LLM_SUMMARY: Want financial support specifically targeted to help small, local businesses recover and stay afloat after the fire's impact.

CONTENT: The Mayor and Supervisors need to pass new laws and regulations to reduce the price of emergency housing.  Charging retail rates is corrupt, feathering the nest of our worst segment, the rentiers.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that emergency housing costs are too high after the fire. Want local leaders to regulate prices and stop landlords from profiting off disaster victims.

CONTENT: When the fires broke out it was made very clear they were going to be very strict on rent gouging but I have not seen any accountability on this. I have also never seen accountability on this across the board. Rent has been unattainable for so many for so long. There are also many people who face wage garnishments for terrible situations when they try to work with a leasing office and do the right thing and get out of a lease when something tragic happens like a loss/helping out a family member etc and the leasing office/property won’t work with them at all and then you have 1,000’s of California residents who are garnished up to 25% of their weekly pay! California need to stop allowing any garnishments by greedy companies + price gouging
LLM_SUMMARY: Despite promises to prevent rent gouging after the fire, there's been no accountability. Rent remains unaffordable, and property companies unfairly garnish wages when residents face hardships an

CONTENT: The economy already favors the wealthy and successful, so these emergencies require special protections and provisions for underserved small businesses that need extra help to recover.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses need targeted support and special protections during wildfire recovery, since the economic system already advantages larger, wealthier businesses over underserved ones.

CONTENT: County needs to expedite all permits for building houses.  We absolutely can't afford to rent and pay mortgage for as long as this is going to take so don't want permits delayed for months costing us tens of thousands of dollars we don't have to waste.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by dual housing costs while waiting to rebuild. Need county to speed up permit process - delays are financially devastating when paying both rent and mortgage simultaneously.

CONTENT: We live in California, home of the tech bros. Why can we have a functioning app that anyone and everyone can tap into for resources?
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that despite California's tech industry leadership, there's no comprehensive emergency app available to connect residents with wildfire resources and information.

CONTENT: Two friends of mine lost EVERYTHING, and I have thought of them every single day since the fire. People need to process this and they need all the help they can get.
LLM_SUMMARY: Deeply concerned about friends who lost everything in the fire. People desperately need mental health support to process this devastating trauma and loss.

CONTENT: Rebuilding to specific “like-for-like “ criteria that the Assessor will agree with and that passes Building & Safety and other code checks will cut the time to rebuild way down by clarifying the path to a design and ultimately a rebuild that will serve homeowners affected. I want a chance to rebuild. I need help getting that information straightened out and available NOW!
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by complex rebuilding requirements. Need clear "like-for-like" criteria from Assessor and Building & Safety to speed up reconstruction process. Want to rebuild but need guidance immediately.

CONTENT: I should not have to shoulder Palisades folks rebuilding in such a high risk area.
LLM_SUMMARY: Don't believe taxpayers should subsidize rebuilding homes in high-risk fire zones in Pacific Palisades.

CONTENT: Did I say “Task Force”?  We have a task force organization already. Developing Version 1.0, then Version 2.0…(keep going…) should be done in that framework. Oh, yes, and FUND it and put someone in charge of this “ongoing project” that will get results.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that existing task force structure isn't being utilized effectively. We need proper funding and leadership to develop and improve emergency communication systems that actually deliver results.

CONTENT: We need information and resources. We don't need a weekly webinar every day of the week from every politician and agency so they can look like they are doing something - get yourselves organized, coordinated, and united.  We need accountability. We need affordable insurance so that we aren't priced out or underinsured. We need USACE debris removal for all impacted properties. We need functioning fire hydrants. We need reservoirs filled with water. We need better emergency services and alerts. We need better roads and infrastructure. We need wires moved underground. We need the public resources we pay for with our taxes to support us and not be squandered on pet projects and the unhoused.
LLM_SUMMARY: Stop wasting time with endless meetings. We need coordinated action on insurance, infrastructure, emergency services, and proper use of public resources to actually support affected residents.

CONTENT: California's insurance system requires a complete overhaul—it is currently more complicated than the tax code. This issue must be addressed in clear, straightforward terms before any funds are allocated. Otherwise, the same problems will arise during the next disaster.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance system is too complex and needs major reform before allocating disaster funds. Current complications will just create the same problems during future wildfires.

CONTENT: Streamline communication on financial assistance available for those impacted by fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need clearer information about what financial help is available to fire victims - the process is confusing and communication needs to be more straightforward.

CONTENT: Rebuilding is impacted by labor shortage and material cost. Is the state doing anything to help keep costs low despite the federal mandate of deporting laborers and enforcing tariffs on building materials?
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about high rebuilding costs due to labor shortages from deportations and material tariffs. Seeking information on state assistance to offset these increased expenses.

CONTENT: There needs to be incentive for lawyers in the area to work pro bono for families regarding tenant issues. There's no reason that owning a rental should leave you in the dark.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that lawyers won't help tenants pro-bono with rental issues after the fire. Property owners shouldn't be left without legal support during this crisis.

CONTENT: Also, it is a travesty that people who are displaced are who knows where. For example, how could Pasadena ship out its residents whose homes burned down to other cities? Could the City not have found temporary shelter within the City? It was callous to say that they convention center is a business and boot out people.
LLM_SUMMARY: Outraged that displaced residents were sent to other cities instead of being housed locally in Pasadena. The convention center prioritizing business over sheltering fire victims was insensitive and wrong.

CONTENT: I am worried that I will be forced to leave my beloved Altadena community - how can I afford to live here in the future with additional SBA loan debt to rebuild, uncertain future insurability and affordability, rising property taxes to accommodate the rebuild, and the threat of another wildfire or earthquake disaster that we are woefully unprepared for?  If we, as a two income household with no kids, with engineering degrees and careers, are struggling - What about the rest of the community?
LLM_SUMMARY: Deeply concerned about affording to stay in Altadena due to rebuild costs, loan debt, insurance issues, and rising taxes. If we're struggling as professionals, how can others manage?

CONTENT: Reached out to the Red Cross. They said I was not eligible for counseling!!!! I have been staying in a hotel for three months!
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by Red Cross denying mental health counseling services while displaced in hotel for months after the fire. Feel abandoned when seeking emotional support.

CONTENT: All important to a functioning community. As usual, the question begs - who pays for this?  Should the folks in Etna, CA be taxed for the folly of building so many high-dollar homes in an obvious fire zone? Should Modesto be on the hook for wealthy home owners in Marin or Sonoma or LA?
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about fairness in funding infrastructure repairs after fires. Questions why taxpayers across California should subsidize rebuilding in wealthy, high-risk fire zones.

CONTENT: It is important that government provide assistance to protect individual people from illegal or unfair actions taken against them by insurance companies and/or landlords. Government should simplify the regulatory process of rebuilding but should not be using tax-payer money to issue grants for home building or for bringing existing buildings into compliance with new code requirements. Government should not be using tax-payer money to provide legal aid to undocumented residents; this should be a service provided by the private sector.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should protect us from unfair insurance companies and landlords, but shouldn't use taxpayer money for rebuilding grants, code compliance, or legal aid for undocumented residents.

CONTENT: Rental rates are insane. I still can’t find a place to live while I rebuild my house. Please consider subsidies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by excessive rental costs while trying to rebuild my home. Need financial assistance through housing subsidies during this challenging transition period.

CONTENT: Army Corp and LA County systems need to be in sync. There have been many ROE's lost in the system, leaving us calling daily for status without answers. Also, lets be clear on who will be paying for debris removal, insurance or "free" as what many people are being told.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by lost Right of Entry forms and confusion between agencies. Need better coordination between Army Corps and County, plus clarity on whether insurance or government covers debris removal costs.

CONTENT: Temporary long term housing allows people to focus on the next step the in recovery process. Month to month housing for total loss is not helpful.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need stable long-term temporary housing to properly focus on recovery. Short-term monthly rentals don't provide enough security to plan ahead effectively.

CONTENT: Allow small business owners to rebuild and restore before greedy companies take their space
LLM_SUMMARY: Protect small business owners' ability to rebuild after the fire instead of letting large corporations take over their locations during recovery.

CONTENT: The American Red Cross worked faster than any other entity to ensure we had money days after the fire took our home. I believe in nonprofit support, especially where government bureaucracy can sometimes slow relief.
LLM_SUMMARY: Grateful for Red Cross's swift financial assistance after losing home to fire. Nonprofits provided faster relief than government agencies, highlighting their crucial role in disaster response.

CONTENT: Support for not just homeowners and landlords in the 'burn scar' but in the entire community where long and short term renters leave..
LLM_SUMMARY: Need support for the whole community affected by resident displacement, not just property owners in burned areas - it impacts both long-term and short-term rental markets.

CONTENT:
We already had a shortage of construction labor b4 the disaster

There is an opportunity here to create 1,000s of jobs & numerous small biz's
                               
LA Economic & Workforce Dept needs to implement a strategic workforce development initiative, including the formation of small biz    

Work skill/biz courses could be offered tuition free at LAUSD's 13 adult education/trade schools

Fed/State/NGO small biz assistance, funding/grants can be combined to fund the outfitting of the small companies which will drive the recovery

We don't need master carpenters, but workers who can assemble prefab, install ADUs, living pods, appliances etc. & connect them 2 utilities

Let residents drive the recovery, not big const firms..
LLM_SUMMARY: Need to create local jobs and small businesses through workforce training programs and funding, focusing on basic construction skills to help residents lead recovery instead of big firms.

CONTENT: Give small businesses interest-free loans to rebuild. Maybe lessen their state and local tax burden for the next 2-3 years.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want interest-free loans for small businesses to rebuild, plus temporary tax relief at state and local levels to help recovery over next few years.

CONTENT: Every business near fire areas are struggling. Not only have many residents had to leave, but the ones remaining are financially stressed.
LLM_SUMMARY: Local businesses are suffering due to displaced residents and financial strain on those who stayed, creating a ripple effect throughout our community's economy.

CONTENT: My ALE is limited. I need a somewhere to go once it is out.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about limited Additional Living Expenses coverage and urgently needs temporary housing once insurance funds are depleted.

CONTENT: I fear the small businesses still standing will be forced to close due to families being displaced. We are already seeing it with places like Mathnasium and CodeNinjas in Altadena.  Given the decimation of the schools and aftercare programs, and provided the air is deemed safe, a program to shuttle kids to such places could help them stay solvent.
LLM_SUMMARY: Worried local businesses will fail as families leave the area. Educational centers like Mathnasium are struggling. Suggest shuttle service to help these businesses survive while schools recover.

CONTENT: The protections for renters and regulations makes it unconvenient to rent them. The "protections" needs to be lifted, so more people will be able to access housing. It is better to have less protections and be housed than be homeless!
LLM_SUMMARY: Tenant protections and regulations discourage property owners from renting. We need fewer restrictions so more housing becomes available - having limited protections is better than being homeless.

CONTENT:
Disaster relief insurance training to educate victims on how to advocate for the
Selves!!
LLM_SUMMARY: Need training on how to navigate disaster insurance claims and advocate for ourselves as wildfire victims - we're lost in the process.

CONTENT:
One area where resources should be consolidated is the tax incentives, grants and rebates available from federal, State & local government entities for sustainability measures in rebuilding.  

This is an important part of a multi-layered cost reduction strategy that will make sustainable rebuilding accessible to all property owners.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need better coordination of government tax incentives and rebates for sustainable rebuilding. Having multiple programs at different levels makes it harder for property owners to access support.

CONTENT:
Funding for communities to engage organizers and facilitators to act as paid (not volunteer, as is the Topanga Town Council, Chamber of Commerce, Emergency Preparedness (TCEP), elderly support (SAGES) - to bring community leaders together, to interface with govt agencies.

There should be a team specifically dedicated to coordination and communications as soon as a fire or other crisis strikes.

We need a unified 'easy to use' communications system for communities in crisis, including a clear and well organized hierarchy for distributing communications & a neighborhood/zone system that people are already enrolled in prefire. Cellular systems or mesh net wifi should be available for text only communications throughout the city and county.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need paid coordinators and a unified emergency communications system with clear hierarchy, pre-established zones, and backup text capabilities - not just relying on volunteer organizations during crises.

CONTENT: Provide aid to all infected. Homeowners and renters, total loss and uninhabitables. You pay into insurance to be covered for emergencies and if there are no emergencies, there's no reason for rates to increase. Even where there is an emergency, rates shouldn't increase. The system needs to be overhauled, along with FEMA. The lack of financial support has caused so many to be homeless.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance and FEMA systems are failing us - rates keep rising despite paying premiums, and insufficient aid is leaving fire victims homeless. We need better support for both homeowners and renters.

CONTENT: I think it is critically important to address price gouging of displaced victims. At some point, the rental free market needs some guardrails to ensure all are housed equitably.
LLM_SUMMARY: Rental price gouging of fire victims must be stopped. We need market regulations to ensure displaced people can find affordable housing and aren't taken advantage of.

CONTENT: The city has been over relying on temporary housing and interim housing solutions that are run by non-profits and private businesses. These greedy middle-men are exploiting city programs for their own benefit. The city needs to build public, affordable housing with the EXPRESS intention of reducing property values and rent. Ignore landlord, land developer, and private equity interests that are making it impossible for working class people to survive in this city.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fed up with temporary housing run by profit-seeking middlemen. City needs to directly build affordable public housing, even if it reduces property values, instead of catering to landlords and developers.

CONTENT: Insurance is difficult to navigate and because it is a business, companies are doing everything they can to not pay out on claims. People who lost homes and were underinsured need assistance to close those financial gaps beyond additional loans. People need cash in hand to help with rebuilding. We saw the government response to supporting businesses during COVID with PLP loans that were forgiven. The people of Altadena need a similar benefit.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with insurance companies avoiding payouts. We need direct government financial assistance for rebuilding, similar to COVID business relief, not just loans. Insurance gaps are leaving homeowners struggling.

CONTENT: Accountability has proven almost impossible. There are countless state audits that demonstrate that. Additionally, there are multiple levels of accountability. Ad of today there appears to be no one who will take responsibility.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that no one takes responsibility for wildfire prevention despite multiple state audits. The system has many layers but lacks clear accountability or ownership of the problem.

CONTENT: Home rebuilding with a coordinated sourcing strategy for supplies to give us buyers more power against price gouging.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want coordinated bulk purchasing of rebuilding materials to prevent price gouging and give homeowners more leverage when sourcing construction supplies.

CONTENT: More funding more grants more education on how to get these resources and agency support services!!
LLM_SUMMARY: Desperately need increased funding, grants, and better guidance on accessing recovery resources and support services for businesses affected by the fire.

CONTENT: It's expensive to live in a wildfire prone zone. Either that expense is paid by the people who live there (such as through insurance premiums) or by everyone else who doesn't live there (via taxes). We shouldn't accept unfair increases in insurance premiums, but it's hard to tell what is really fair.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance costs in fire-prone areas are a major burden, and while residents should bear some responsibility, determining fair premium increases versus unfair price hikes is challenging.

CONTENT: Make sure that seniors and people with disabilities are not left behind. Registries alone are not going to help much, offer dedicated funding
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about vulnerable populations during evacuations. Want more than just registries - need dedicated funding to ensure seniors and disabled residents aren't forgotten in emergencies.
