CONTENT: One immediate need is definitely financial support/grants/tax credits for home building and to address new code requirements. Instead of trying to waive the new code requirements to rebuild faster, let's give the community the chance to build back better
LLM_SUMMARY: Need financial support through grants and tax credits to meet new building codes, rather than waiving requirements. This would help us rebuild safer, stronger homes in our community.

CONTENT: Let's make sure that everyone has awesome, effective infrastructure. I don't want my friends in Altadena to get stiffed in favor of a better recovery for the wealthier community in the Palisades, and I don't want one part of Altadena to get better support than another. Equity sounds like a fine term for what I'm asking for.
LLM_SUMMARY: Demanding equal infrastructure recovery across all fire-affected areas, regardless of community wealth. Don't want to see preferential treatment between Palisades and Altadena, or within Alt

CONTENT: I have been in a hotel for three months. The Landlord is harassing me and I am now trying to find a new apartment without any assistance. The Landlord has violated city laws and the city of Pasadena has not been helpful at all.
LLM_SUMMARY: Facing housing instability after fire - stuck in hotel, dealing with landlord harassment, and struggling to find new housing without support. City officials haven't helped resolve these issues.

CONTENT: Needs to be expedited, Phase 2 is only 3% done.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by extremely slow progress of Phase 2 debris removal efforts, with only 3% completion so far. Process needs to move much faster.

CONTENT: As everyone knows, the red tape is insane, permitting costs are insane, construction costs, architects -- if anyone is able to rebuild in Altadena it will be a miracle.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by overwhelming costs and bureaucracy involved in rebuilding - from permits to construction to architects. Doubts whether anyone will realistically be able to rebuild their home in Altadena.

CONTENT: No one should be profiting from this - this is a disaster, not a business opportunity. While this also isn’t time for NIMBYism, I hope that relief can go to the community, and not to any speculators hoping to profit off of Angelenos.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned that disaster relief should directly benefit affected community members rather than being exploited by outside speculators and businesses looking to profit from the situation.

CONTENT:
Local businesses in Altadena that survived the fire have been destroyed by loss of the community.  We need to help these businesses stay open and keep people employed.  This is a critical part of our community. 
 Once everything closes, there will be nothing here except big box stores.
LLM_SUMMARY: Worried our local Altadena businesses won't survive, even after escaping the fire. Without support to keep them open and people employed, we'll lose our community character to big chains.

CONTENT: many are under insured if insured at all, must rebuild rapidly for people to afford to move back
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance coverage is inadequate or nonexistent for many residents. Quick rebuilding is essential so people can afford to return to their homes.

CONTENT: Close the gap on CFPs underinsurance so that people can rebuild back.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to address the underinsurance problem with California Fair Plans so homeowners can actually afford to rebuild after fires.

CONTENT:
Reduce onerous building regulations. California citizens affected homeowners should be given preference 
.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want less restrictive building regulations and priority treatment for California residents affected by fires when rebuilding their homes.

CONTENT: I'd like to see public support/subsidies for roofing and building materials that resist fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want government help to make homes more fire-resistant through subsidies for protective building materials and roofing upgrades.

CONTENT: The State must ensure that property owners can obtain home insurance that offers full coverage as compared to the Fair Plan
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies need to provide comprehensive coverage instead of relying on the limited Fair Plan - the state needs to make this happen.

CONTENT: Excellent items funded by previously appropriate taxation.
LLM_SUMMARY: Satisfied that tax money was well-spent on emergency preparedness resources.

CONTENT: About 225,000 units, or 6.1%, of Los Angeles County's total housing stock, were vacant per a 2023 Census survey. Whole apartment buildings are used as illegal Airbnbs, or held vacant for tax purposes. A serious civic push to free up these unavailable units would have a profound impact not just in providing options for fire refugees, but for all rent burdened Angelenos.
LLM_SUMMARY: Vacant housing and illegal short-term rentals are wasting potential homes. Converting these units could help both wildfire victims and struggling renters find affordable housing in LA County.

CONTENT: Businesses need help, we need our businesses! Financing should be available to them at a very low interest rate. We love our small business owners and they need support.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses desperately need financial support through low-interest loans to recover. They're vital to our community and we must help them survive this crisis.

CONTENT: Partner with WatchDuty and maybe fund them, they’re a good non-profit that can provide essential support to the state.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should partner with and fund WatchDuty - they're a non-profit that could provide valuable emergency support services to California.

CONTENT: We can't rebuild alone. We need help from EVERYONE -- the state and county government, from public donors, from community groups, and most of all each other. There are resources available but information about and access to services is all over the place. We desperately need a functioning hub with vetted information that will put us in contact with each other and provide information on how to access additional funding and support. And that hub MUST be virtual -- many of us had to move far away to find affordable housing and can't attend in person events.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need a centralized virtual hub for coordinating recovery resources and connecting displaced residents - current information is scattered and hard to access, especially since many of us relocated.

CONTENT: We need better equitable contracting practices to ensure that the tax payer funds use for services actually have outcomes that benefit our community.
LLM_SUMMARY: Local tax dollars for recovery services should be contracted more fairly to ensure they actually help our community and deliver meaningful results.

CONTENT: I was in a fire recovery support group, and hearing the stories of people waiting in lines for vouchers for 8 hours is a joke. Working class people don't have the time for that. Older people shouldn't have to stand in a line for that long. And the people waiting in that line weren't even all guaranteed relief! The whole day passed and people after the 400th person were denied. Also - of the people who received relief vouchers, they then had to go to a Walmart to cash them (which some employees didn't even know how to do). There is one too many steps involved. A relief voucher should be minimal steps. What if people don't have easy access to transportation? And why is the government relying on private corporations? It's just so dystopic.
LLM_SUMMARY: The voucher system for fire relief is broken - long wait times, limited availability, and complex redemption processes at Walmart create unnecessary barriers for working people and seniors seeking assistance.

CONTENT: Many people's insurances pulled out and now they are left with nothing. Steps need to be taken to ensure that people can get the money they deserve to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies abandoning us left many with nothing. We need measures to guarantee people receive proper compensation to rebuild after these devastating fires.

CONTENT: Streamlining support for small businesses to revitalize neighborhoods, please! Let the fruit carts and taco trucks thrive!
LLM_SUMMARY: Want faster, simpler support to help small businesses and street vendors bounce back in our fire-affected neighborhoods. Less red tape would help our local economy recover.

CONTENT: Need to suspend coastal commission and CEQA  for all fire victims not just these recent fires. The Franklin, Mountain and Woolsey fires and more.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want coastal commission and CEQA regulations suspended for all fire victims, not just recent ones - should include Franklin, Mountain, Woolsey fires and others.

CONTENT: This hasn't been a large problem for my wife and myself. But we have met many other survivors that do need some assistance in this area. Offering online assistance might be a great solution for those that have access to online assistance. Perhaps some group sessions of those suffering similar afflictions might be beneficial too. Offering cultural appropriate group sessions with multilingual would be a good idea too.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need more mental health support for fire survivors, especially online options and culturally appropriate group sessions. While I'm okay, I've met others who really need this help.

CONTENT:
When a person calls their insurance company after a fire - you'd expect they'd receive an A-Z step by step "Here's how to file and complete your claim." Instead, they get "You're in a dark room, find the light switch"

The insurance piece of this is very complicated. But the claims part need not be. This is something where the Dept can make quick and substantive changes overnight. Force guidelines for claims to be clear and easy to follow.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance claims after fires are needlessly complicated and confusing. The Department should require insurance companies to provide clear, step-by-step guidelines for filing claims.

CONTENT: Grants should go to small businesses and individuals who have been established in the community.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses and established community members should be prioritized for grant funding and financial assistance.

CONTENT: local business is critical but often a forgotten stakeholders in all of this.  they need to be prioritized.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses are vital stakeholders in wildfire recovery but get overlooked. They deserve more priority and support in the response efforts.

CONTENT: Force Insurance Companies to cover toxin testing inside smoke damaged homes. If the health department says we should be concerned about this why does insurance refuse to cover it? How can we feel safe moving back in our homes. The testing is very expensive…$5-$10 thousand depending on tests necessary. We paid close to $7000.00 out of pocket and are awaiting results. Many do not have the resources to pay for this themselves.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should be required to cover indoor toxin testing after smoke damage. The high cost ($5-10K) prevents many from confirming their homes are safe to reoccupy.

CONTENT: Our fire fighters need better benefits to secure their families futures. It does no good to fund these programs and under pay the people to do this highly dangerous job
LLM_SUMMARY: We must properly compensate firefighters for their dangerous work, not just fund prevention programs. They deserve better benefits to support their families.

CONTENT: Supporting local businesses should   be a very high priority. With restricted traffic and homeowners evacuation it will be extremely difficult for local businesses to continue to operate profitably. I worked from my home and lost everything in the fire. IT has proven very difficult trying to operate my business without my tools of office files. Grants have helped but it hasn't been enough.  I see millions of dollars being raised for fire relief but it hasn't really helped us so far.
LLM_SUMMARY: Lost my home-based business and essential work tools in the fire. Despite grants and relief funds being raised, support hasn't been adequate to help small businesses recover and operate effectively.

CONTENT: Eliminate new code requirements, residents are dealing with enough and they don't have unlimited funds for new code upgrades. Let residents build at a minimum to what they had before without all the bureaucracy. The city and county already provide massive amounts of 'legal aid' for tenants and illegals there is no need to reinvent the wheel.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by costly new building codes and bureaucracy. Want to rebuild to previous standards without additional requirements. Existing legal aid programs are sufficient - no need for more.

CONTENT: Require insurance companies to issue 100% of personal property coverage for completely destroyed homes and 75% for standing homes within the burn zone without inventory lists.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should automatically pay out full coverage for destroyed homes and 75% for damaged homes in burn zones, without requiring detailed inventory documentation.

CONTENT: Direct financial assistance to residents. Many are uninsured or those who are will have a GAP in order to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need direct financial help for residents - many of us have no insurance or insufficient coverage to fully rebuild after the fire damage.

CONTENT:
The mail. I know that's a federal issue but for heavens sake the mail was a mess. 

Let state/county/city items be forwarded. 

I have been fighting with mail for months now. i tried putting a hold on it, but that didn't work. Then i tried forwarding to an accessible mail place, but most government mail isn't allowed to be forwarded so I would apply for help and kept getting notified that I had address issues and would be disqualified from programs etc. I would tell them "I'm evacuated/displaced and getting mail forwarded" but it caused a massive issue. It still is causing delays, cancellations, and confusion.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with mail forwarding restrictions during evacuation - especially for government correspondence. This caused major problems with assistance programs since official mail couldn't be forwarded to temporary address.

CONTENT: If I rebuild, I want a guarantee I can acquire the necessary fire insurance to cover my loss.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need assurance that I can get fire insurance coverage before committing to rebuilding my home after the wildfire damage.

CONTENT:
For victims that are still experiencing homelessness we need to rent out a old hotel or a designated hotel for those who have been impacted and unable to afford housing at the current moment !! This will
Help them get on their feet to save money for mortgages and future rebuilding expenses!!
LLM_SUMMARY: We need temporary housing like hotels for fire victims who are homeless. This would help us save money for rebuilding and future housing costs while getting back on our feet.

CONTENT: Permitting costs should be waved. We aren’t building an addition, we are rebuilding our lives after a huge tragedy. Give us a break.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that rebuilding permits cost money after losing everything. Want fees waived since we're just trying to recover from disaster, not doing optional renovations.

CONTENT: Renters and homeowners may need real financial assistance, even if they are uninsured or underinsured.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need actual financial help for both renters and homeowners affected by the fire, regardless of their insurance status - many of us don't have adequate coverage.

CONTENT: Local business assistance should be spared for those who really need it. We don't need a situation like the PPP loans where the well off ran away with a huge chunk of the pie meant for others.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned that business recovery aid should target truly needy small businesses, not get diverted to wealthy recipients like what happened with PPP loans during COVID.

CONTENT: Rather than tax, tax, tax to create subsidies, let's make it easier for businesses to operate. Cut the red tape. Incentivize them to stay in Los Angeles.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want less taxation and bureaucracy, more incentives to keep businesses in LA. Simplifying operations would help more than subsidy programs funded by higher taxes.

CONTENT: Grants are essential, but they need to be more accessible to individual people. We’re seeing a lot of money go to “organizations”, but the people need it directly. We don’t need funded services that are difficult to access, we need cash in hand to meet our needs.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that recovery funds go to organizations rather than directly to affected individuals. Want easier access to cash grants so we can address our immediate needs ourselves.

CONTENT:
When it comes to managing dollars, people want to see the overall dollars being distributed via programs. 

If there's 10,000 homes and businesses burnt, and we have $6B collectively raised for every single program from mental health to temporary housing, to environmental cleanups...

That's nearly $600,000 per structure on top of their insurance payments. If that's the case, just give them the bulk of the money and let the communities self organize and solve their repair. Pool a portion of the money into local government accounts for things like rebuilding schools and repairing sidewalks. 

If the number is much much less, like $1B, mostly not cash, and not all available today, then fine build it all out slowly with programs.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should know the total aid money available. If it's substantial, give it directly to affected property owners to manage recovery themselves, with some pooled for public infrastructure repairs.

CONTENT:
Reduce permit fees 
Assist in the rebuild reduce cost of supplies to help
LLM_SUMMARY: Need financial relief through lower permit fees and rebuilding costs - the community needs help making reconstruction more affordable.

CONTENT: Everyone who lost their homes in the fires deserves assistance regardless of legal status.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to provide financial help to all fire victims, documented or not - losing your home to a wildfire doesn't discriminate based on immigration status.

CONTENT: Since Trump has blamed California for not engaging in forest management, could we request funding for clearing dead brush AND downed trees that are still not cleaned up from that big wind event. Generate jobs that way.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want funding to clear dead brush and fallen trees from wind damage - could create jobs while addressing forest management needs Trump criticized California for neglecting.

CONTENT: The burn map cannot be used to determine eligibility. There are thousands of residents displaced due to smoke/soot/ash damage that are within the 250 yard health advisory boundary of the burn and they aren’t eligible for assistance because they aren’t in the burn area even though they are just as displaced and have lost all their interior contents. We’re being hung out to dry.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that assistance eligibility is limited to burn area only, ignoring nearby residents suffering smoke and ash damage who are equally displaced and have lost belongings.

CONTENT:
Things to be addressed first in recovery:
1- Priority #1: Make sure all toxic debris has been cleared out (including charred structures, cars, and flora/trees). There should also be thorough environment analysis of the topsoil in: PP, Malibu, and Altadena- to make sure there are no toxins hiding in the ground that could lead to increased cancer rates in the future.
2-Secondary priority: Make sure that current occupants/tenants/homeowners DO NOT LOSE THEIR HOMES. Mandatory moratorium on mortgage payments and rent for the rest of 2025. People should not be made to pay for property that is burned out. 
3-Teritary priority: Generous assistance for home insurance policyholders as they attempt to rebuild (maybe ~$50k per household?)
LLM_SUMMARY: Need thorough toxic debris cleanup and soil testing first, then protect residents from losing homes through payment freezes, and finally provide substantial insurance assistance for rebuilding efforts.

CONTENT: Government should step in above greedy developers to help survivors. There is no better time than now to start community land trusts while also building community public housing that serves everyone.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want government intervention to prioritize community needs over developer profits through land trusts and public housing that helps all wildfire survivors rebuild, not just wealthy homeowners.

CONTENT: Agree. Our lender said any kind of forbearance or deferment would result in a re-negotiation of the entire loan. This is not helpful.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that lender wouldn't allow temporary payment relief without completely restructuring the loan, making it an unhelpful option during wildfire recovery.

CONTENT: The underinsured and uninsured need a lot more help. Also we need grants for rebuilding smaller commercial property and to help small businesses.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need more support for those without adequate insurance coverage, plus grants to help rebuild small businesses and commercial properties damaged by the fire.

CONTENT:
AS a tenant in Santa Monica I was flat out of luck. I just had to move out of my unit two weeks ago because the owner was refusing to do the needed ash mitigation and refused to speak about it. Because I was 1 block outside "the fire zone" I didn't qualify for help even though had an apartment filled with ash. Fights with landlord ensued and there was no protection from eviction.

Nearby communities are impacted too. I get that the line has to be drawn somewhere but this is ridiculous.

So exhausted with having had a huge impact but no help because I am one block out of zone and had an apartment.

I have some ALE but it took a long while to kick in and I had no idea how to navigate it. I still need help understanding how insurance can help
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated tenant forced to move after landlord refused ash mitigation. Being just outside official fire zone meant no assistance, despite significant impact. Insurance and legal protections unclear and inadequate.

CONTENT: Insurance companies must be held accountable for claims. They are in the insurance business. That is a risk reward business. Extreme profit at the expense of people is unacceptable.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are making excessive profits while avoiding their responsibility to pay claims. They need to be held accountable since risk and payouts are fundamental to their business model.

CONTENT: Insurance companies need to make it easier to access ALE while it is unsafe to live in standing homes in the impacted area.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should streamline access to Additional Living Expenses when homes are unsafe but still standing in fire-affected zones.

CONTENT:
Insurance company made a lot of $$$$$ now they are leaving, asking for any nonsense or single bs details about any property even a shadow of a roof is a denial for them.
We need more effort from the insurance commissioner
Not just for Homeowners 
Bussines Owners, Worker's Compensation and all those insurance we normally paid e every single day/month.
We need a specific rule for these and everything about the insurance Bussines network..
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with insurance companies abandoning area and denying claims over minor details. Want stronger oversight from insurance commissioner to protect homeowners and businesses through better regulations.

CONTENT: This is a critical role of government but it needs to be done in a way that ensures safety and safe removal of toxic debris. This also needs to be done in a way that treats all communities equitably (not wealthy neighborhoods first), and with an environmental justice lens
LLM_SUMMARY: Government must handle toxic debris removal safely and equitably across all communities, not prioritizing wealthy areas. Environmental justice needs to be central to the recovery process.

CONTENT: Clean the debris FAST. Waive permit fees for the people who are rebuilding, whether that means like for like or smaller or bigger than what they had. Direct GRANT to homeowners.
LLM_SUMMARY: Urgently remove debris and eliminate permit fees for all rebuilding projects. Provide direct grants to homeowners to support recovery, regardless of rebuild size or type.

CONTENT: There is still a lot of confusion about what FEMA and SBA can help with. I hear from from a lot of people even if they have insurance.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by lack of clarity around FEMA and SBA assistance programs, even for those with insurance. Need better communication about what help is available.

CONTENT: Legal aid necessary
LLM_SUMMARY: Need legal assistance but no details provided about specific requirements.

CONTENT: Having been non renewed by my insurance company I think it is critical to assist homeowners rebuild their homes through a grant program. To keep the community flavor it will require getting year old owners back in their homes. Otherwise the old neighborhood will be replaced with money hungry developers with no thought of community only profit. Tenants will need access to new apartment building so assisting the owners rebuild in a timely fashion with also be critical
LLM_SUMMARY: Worried about losing community character after insurance non-renewal. We need grants to help original homeowners rebuild quickly, preventing developers from taking over and displacing tenants.

CONTENT: This is so very important. Altadena's backbone is small, mom 'n pop businesses, and they cannot come back without support. Otherwise soulless, generic chains will fill the void.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small local businesses are essential to Altadena's character and need support to recover, or chain stores will take over - we can't let that happen to our community.

CONTENT: Our senior community, especially in Altadena, needs support navigating this disaster!
LLM_SUMMARY: Seniors in our Altadena community desperately need guidance and assistance dealing with the emotional toll of this wildfire disaster.

CONTENT: We should be investing in new ideas for fire mitigation strategies. For example, insuring a home from fire could be cheaper if the home has a built-in (or on) fire protection system that significantly improves its odds of surviving a fire. We could incentivize the free market to explore new technologies or ideas through grants or subsidies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want insurance companies to offer lower rates for homes with fire protection systems and support innovation in fire mitigation through market incentives and grants.

CONTENT: expansion of broadband is essential but the data providers took all the ACP money and now thats over
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that broadband expansion isn't happening since data providers took Affordable Connectivity Program funds and the program has ended.

CONTENT: Push insurance companies to simply pay out 100% on total losses, as we are all under insured anyhow.  This has occurred in prior fires, and we are desperately needing to rebuild sooner than later, so knowing a budget is key, and key now.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should fully pay out total losses since we're all underinsured. We need quick payouts to start rebuilding - this has been done for previous fires.

CONTENT: Can someone set up a grant finder website?
LLM_SUMMARY: Need a centralized website to help find and access available grants for wildfire recovery.

CONTENT:
I totally concur with this remark. Our home insurance has more than doubled each year for the last two years and there is no end in site to the increases.  This is not sustainable.  It is no surprise that so many homeowners who lost their homes either were woefully uninsured or had no insurance.  

Also, what is not calculated in the rebuild costs is how much construction costs will rise due to the limited number of legitimate and qualified construction companies available in a crisis like this. It is completely understandable why we so many people are leaving for other states.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance costs are skyrocketing unsustainably, leading to underinsurance. Limited qualified contractors drive up rebuilding costs after fires, forcing many residents to leave California.

CONTENT: Underinsurance and lack of insurance is obviously going to be a huge problem. Hopefully organizations will step up to offer options in terms of cheaper builds and getting creative for funding/grants to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Worried about insufficient insurance coverage. Hope organizations can provide affordable rebuilding options and creative funding solutions through grants to help people recover and rebuild.

CONTENT: Insurance companies should pay all policy limits for inventory and property value. Future wildfire survivors are paying for those limits, the insurance companies shouldn’t make the process difficult to collect those limits.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies need to pay full policy limits without making claims difficult. We pay for this coverage, so they shouldn't create obstacles for wildfire survivors.

CONTENT: Rent gouging is rampant. I'm grateful the AG has prioritized investigations into guilty landlords, but I'm in a delicate spot of not wanting to lose housing while I've been collecting materials for a case. There has got to be a way to nip this in the bud earlier, so that a homeseeker isn't intimidated by retaliation. Can we CC in some sort of caseworker to let a landlord know we mean business?
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by rent gouging after the fire but hesitant to report landlords due to fear of retaliation. Want protection and support from caseworkers when reporting illegal rent increases.

CONTENT: Those who had good insurance or money to rebuild were able to take advantage of grants early on. The grants offered are first come first serve. In my community of Paradise CA, fixed income, low income and lower med. income were offered loans because they received tiny payouts from the PG$E bankruptcy stretched out over 6 years. Most were not able to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance and wealth determined who could access early grants. Lower-income residents got stuck with loans and small PG&E bankruptcy payouts, making rebuilding impossible for many in our community.

CONTENT: We are middle income family-working class.  We need grants and we need the help.
LLM_SUMMARY: Struggling working-class family seeking financial assistance through grants to help recover from wildfire impacts.

CONTENT: Rebuild to new codes and fire safe is not affordable. Even if you do rebuild to fire safety Insurance lies and does not insure regardless of how safe
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies won't cover homes even when rebuilt to fire-safe standards, and meeting new safety codes is too expensive for most people anyway.

CONTENT: We must support those who lost their businesses and were employing local workers. For communities to prosper, we must incentivize the local economy to ensure everyone not only recovers, but everyone thrives.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to help businesses that employ local workers get back on their feet. Supporting the local economy is crucial for our whole community's recovery and long-term success.

CONTENT: Please expedite permitting and waive the necessary fees
LLM_SUMMARY: Need faster permit processing and fee waivers to help us rebuild and recover from the fire damage.

CONTENT: I agree, there should be more support for our most vulnerable in our communities! Seniors, veterans, disabled, people with less than who were displaced/affected from any disaster including fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need more mental health support for vulnerable community members - seniors, veterans, disabled, and low-income people who were displaced by disasters like fires.

CONTENT: Depends on the community.  I sense this is more needed in Altadena than Palisades.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses need more recovery support in Altadena compared to Pacific Palisades, as economic needs vary between these communities.

CONTENT: All Utility companies need to be made FULLY accountable. PG$E was NOT made fully accountable only 70% accountable. Victims throughout CA need to be fully compensated-100%!
LLM_SUMMARY: Utility companies must be held 100% accountable for wildfires they cause, not partially like PG&E. Full compensation is needed for all California wildfire victims.

CONTENT: Our loss of use coverage is up to 2 years.  I don't think we can rebuild our home in 24 month from this point... We need more help after 2 years from the fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance's two-year loss of use coverage isn't enough time to rebuild our home. We need extended support beyond this timeframe to complete reconstruction.

CONTENT: More funds are needed to help residents remove dead trees and other fuel on private lands.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need financial assistance to clear hazardous vegetation from private properties - dead trees and other fire fuels are a major risk that homeowners can't address alone.

CONTENT: All of the above. Rebuilding is going to be very expensive and most people are underinsured. We need grants and don't want to fall further into debt.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about high rebuilding costs and underinsurance. Need grants rather than loans to avoid taking on more debt during recovery process.

CONTENT: Finding an affordable place to live is nearly impossible! We need help finding a place to live because the rents are so high and landlords don’t want pets. And make it illegal to charge additional rent for pets, especially after a declared disaster like LA. No one charges additional rent for toddlers, yet they are far more destructive than pets.
LLM_SUMMARY: Desperate for affordable housing after the fire, but high rents and pet restrictions make it impossible. It's unfair to charge extra for pets during disasters when children cause more damage.

CONTENT: Consistency for One California is a must. My community of Paradise Ca had substantial costs with permits, surveys, septic, architect costs. Fleeced by our own town.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by excessive rebuilding costs in Paradise, including permits, surveys, and architectural fees. Feel taken advantage of by local government during reconstruction process.

CONTENT: Disability child or adult need much more help, but sadly we have such a limited help.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need much more assistance for disabled individuals during wildfire recovery - current support is very limited and inadequate.

CONTENT: Maybe on a community level thru religious affiliations and other community organizations but not the county not city
LLM_SUMMARY: Don't expect help from city or county - look to religious groups and community organizations for emotional support. They're the ones actually helping people.

CONTENT: Homeowners and insurance companies should have to review the policy yearly and insurance language must be written at a 6 grade level in order for everyone to understand.  There are to many hidden meanings and definitions as well as all information should be explicit and complete.  Do not let insurance companies provide homeowners with a summary chart that leaves out specific restrictions.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance policies need yearly reviews and must be written simply. Too many hidden terms and restrictions are buried in complex language. Companies shouldn't hide details in summary charts.

CONTENT: Use Strong Towns principles in the rebuilding process. Prioritize the lowest-income households first. Deprioritize owners with second-homes. Establish clear process and timelines for residents to gain access to aid. Do not bypass environmental concerns.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want rebuilding to follow Strong Towns approach, helping low-income residents first. Need clear timelines for aid access. Don't skip environmental reviews or prioritize vacation homeowners.

CONTENT: Must clean before anything. Do clean-up at the neighborhood or at minimum at the block-level, not individual building site, to be more more efficient and cost effective. Require home owners and insurance companies to bundle efforts/$$.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need coordinated, block-level debris cleanup instead of individual property efforts. Homeowners and insurance companies should pool resources for more efficient, cost-effective neighborhood recovery.

CONTENT: Local and small businesses are vital to the community.  Their needs may appear to be different from the residents, and those differences should be acknowledged.  I would see this as a opportunity to prioritize local businesses.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses are crucial to our community and have unique recovery needs compared to residents. We should use this as a chance to make them a priority.

CONTENT: All of these should be areas in which "financial aid" is available.  I don't have answers as to where that comes from, but I believe that as a nation/state/community, we should offer assistance to make each person as whole as possible.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need financial aid available at all levels - national, state, and local - to help restore people's lives after wildfires. Our community should support making everyone whole again.

CONTENT: After a major natural disaster is NOT the time to decrease funding at the basic firefighting level.  And yes, agencies at all levels should be accountable to the people they serve.  As noted above, transparency and truth is needed to ensure that the money goes where it should.  I do believe that non-partisan oversight is needed.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need proper funding for basic firefighting, not cuts after disasters. All agencies must be transparent and accountable, with non-partisan oversight to ensure money is spent correctly.

CONTENT: Take care of the local business owners as well as the owners (first) EXPEDIENTLY,
LLM_SUMMARY: Small business owners and property owners need rapid financial assistance and support to recover from wildfire impacts.

CONTENT: ADU shall not be a requirement regardless of CA housing shortage.
LLM_SUMMARY: Opposed to mandatory ADU requirements during rebuilding, despite California's housing crisis.

CONTENT: LA has the opportunity to set the example and lead the way for Southern California and the world on how to rebuild with climate resilience in mind
LLM_SUMMARY: We can be a model for climate-resilient rebuilding in Southern California and beyond - LA needs to take the lead and show how it's done.

CONTENT: I think planning for a more rebust LA can happen now, and implementation can happen in time.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to start planning now for a more resilient Los Angeles infrastructure, rather than waiting until after disasters strike to make improvements.

CONTENT: We need deregulation and free permitting. building Codes are great and needed for public safety but then why is government penalizing citizens, owners and builders by charging them to implement safety codes. Makes no sense! Property taxes are already excessive and should already cover this expense and service to promote safety and avoid the need for people to dodge code or safety requirements.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that building permit fees discourage safety code compliance. Government shouldn't charge us to implement required safety measures - property taxes should already cover these costs.

CONTENT: partially, the new code requirements should be evaluated by DISINTERESTED 3rd party experts to make sure they actually do something. so much code is basically lobbied into existence by people and companies who gain from requiring expensive, spurious non-sense. there should be significant legal aid for that effort.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want third-party experts reviewing building codes to prevent unnecessary, profit-driven requirements. Need legal support to challenge questionable codes that increase rebuilding costs.

CONTENT: this should be focused on prevention and rebuilding in such a way as to create resilience, not rebuilding in the old way then creating warning systems to alert us when history repeats itself.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to prioritize fire prevention and rebuild with resilience in mind, rather than just recreating vulnerable conditions and relying on warning systems when disasters strike again.

CONTENT: working with the county is extremely difficult and time consuming. policies mostly don't make sense and are often conflicting. this is an opportunity to streamline the processes without degrading the quality of the outcome.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by complex, contradictory county policies that slow down recovery. Want streamlined processes while maintaining quality standards for rebuilding businesses after wildfire damage.

CONTENT: government efficiency. and i don't mean in the DOGE sense. i mean real govt efficiency in designing code that makes sense, isn't bloated, but is very focused on smart building. reducing costs. property values in the area have increased by 3x +++ in the last 30 years. has the cost of running the govt increased by 3x? there should be budget surplus. government ineffectiveness in combo with lack of high information civic participation is the root cause. adding better vent covers is important, but will not solve the underlying issues.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need smarter building codes and more efficient government spending. With property values tripling, we should have budget surplus for fire prevention, but bureaucratic inefficiency and low civic engagement are bigger problems.

CONTENT: Please put as many power lines underground as possible.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to prioritize undergrounding power lines to prevent fires - this should be a key focus of prevention efforts.

CONTENT: CA should just call the entire state a WUI CA Fire zone. No more pockets where CA Fire WUI regulations are not in place
LLM_SUMMARY: We need statewide wildland-urban interface fire regulations across California, not just in designated areas. The current patchwork approach leaves communities vulnerable.

CONTENT: Building code needs to emphasize fire safe
LLM_SUMMARY: Building codes must prioritize fire safety measures.

CONTENT: Tax relief for fire hardened houses and neighborhoods. The more contiguous houses that are fire hardened the more tax relief/house. So we encourage NEIGHBORHOODS to communicate and cooperate
LLM_SUMMARY: Want tax incentives for fire-hardening homes, with bigger breaks when multiple neighbors participate. This would promote community-wide protection through cooperation and communication.

CONTENT:
Infrastructural changes are necessary. They are also incredibly expensive. Burying power lines throughout the city is incredibly expensive... who is going to pay for it? You need a more robust, dense tax base. 

These analyses of different cities have been done by Urban3, which reveals how tax revenue/acre increases with density. Greater density would easily help to fund the necessary infrastructure improvements.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need buried power lines for safety, but it's too expensive without increasing population density to generate more tax revenue per acre to fund these improvements.

CONTENT: Insurance companies make their money on being able to predict risk. I think if an insurer says it's too risky to live somewhere, we should listen.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies know how to assess risk - if they won't insure certain areas due to fire danger, we should take that as a serious warning sign.

CONTENT: Replacing sprawled, high-fire risk areas with natural buffers against fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should convert high-risk developed areas back to natural landscapes that can act as fire barriers.

CONTENT: However, the environmental recovery should include a plan to establish and maintain fire breaks in the Santa Monica mountains above and around the town. The area managed by the conservancy and the state parks in the mountains are really wild animal parks, and should be treated and managed as such balancing the needs of the animals against the safety of the surrounding communities. The historical approach is resulting in larger and more frequent wildfires. So something clearly has to change.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need better fire breaks in the Santa Monica mountains and smarter management of wildlife areas. The current approach isn't working - fires are getting worse and more frequent.

CONTENT: Undergrounding power as feasible.  Also, roads are already notably damaged by heavy equipment. Many will require road replacement (including new grading and base)
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about power lines needing to be moved underground and extensive road damage from heavy equipment. Roads will need complete reconstruction, including new grading and foundation work.

CONTENT: Provide shelter even if temporary w/tiny home or mobile unit while rebuilding. Look at Sonoma county after their fires-lots of people lived in temporary units on their lot while rebuilding. Also the county had a dedicated fast track team to process building permits.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need temporary housing options like tiny homes while rebuilding, similar to Sonoma County's approach. Fast-track permitting process would help speed up recovery and reconstruction.

CONTENT: This should be seen as an opportunity to do in ground power lines. 5g cell towers. Water collection from roofs into cisterns. Pedestrian and bike friendly infrastructure.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to use this rebuild as a chance to modernize with underground power, 5G, water collection systems, and better pedestrian/bike infrastructure - not just restore what was there before.

CONTENT: We need clear guidance on fire resistant best practices. Most of the guidance is tailored to homes in rural areas.  It does not apply to homes that are 10 feet apart in a city suburb.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that fire safety guidelines don't address suburban realities - need specific recommendations for closely-spaced homes in urban areas, not just rural properties.

CONTENT: We should be considering discontinuing natural gas lines to neighborhoods that opt in for that.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want neighborhoods to have the choice to eliminate natural gas infrastructure, suggesting this as an option for utility restoration and future safety.

CONTENT: Rebuilding assistance should take into account what we know about fire and other disasters to guide "smart" rebuilding
LLM_SUMMARY: We need rebuilding assistance that incorporates lessons learned from past fires and disasters to ensure smarter, more resilient reconstruction approaches.

CONTENT: - Putting utilities underground - Palisades never had good phone or internet reception (esp ATT) unless connected to a specific Wifi, this can be improved - Look to establish a public middle school in the Palisades - Filling and maintaining a reservoir at all times - Getting out of the Palisades (whether during a fire evacuation or during morning or afternoon rush hour) was always tough - especially on Chatauqua and the left turn onto PCH - it could take 20+ minutes to get down.
LLM_SUMMARY: Poor cell service and evacuation bottlenecks at Chautauqua/PCH made emergency situations more dangerous. Underground utilities and improved infrastructure needed for safer community access and communication.

CONTENT: prioritise watershed and water systems restoration and regeneration. Reduce run-off - slow it, spread it, sink it. all electric wires need to go underground. Permeable pavement. encourage community allotments, native tree planting.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to focus on water system restoration and preventing runoff. Moving power lines underground is crucial. Adding permeable surfaces and native plants would help our community recover.

CONTENT: Make this process easier by committing to a bold mission statement focused on improvement. Hire more locals and ensure our Los Angeles team is trained to accelerate progress. We must dismantle the slow, outdated government processes and replace them with efficient, modern solutions. We should not repeat past mistakes; instead, we will grow and thrive.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to modernize and streamline rebuilding processes by hiring local talent and updating inefficient government systems. The old way is too slow - we must improve to move forward.

CONTENT: Remove the red tape and long waits. Hire and train locally. Give back to our own and do it quickly. Why does it take months to onboard people to help us? Why are they not people from here that understand us?
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by slow recovery assistance and bureaucracy. Want faster local hiring and support from people who understand our community, rather than waiting months for outside help.

CONTENT: All areas prone to wildfires - entire water systems should be retrofitted - to include special water dischargers. Strategically placed to water trees, buildings, houses, and the ground. I believe such a system would be one hundred times more effective than any system currently in place as it relates to fighting wildfire. We can look to the Japanese Government for their blueprints on how they accomplished this. With that, these areas should have sirens to alert everyone, including annual drills for preparedness training.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need comprehensive water systems with strategic dischargers to protect against wildfires, following Japan's model. Add warning sirens and regular community preparedness drills for better protection.

CONTENT: People need places to live, but I don't think it should be in high-risk fire zones if we can help it. Pay the people who lost their homes, but rebuild high-density housing in urban areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should compensate those who lost homes but discourage rebuilding in fire-prone areas. Instead, focus on developing high-density housing in safer urban locations.

CONTENT: I've never understood why there are above ground electric wires in Angeles National Forest and Eaton Canyon specifically. The area is prone to fires! Get those underground or out of the park!
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that high-risk fire areas still have above-ground power lines in Angeles National Forest and Eaton Canyon. Demands utilities move lines underground or relocate them entirely.

CONTENT: MUST have underground power lines!  Its 2025 for goodness sakes.  The water systems are also archaic and are long overdue for an overhaul
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that power lines aren't underground yet in 2025. Water infrastructure is outdated too - both systems desperately need modernization to prevent future disasters.

CONTENT: Allow people to do what they need to do to rebuild.  EVERYONE is going to have a significant shortfall when it comes to rebuilding.  Clear the way so there are less hurdles
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by rebuilding obstacles and financial shortfalls. Want authorities to reduce bureaucratic barriers and make it easier for fire victims to rebuild their homes.

CONTENT: Stop building in all fire-prone areas!
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to completely halt development in areas vulnerable to wildfires.

CONTENT: Underinsured homeowners can't afford the new code requirements.  Grants and tax relief should be provided to ease that burden.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building code upgrades are too expensive for underinsured homeowners like us. We need financial help through grants and tax breaks to afford these mandatory improvements.

CONTENT: Coordination with home owners. Require soil testing
LLM_SUMMARY: Need better coordination with homeowners on debris cleanup and mandatory soil testing to ensure proper environmental recovery.

CONTENT: Provide more transparent plans for future of undergrounding and locations as that will influence plans.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want clearer communication about future utility undergrounding plans and locations so I can make informed decisions about my property and recovery.

CONTENT: All housing rebuilds and new developments in rebuilding areas should be reviewed ministerially and expedited so that permits can be issued within 30-60 days. This should apply to any housing project meeting current building and zoning codes and, of course, to actual rebuild projects. The Mayor and Governor's arbitrary 110% footprint and height requirement only punishes people who need to rebuild their homes or businesses by not allowing them to build what would be allowed for anyone else in the City.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that rebuild permits face unnecessary restrictions and delays. Want expedited approvals for code-compliant projects, without arbitrary footprint limits that unfairly constrain what fire victims can rebuild compare

CONTENT:
Underground power lines, holding Edison corporate accountable, not letting Edison pass on their mistakes onto the cost of their customers. Every time they go into litigation or bills go up. 

When they need to shut off power due to weather - my husband can’t work. So he doesn’t get paid. 

The way palisades and Altadena need to be rebuilt needs to be smart. All street lights need to be solar, solar cross walks, a better environment and a safer environment for kids.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with Edison's accountability and costs passed to customers. Power shutoffs affect income. Want smart rebuilding with solar infrastructure for safer community environment.

CONTENT: Affordable fire resistant building supplies is a necessity. More native plants that aren't extremely flammable
LLM_SUMMARY: Need affordable fire-resistant building materials and less flammable native plants to better protect our community from future fires.

CONTENT: Toxics removal is very important for long-term community health.  We need to understand what sort of toxic were produced by the fire and not be in such a rush to rebuild that we create long-term problems in the process.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about rushing rebuilding before properly addressing toxic debris from the fire. Want thorough assessment and removal of hazardous materials to protect community's long-term health.

CONTENT: We need a community that can live with fire.  As I understand it, the homes built to the latest standards for materials and design, which also had appropriate defensible space, did much better than other homes in the fires.  We need to ensure that the rebuild follows these standards, which includes financing, ensuring that contractors are properly trained, appropriate materials are available, and agreements that communities rebuilt to these standards are insurable in the future.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must rebuild homes using fire-resistant materials and designs with proper defensible space. This requires financing, trained contractors, material availability, and insurance company buy-in for long-term community resilience

CONTENT: What is wildfire adaptation? Fire-resistant design and preparedness training are not the City's role; let Angelenos, their architects, and private organizations do this.
LLM_SUMMARY: City shouldn't be involved in wildfire adaptation - leave fire-resistant design and preparedness to residents, architects, and private organizations to handle independently.

CONTENT: Do NOT skip CEQA or EIRs, we are still THE biggest urban oil field in the nation and had the biggest urban wildfire in history, not testing the soil and ensuring there are no remnants of toxic oil chemicals is very important. No one deserves to live on top of toxic land.
LLM_SUMMARY: Strongly oppose bypassing environmental reviews and soil testing, given LA's oil field history. Must ensure no toxic chemicals remain in burned areas before rebuilding. Safety is paramount.

CONTENT: Focusing on what the City can fund at a time of unprecedented deficits is absurd, and the City is unable to hold its agencies accountable. Angelenos should hold the Council responsible for the City's failures at the ballot box. City government should ensure that fire prevention requirements are clear to allow private citizens and enterprises to implement them without bureaucratic delays.
LLM_SUMMARY: City's budget constraints shouldn't excuse poor fire prevention. Council needs to be held accountable through voting, and prevention requirements must be streamlined for private implementation.

CONTENT: This is essential and should be done by private enterprise to the extent feasible. Large infrastructure contractors can do this much faster than Public Works or LADWP and likely more cost-effectively. This is not the time for political egos to eye ad opportunities for the next election; move out of the way and let the city rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Private contractors should handle infrastructure restoration instead of government agencies - they're faster and more cost-effective. Stop playing politics and let experts rebuild our city.

CONTENT: Make sure all homes and buildings rebuilt can withstand future climate risks and impacts like fires, heat, drought, extreme storms, flooding. Make sure communities are resilient to start before disasters hit. Use and work with nature and natrure-based solutions to mitigate the climate hazards.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to proactively build climate-resilient homes and communities that can withstand fires, storms, and other disasters. Working with nature-based solutions is key to reducing future risks.

CONTENT: Make fossil fuel polluters pay for deceiving the public about fossil fuel use and driving the climate crisis that has led to increased extreme heat, drought, and other conditions that have led to higher fire risk. Also, there must be focus on more utilization of prescribed and cultural burns to manage fuel loads, as well as avoiding building and redevelopment in areas of high risk.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to hold fossil fuel companies accountable for climate change's role in fire risk, while implementing prescribed burns and limiting development in high-risk zones.

CONTENT: Codes need to be updated to maintain vegetation perimeters, so the fires can't spread from vegetation to houses.  If the home owner can't afford tree-trimming and so forth, the cities must help pay for this, because the cost of neighborhoods burning down is far worse.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need updated vegetation codes and city funding to help homeowners maintain defensible spaces. Can't let cost barriers put neighborhoods at risk of burning down.

CONTENT: In high-risk areas, further development must be tied to adequate evacuation routes
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to ensure any new construction in fire-prone areas includes proper evacuation planning. Current routes aren't sufficient for everyone to get out safely.

CONTENT: I should not have to shoulder Palisades folks rebuilding in such a high risk area.
LLM_SUMMARY: Don't want my tax dollars supporting rebuilds in high-risk fire zones like Pacific Palisades.

CONTENT: Underground all power lines. Widen roads. Fix the fire hydrants and reservoirs.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need basic infrastructure improvements - underground power lines, wider roads, and properly maintained hydrants and water systems for firefighting.

CONTENT: People displaced by the fires need help not only with rebuilding, but with living in their chosen communities immediately.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need immediate housing assistance to stay in our communities while rebuilding, not just help with reconstruction later on.

CONTENT:
I believe now is exactly the right time to do the Caltrans redesign making PCH a boulevard instead of a 5-lane highway (without a middle lane that is unnecessary and inappropriate for a semi-rural community if the re-design ensues) leaving much more space on the sides for cars to make way for emergency vehicles. Biking and walking on PCH are already happening.  Please, let’s make it safe.

Please underground utilities throughout Malibu.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should use this opportunity to redesign PCH as a safer boulevard with better emergency vehicle access, bike lanes, and pedestrian paths. Also crucial to underground all utilities in Malibu.

CONTENT: Provide grants to help people fire harden their homes for those who can't afford it to reduce the chances and severity of future fires
LLM_SUMMARY: We need financial assistance through grants to help lower-income residents make their homes more fire-resistant, which will help prevent severe damage in future fires.

CONTENT: Strongly consider requiring new builds to be resilient by using the Passive Housing Standard, all electric buildings and fire resistant building materials. Electrifying homes and using a PHS combined lead to massive energy savings for homeowners and benefits to the entire community and region by lowering building pollution.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want new construction to follow Passive Housing Standards and use fire-resistant materials. All-electric homes would save energy costs while reducing pollution for the whole community.

CONTENT: While everyone wants to build back exactly as we were, we need to consider that this will happen again. We should consider using fire resistant materials when rebuilding.
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't just rebuild exactly like before - we need to think ahead and use fire-resistant materials since this could happen again in the future.

CONTENT: I would like to see several well-publicized and documented rapid pilot programs in various communities in LA that help Angelenos understand the scope and disruption related to retrofitting old systems. Everyone wants to DWP, etc to "do it", and they absolutely must, but it would be great to understand what that looks like, how we as citizens need to willingly participate in the process when it's our neighborhood's turn, how this affects our bottom line and what kind of ecological and safety improvements this brings to our communities.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to see pilot programs showing what utility infrastructure upgrades actually look like in neighborhoods - the disruption, costs, and benefits - so residents understand and can better support these necessary improvements.

CONTENT: Pre-permitted ADU designs. Most folks are not picky about how an ADU looks- they want fast build and understandable regulations- so they can earn rent.... which creates more housing in LA.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want pre-approved ADU designs to speed up rebuilding and create rental income. Don't care much about looks - just need clear rules and quick construction to add housing.

CONTENT: All important to a functioning community. As usual, the question begs - who pays for this?  Should the folks in Etna, CA be taxed for the folly of building so many high-dollar homes in an obvious fire zone? Should Modesto be on the hook for wealthy home owners in Marin or Sonoma or LA?
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about fairness in funding infrastructure repairs after fires. Questions why taxpayers across California should subsidize rebuilding in wealthy, high-risk fire zones.

CONTENT: Bury the power lines. Put in sidewalks.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need underground power lines and proper sidewalks installed - these basic infrastructure improvements are essential.

CONTENT: I kindly urge you to consider hiring and training individuals from Los Angeles for this work. We can make a positive impact by reducing bureaucratic barriers and giving our local community a chance. The job market in LA is genuinely challenging right now, and supporting our own can bring hope and opportunity to those in need. Hire our own, train our own, and stop with the six-month hiring process. People are losing everything, and we aren't requiring these contractors to hire those affected.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with slow hiring processes and outside contractors. Want local LA residents hired and trained for restoration work - it would help our struggling community and provide needed jobs for fire-affected people.

CONTENT: We need safe water and soil so that the toxins not only do not enter our systems but it doesn't enter into the systems of the animals in our area. If there are toxins in our soil, any movement of that soil can kick up the toxins and cause major damage to our respiratory systems. Rebuilding should walk side by side with safety of the community.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about toxic debris contaminating water, soil, and air, affecting both residents and wildlife. Want rebuilding efforts to prioritize community safety through proper environmental cleanup.

CONTENT: Underground electricity please. Bike paths, sidewalks would be amazing. Many of our Altadena streets didn’t even have sidewalks.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want underground power lines installed and basic infrastructure like sidewalks and bike paths added - our Altadena streets are missing these essential safety features.

CONTENT: Long term goals for hardening homes against wildfires in the future is a must. Those homes being rebuilt and those being repaired should take steps to ensure proper materials are used as a start. Climate change is real and is here to stay.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to focus on making homes more fire-resistant during rebuilding and repairs. Using proper materials is essential since climate change will continue to increase wildfire risks.

CONTENT:
Exactly. ADUs should not be allowed in fire prone areas unless there is parking on property and there is a large enough lot to allow a wide buffer of space between the ADU and other structures.
In areas where the roads are narrow and it is already difficult to evacuate there should be a total ban on additional density. It is irresponsible to put more people in harms way and increase the danger to those already living there!
LLM_SUMMARY: Strongly oppose ADUs in fire-prone areas without adequate parking and spacing. Adding density where evacuation is already difficult puts more lives at risk and endangers existing residents.

CONTENT: Now is the time for Altadena to get sidewalks.  Let's future proof this community so that people can come back.  And while at it, bury the powerlines.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should use this opportunity to improve Altadena's infrastructure - add sidewalks and bury power lines to make our community more resilient and attractive for returning residents.

CONTENT: fire retardant materials, fire suppression units on buildings  regardless of materials used and directed in exposed areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need buildings with fire retardant materials and built-in fire suppression systems, especially in vulnerable areas exposed to wildfire risk.

CONTENT: Design roadways and bike/ped paths as green fire breaks through communities. Rebuild roadways as complete streets so they are safer for walking and bicycling and slow speeding to avoid crashes.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want roads and paths redesigned as fire breaks while making them safer for walking and biking - this would serve multiple community safety purposes.

CONTENT: It's clear that an inability to quickly shut down power contributed to the severity of the fire, along with exposed power lines. With the areas so devastated, it seems prudent for us to explore buried power lines to expand fire safety.
LLM_SUMMARY: Slow power shutoffs and exposed lines worsened the fire's impact. We should consider underground power lines to better protect our community from future disasters.

CONTENT: Let people rebuild historical homes without excess modern restrictions and codes. There must be room for nuance.  The State must empower local governments to be able to have their communities have a say in what this rebuild looks like.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want local control over rebuilding historic homes without excessive modern regulations. Communities should have more say in post-fire reconstruction, with flexibility in code requirements.

CONTENT: Bury the lines.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to bury power lines underground to prevent future fire risks.

CONTENT: I agree that money should not be spent on the monopolization of internet providers like Spectrum or AT&T. Money should go towards local and government infrastructure where able.
LLM_SUMMARY: Money should go to local and government infrastructure instead of being spent on monopolistic internet providers like Spectrum and AT&T.

CONTENT: We have a policy problem in California related to insurance.  it's not a market problem.  hurricanes wipe out MILLIONS of homes.  we are now worried about not having anymore home insurance because of 14,000 homes lost.  the Governor, Legislature and Insurance Commissioner need to fix this problem once and for all.  the California govt is to blame for our lack of insurance.  I want to be able to insure my home when i rebuild and i honestly don't think i'll be able to.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that California government's poor insurance policies may prevent me from getting coverage when rebuilding. This isn't a market issue - it's a policy failure that officials must fix.

CONTENT: To mitigate the risk of fire, all utilities that can cause ignition must be hardened. The utility companies must be responsible for this without expectations of reimbursement. The utility companies should have these safeguards built in if they want to do business. All new buildings must have fire resistant design, assuring that materials used are not toxic when exposed to fire. Areas prone to wildfire should not be rebuilt without technologies that reduce the danger.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need utility companies to fireproof their equipment at their own cost, and new construction must use fire-resistant, non-toxic materials. High-risk areas should only rebuild with proper safety technology

CONTENT: We need expertise and help to fire harden our whole community, not just encouraging a few people with the money to do it. Also we can't insure our way out of this. Insurance companies will leave if they don't make a profit and the state can't afford to take their place with the pace and severity of disasters. Education, fire audits, financial assistance. Community immunity.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need community-wide fire hardening, not just individual efforts by those who can afford it. Insurance isn't sustainable - we need education, fire audits, and financial help for collective protection.

CONTENT: Standing aside doesn't seem to be working. These insurance companies don't want to pay out anything and someone has got to twist their arm.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are refusing to pay claims and need to be pressured to provide proper compensation - we can't just stand by and let them avoid payouts.

CONTENT: This could be a strategic community effort rather than each individual homeowner having to go at it alone, which also strains the insurance systems, which in turn raises costs down the road.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should tackle insurance and recovery as a coordinated community effort instead of individually - it would be more efficient and help control long-term insurance costs.

CONTENT: Power lines need to be underground.  Europe has them, why doesn't California? This, and controlled burns, using goats to clear brush around urban-wildlife interface areas needs to be a priority for the state, county and city, and all water systems should be audited before the fire season begins. Leadership should be held accountable for not maintaining fire hydrants and reservoirs. There should be more budget dollars allocated to these preventative measures vs incurring billions in losses and the horrific trauma of our people. We should NOT be taxed through more bond measures for losses that were preventable or at least not a disaster of epic proportions.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines and preventative measures like controlled burns should be prioritized over costly disaster response. Leaders must be accountable for maintaining fire infrastructure instead of passing costs to taxpayers.

CONTENT: Bury power lines and prevent costs from being passed to consumer.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want underground power lines but don't make residents pay for it - the costs should be absorbed elsewhere.

CONTENT: state farm is trying to resist paying out and is claiming that in order to get 50% payout now we have to sign a form that in 36 months they are no longer liable to pay more. they also are requiring a list of all private property even if house is complete loss.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance company forcing us to sign away future claims to get partial payout now, and demanding detailed property lists despite total home loss. They're making it unnecessarily difficult.

CONTENT: I think it's really important to consider where to rebuild, and where not to rebuild. My grandmother's home burned down, and everyone in her community wants to rebuild in the same place. But does it really make sense when we know that the Palisades Highlands is in an extremely high fire risk area? To the extent that folks want to rebuild in high risk areas, should the entire state of California shoulder that risk through our tax dollars and insurance payments?
LLM_SUMMARY: Questioning if we should rebuild in high-risk fire zones like Palisades Highlands. While my grandmother's community wants to rebuild there, I wonder if taxpayers should keep subsidizing construction

CONTENT: Push insurance companies to simply pay out 100% on total losses, as we are all under insured anyhow.  This has occurred in prior fires, and we are desperately needing to rebuild sooner than later, so knowing a budget is key, and key now.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should fully pay out total losses since we're all underinsured. We need quick payouts to start rebuilding - this has worked in previous fires.

CONTENT: Legal aid to help those affected navigate the overly complex world of insurance and permits for building is incredibly important and necessary to support community and prevent investors from controlling the market.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need legal support to deal with complex insurance claims and building permits - this helps our community rebuild and keeps investors from taking over after the fire.

CONTENT:
I totally concur with this remark. Our home insurance has more than doubled each year for the last two years and there is no end in site to the increases.  This is not sustainable.  It is no surprise that so many homeowners who lost their homes either were woefully uninsured or had no insurance.  

Also, what is not calculated in the rebuild costs is how much construction costs will rise due to the limited number of legitimate and qualified construction companies available in a crisis like this. It is completely understandable why we so many people are leaving for other states.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance costs are skyrocketing unsustainably, leading to underinsurance. Limited qualified contractors drive up rebuilding costs. These financial pressures are forcing many to relocate out of state

CONTENT: Insurance companies should pay all policy limits for inventory and property value. Future wildfire survivors are paying for those limits, the insurance companies shouldn’t make the process difficult to collect those limits.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies need to pay full policy limits without making claims difficult. We pay for this coverage, so they shouldn't create obstacles for wildfire survivors seeking compensation.

CONTENT: In our rural area, we've discovered the hard way that key equipment for landlines, cable/internet and cell service often shares a power pole. Which means literally every means of communication most people have access to goes down at the same time if the fire takes out that ONE pole. There ought to be a mandate for undergrounding ALL of those services and separating them where undergrounding is not possible. A grant program to equip rural residents with satellite phones for emergency use would also help, as would establishing local emergency radio frequencies we could tune into for updates. Also, cell phones should be able to connect to ANY available tower for ALL CALLS (not just 911) and alerts (nixle, watch duty, etc) during emergencies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about communication vulnerabilities when single power poles fail during fires. We need underground utilities, separated infrastructure, satellite phones for rural areas, and unrestricted cell tower access during emergencies.

CONTENT: Require all electrical power lines to be undergrounded in the foothills and Altadena! SCE did a lousy job of protecting the residents along the foothills.
LLM_SUMMARY: SCE needs to put power lines underground in Altadena and the foothills. They failed to protect residents by not taking this basic safety measure.

CONTENT: Rebuild to new codes and fire safe is not affordable. Even if you do rebuild to fire safety Insurance lies and does not insure regardless of how safe
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies won't cover homes even when rebuilt to fire-safe standards, and meeting those codes is too expensive anyway. They're not keeping their promises.

CONTENT: All Utility companies need to be made FULLY accountable. PG$E was NOT made fully accountable only 70% accountable. Victims throughout CA need to be fully compensated-100%!
LLM_SUMMARY: Utility companies must be held 100% accountable for wildfires they cause, not partially like PG&E. Full compensation needed for all California wildfire victims.

CONTENT: Better coordination is needed between insurance companies and state agencies, so that residents of threatened areas can receive $ for temporary housing BEFORE evacuation is mandatory and can continue to receive it until essential services are restored to their homes. Right now, most people only receive assistance as long as evacuation is mandatory and only until the order is lifted, regardless of whether power, water and other essential services have been restored.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance and government agencies need to provide temporary housing funds before mandatory evacuations and continue support until homes have essential services restored, not just during official evacuation periods.

CONTENT: Homeowners and insurance companies should have to review the policy yearly and insurance language must be written at a 6 grade level in order for everyone to understand.  There are to many hidden meanings and definitions as well as all information should be explicit and complete.  Do not let insurance companies provide homeowners with a summary chart that leaves out specific restrictions.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance policies need yearly reviews and must be written simply. Too many hidden meanings and restrictions. Companies shouldn't get away with incomplete summary charts that hide details.

CONTENT: Hold power companies to strict guidelines and penalties for failure to maintain safety. Hold individuals as well as companies responsible for obvious neglect.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need strict enforcement and penalties for both power companies and individuals who neglect fire safety guidelines and maintenance responsibilities.

CONTENT: Undergrounding powerlines should be done now, before roads are repaved.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to put power lines underground first, before redoing the roads. Don't waste time and money doing things in the wrong order.

CONTENT: Must test pist phase 2 debris removal including schools and parks. Combination of federal state county and community responsibility.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need coordinated testing and cleanup of debris across schools and parks, requiring cooperation between federal, state, county and community levels.

CONTENT: Similar to a comment made yesterday: "I don't think that everyone should have to hire an attorney to get the fair benefit of their fire insurance policy." I wonder about California's appetite for SB 222 that might create an insurable future but at the cost of affordable gas. I read somewhere that climate change contributed about 25% to the impact of the fires. If that is true, then maybe oil and gas liability should be capped (or a mandatory oil and gas recovery fund set aside to the tune of an accurate reading on percentage of projected damages)
