LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that insurance claims require lawyers. Questioning if oil/gas companies should have liability caps or contribute to recovery funds based on their role in climate-driven fire damage.

CONTENT: Utilities must be held accountable. Insurance should only be valid for those who follow best fire safe practices.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to enforce accountability for utility companies and link insurance coverage to proper fire safety compliance by property owners.

CONTENT: Must clean before anything. Do clean-up at the neighborhood or at minimum at the block-level, not individual building site, to be more more efficient and cost effective. Require home owners and insurance companies to bundle efforts/$$.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need coordinated neighborhood-wide debris cleanup, not just individual properties. Bundling homeowner and insurance resources would make the process more efficient and cost-effective.

CONTENT: Take care of the local business owners as well as the owners (first) EXPEDIENTLY,
LLM_SUMMARY: Small business owners and property owners need rapid financial assistance and support to recover from wildfire impacts.

CONTENT: Would need clarity of which agencies would help with this in LA county so it can be effective.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need clear information about which LA County agencies are responsible for helping with climate resilience efforts - otherwise we can't make real progress.

CONTENT: Issues if the residents weren't insured/ underinsured. Making sure they receive timely support for rebuilding/ limited redtape. CA may have more strict building codes based on earthquake/ fire concerns. Ensuring the costs/ codes to build appropriately are still accessible based on the incomes/ avoiding exploitation from real estate corporate entities (Blackrock).
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about underinsured residents getting timely rebuilding support without excessive bureaucracy. Worried that strict building codes and corporate exploitation could make reconstruction unaffordable for many homeowners.

CONTENT: To help retain the local residents that were impacted/ future residents that are near fire risk areas, economic development/ workforce development will be essential. If grants are provided, it may be helpful to include local higher education institutions (community colleges, cal states, UCs), to make it more inclusive and a learning opportunity (volunteering/ college internship credit, college corps).
LLM_SUMMARY: Want economic support to keep residents in fire-prone areas. Suggest partnering with local colleges for grants and workforce development, creating opportunities through internships and volunteer programs.

CONTENT: I absolutely support economic assitance for local, small businesses.
LLM_SUMMARY: I strongly favor providing financial aid to help local small businesses recover.

CONTENT: Need to focus on helping individuals save their properties and rebuild. Focus on the children that lost schools, community activities and their childhood because they no longer have a home.
LLM_SUMMARY: Prioritize helping people save and rebuild homes, and support children who've lost their schools, activities, and sense of normalcy due to displacement from the fires.

CONTENT: partially, the new code requirements should be evaluated by DISINTERESTED 3rd party experts to make sure they actually do something. so much code is basically lobbied into existence by people and companies who gain from requiring expensive, spurious non-sense. there should be significant legal aid for that effort.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want third-party experts reviewing building codes to prevent unnecessary expensive requirements pushed by lobbyists. Need legal assistance to support this oversight and protect homeowners.

CONTENT: people should absolutely be allowed to live on their properties while they rebuild. it's crazy to be paying a mortgage on a property that you can't live on while you figure out how to rebuild your home. there should also be clear public information about what is permittable in the area and the county should be educated about it and required to expedite it. they often give wrong information. last, permitting fees for building new ADU (that weren't there before the fire) should be permanently waived. the cost of permits is often 50% of the total ADU budget.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with paying mortgage while unable to live on property during rebuilding. Want clear permitting information, expedited processes, and waived ADU permit fees due to high costs.

CONTENT: i think this is very important, but the way to deal with it is to actually support people getting back on their feet, not providing mental health services.
LLM_SUMMARY: Mental health services aren't what we really need - focus should be on practical support to help people rebuild their lives and recover materially first.

CONTENT: Tax relief for fire hardened houses and neighborhoods. The more contiguous houses that are fire hardened the more tax relief/house. So we encourage NEIGHBORHOODS to communicate and cooperate
LLM_SUMMARY: Want tax incentives for fire-hardening homes, with bigger breaks when multiple neighbors participate. This would promote community-wide preparation and cooperation among residents.

CONTENT: Don't need tax relief as much as streamlining approvals to get businesses back open, and densifying neighborhoods to make small businesses more profitable. Best way to assist local businesses is to get them back open again and as easily accessible as possible.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need faster business reopening approvals and denser neighborhoods to help small businesses recover and thrive, rather than just tax relief. Getting shops open and accessible is the priority.

CONTENT: Think inline with holding agencies accountable extends to after wildfires. We are seeing little to no approvals for housing reconstruction or repair. Beaucratic lallygagging post-crisis, when people have lost their homes and possessions, is entirely unacceptable
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by slow bureaucratic response after the fire. Agencies need to be held accountable for delays in housing reconstruction approvals when people have already lost everything.

CONTENT: Consistent testing and transparency please
LLM_SUMMARY: Want regular environmental testing and clear communication about debris removal progress and results.

CONTENT: Help the people who had mobile homes get back onto that land. That is the remaining middle class in the Palisades and we must not let it be overtaken by rich real estate developers.
LLM_SUMMARY: Protect middle-class mobile home residents by helping them return to their land, rather than letting wealthy developers take over the area after the fire.

CONTENT: Provide shelter even if temporary w/tiny home or mobile unit while rebuilding. Look at Sonoma county after their fires-lots of people lived in temporary units on their lot while rebuilding. Also the county had a dedicated fast track team to process building permits.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need temporary housing options like tiny homes on our lots during rebuild, plus faster permit processing. Sonoma County's model with dedicated permit teams worked well after their fires.

CONTENT: There is currently a grant for adu prebuilding costs - expand this program.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to see the ADU pre-building grant program expanded to help more people rebuild after fires. The current program is too limited.

CONTENT: Support/grants for pre-fire established small businesses that have been impacted by the fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need financial assistance and grant programs specifically for established local businesses that were affected by the fires, not just new businesses coming in.

CONTENT: The money to do this should already be a part of all the money that is being paid into the state, county and city.  Why there is almost no funds or action in the past in this area does not make any sense.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that despite paying taxes at multiple levels, there seems to be inadequate funding and action for wildfire prevention. This lack of prioritization makes no sense to me.

CONTENT: Remove the red tape and long waits. Hire and train locally. Give back to our own and do it quickly. Why does it take months to onboard people to help us? Why are they not people from here that understand us?
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by slow bureaucracy and outside hiring. Want faster local hiring and training to support community recovery - people who understand our needs and situation.

CONTENT: Accessible resources for all impacted!!!
LLM_SUMMARY: Need emergency resources that everyone affected by the fire can actually access and use.

CONTENT:
We need ACCOUNTABILITY, REFORMS, GRANTS, and TAX BREAKS. We cannot rebuild this community without help for individual home owners.
(And please keep it closed until more debris is cleared and more of the fortunate are able to repopulate standing homes. Remediation lines are long. It’s too soon.)
LLM_SUMMARY: Need financial support through grants and tax breaks to rebuild, plus better accountability and reforms. Keep area closed until debris clearing is complete and homes are safe to return to.

CONTENT: Through no fault of our own we are underinsured.  It's still unclear if we are going to get any FEMA money.  I still don't know what role Hagerty is going to play.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by insurance coverage gaps and uncertain about financial assistance from FEMA and Hagerty's role in the recovery process.

CONTENT: I am middle class. I’ll pour every cent into this rebuild, but I’m still not sure I can pull it off and I’m not sure I’m going to qualify for any help. Can you please keep that in mind? SEND GRANTS, PLEASE! I’ll follow every fire hardening guideline I can afford.
LLM_SUMMARY: Desperate for financial help to rebuild but worried I won't qualify for assistance as middle-class homeowner. Will follow fire safety guidelines but need grants to make it possible.

CONTENT: We have specific questions about the California Fair Plan.  What construction features are covered under the "Ordinance or Law" item in the CFP policy?  At one point I heard Steve Soboroff say that everyone should hire an attorney.  I don't think that everyone should have to hire an attorney to get the fair benefit of their fire insurance policy.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with California Fair Plan insurance coverage clarity and concerned about needing lawyers to get fair compensation. Shouldn't have to hire attorneys just to understand policy benefits.

CONTENT: Be sure all monies being distributed are not being scammed or stolen by those who are not eligible or impersonating those who do.  Slow it down and coordinate with all the other money coming in and make sure it gets to the right people.   Stop hiring big firms that are somehow supposed to help but are just another layer of bureaucracy and waste of money.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with bureaucracy and potential fraud in disaster relief. Want better coordination of funds and direct distribution to legitimate recipients, rather than paying large firms as middlemen.

CONTENT: Construction cost escalation from date of the fire to completion of homes will vastly exceed anyone's insurance settlement.  There was 6% per year escalation before the year, 9% in the last year, and will increase based on the massive reconstruction from the two major fires, tariffs, and regional labor shortage
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance settlements won't cover rapidly rising construction costs due to fire reconstruction demands, tariffs, and labor shortages - we're seeing 9% annual increases and it's getting worse.

CONTENT: Expedited permitting time and the cost of permits for rebuilds should be waived - these rebuilds are not being done by choice but by necessity and a result of government not being prepared and letting an entire community burn to the ground overnight.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that rebuilding permits are costly and slow after losing home to fire. Government should waive fees and speed up process since this wasn't our choice but their failure to protect us.

CONTENT:
County or city building processes have to be streamlined and charges kept manageable
For people
To recover successfully.  Plans and permits can’t be mired in municipal offices for undue amounts of time.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by slow municipal processes - we need streamlined building permits and reasonable fees to help fire victims rebuild their homes without getting stuck in bureaucratic delays.

CONTENT:
Again getting bonds together and finding resources is a priority and time is of the essence call
For special elections to help manage decisions
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to quickly secure bonds and resources through special elections to make urgent infrastructure decisions and manage recovery efforts.

CONTENT: The City has no money to do this; let charitable Angelenos take care of each other. Stop wasting our time and money.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fed up with city involvement - believes private charity between Angelenos is better than government financial assistance, which they see as wasteful spending.

CONTENT: The insurance landscape in California needs to be addressed. The FAIR plan is terrible, and private insurance companies take to long to process claims. There need to be faster ways for survivors to get access to funds after their home is destroyed.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance system is broken - FAIR plan is inadequate and private claims are too slow. We need faster ways to get money to wildfire survivors who've lost everything.

CONTENT: This really equires the Mayor and Supervisors to create a list of projects and see which they can partner with the State and Federal Gov to reduce or eliminate corporate gouging and unfairness.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want local leaders to work with state and federal government on specific projects to prevent price gouging and protect small businesses during wildfire recovery.

CONTENT: Renters need support from the County just the same as homeowners. I, a long with so many others, have not received our security deposits back despite the 21 day law. It then becomes our responsibility to start, and pay for, a Small Claims case, and good luck collecting it. We are busy trying to find a place to live, filling out paperwork and dealing with insurance/FEMA, and trying to apply for grants that never seem to materialize. We need help.
LLM_SUMMARY: Lost everything as a renter and struggling to recover deposits, find housing, and navigate aid systems. County needs to support renters equally to homeowners through this overwhelming process.

CONTENT:
The small business support that exists right now is a complete joke. They are high interest loans that are few and far between, businesses in palisades are battling with their internet provider for early cancellation - it’s not early cancellation. There is nothing to go back to!! Some of them are on the hook for over $10,000! These are everyday people
Who showed up day in and day out for our community and the county/city/state is turning their backs on them. 

Why are their no streamlined grants? Incentive them to say.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small business support is inadequate, with limited high-interest loans and unfair internet contract penalties. We need real grants and incentives, not barriers that hurt local businesses trying to rebuild.

CONTENT: Permit process needs to expedited without delay and costs need to be minimal for residents to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with slow rebuilding process - want expedited permits and reduced costs to help residents rebuild their homes more quickly after the fire.

CONTENT: Make it so all the small businesses can come back. Grants, incentives, or any sort of help should be given
LLM_SUMMARY: We need financial assistance through grants and incentives to help small businesses rebuild and return to the community after the fire's destruction.

CONTENT: Codes need to be updated to maintain vegetation perimeters, so the fires can't spread from vegetation to houses.  If the home owner can't afford tree-trimming and so forth, the cities must help pay for this, because the cost of neighborhoods burning down is far worse.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need updated vegetation codes and city support for homeowners who can't afford maintenance. Preventing fires through proper clearance is cheaper than rebuilding burned neighborhoods.

CONTENT: Make it easier to get temporary housing
LLM_SUMMARY: Need simpler process to access temporary housing after being displaced by fire.

CONTENT: Multifamily housing must be included in USACE's debris removal mission. It is the only fair thing to do. Treating one group of residents differently from another, when both impacted groups have suffered, pay taxes, and vote, is unjust. Multifamily housing residents tend to be underinsured by the way insurance companies structure insurance, tend to be lower income/wealth than single family homeowners, are often on a fixed income, single income, retired, and older. To discriminate against this vulnerable population is unjust and inexcusable.
LLM_SUMMARY: We deserve equal debris removal support for multifamily housing. It's unfair to exclude us when we're often more vulnerable, underinsured, and affected just like single-family homeowners.

CONTENT: Make testing affordable to those Altadenans who have lost everything.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need affordable soil testing options for Altadena residents who lost homes - we can't afford to pay for environmental assessments after losing everything.

CONTENT: I think some people have been more traumatized by their insurance than by the fire. Maddening and heartbreaking.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies have caused more trauma than the actual fire through their difficult claims process - it's both frustrating and emotionally devastating.

CONTENT: People displaced by the fires need help not only with rebuilding, but with living in their chosen communities immediately.
LLM_SUMMARY: We urgently need support for both immediate housing and long-term rebuilding efforts to stay in our communities after being displaced by the fires.

CONTENT:
Funding for communities to engage organizers and facilitators to act as paid (not volunteer, as is the Topanga Town Council, Chamber of Commerce, Emergency Preparedness (TCEP), elderly support (SAGES) - to bring community leaders together, to interface with govt agencies.
There should be a team specifically dedicated to coordination and communications as soon as a fire or other crisis strikes.
We need a unified 'easy to use' communications system for communities in crisis, including a clear and well organized hierarchy for distributing communications & a neighborhood/zone system that people are already enrolled in prefire. Cellular systems or mesh net wifi should be available for text only communications throughout the city and county.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need paid coordinators and a unified emergency communications system with clear hierarchy, not just volunteers. Pre-established neighborhood networks and backup text systems are essential for crisis response.

CONTENT: Provide grants to help people fire harden their homes for those who can't afford it to reduce the chances and severity of future fires
LLM_SUMMARY: We need financial assistance through grants to help lower-income residents make their homes more fire-resistant, which will help prevent severe damage in future fires.

CONTENT: REALLY speed up the approval process. Also, strongly encourage bungalow courts for multi-family housing-- basically groupings of 4 to 10 ADU-type buildings. They suit the Alta/Pasadena aesthetic, are affordable, are much better looking than flat, generic boxes, and will help bring renters to our community.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want faster building approvals and support for bungalow court-style housing developments. These match our neighborhood's character, are affordable, and would attract renters while looking better than standard apartments.

CONTENT: As long as there are checkpoints and the lines to enter are long, it will be very difficult for businesses to thrive.   We need to help them
LLM_SUMMARY: Checkpoints and long entry lines are hurting local businesses' ability to recover. We need to provide support to help them survive these access restrictions.

CONTENT: I kindly urge you to consider hiring and training individuals from Los Angeles for this work. We can make a positive impact by reducing bureaucratic barriers and giving our local community a chance. The job market in LA is genuinely challenging right now, and supporting our own can bring hope and opportunity to those in need. Hire our own, train our own, and stop with the six-month hiring process. People are losing everything, and we aren't requiring these contractors to hire those affected.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with slow hiring processes and outside contractors. Want local LA residents hired and trained for restoration work - it would help our struggling community while rebuilding from fire damage.

CONTENT: C.C.C.-like organization of volunteers &/or prisoners to help with cleanup and maybe earn some money.
LLM_SUMMARY: Suggests using organized volunteer groups or prison labor programs, similar to Civilian Conservation Corps, to assist with cleanup efforts while providing work opportunities.

CONTENT: Remove all bottlenecks when it comes to grants, economic recovery, and small business support.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need faster, simpler access to financial aid and business recovery resources without bureaucratic delays holding things up.

CONTENT: The debris removal is very uncoordinated and gate keeping is occurring by a few trucking companies that are barring other trucking companies from participating.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that debris removal is disorganized and certain trucking companies are monopolizing the work, preventing other companies from helping with the cleanup effort.

CONTENT: Businesses are critical to providing goods to the community. Without 3rd places, a community cannot thrive. Also, set backs should be increased like after the Paradise fire, reduces spread rate of fires AND entices fire insurance companies to return.
LLM_SUMMARY: Local businesses are vital for community wellbeing, but we need larger setbacks like Paradise implemented to reduce fire spread and bring back insurance companies.

CONTENT: Perhaps aid can be giving to homeowners who offer their ADU's as interim housing for those displaced in the fires?
LLM_SUMMARY: Suggesting financial assistance for homeowners who provide their ADUs as temporary shelter to those displaced by wildfires could help address housing needs.

CONTENT: Upzone the burned areas to increase the value of the land so that the homeowners can be made whole.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want burned areas upzoned to increase land value and help homeowners recover their losses through higher property values.

CONTENT: Where are the fundraising dollars going? We have received a minimal amount of $ . Are the dollars being vetted?
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated about lack of transparency in wildfire relief fund distribution. Questioning how donations are managed and why so little financial support has reached those affected.

CONTENT: Insurance assistance in layman terms would be essential. We shouldn't require a lawyer to understand our insurance policies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need insurance policies explained in simple terms we can understand without hiring lawyers. The language is too complex and confusing for regular people.

CONTENT: If undocumented residents lost their homes and valuables in the fires they 100% deserve assistance just as any other citizen affected by the fires. They are human too with families and contribute to our society.
LLM_SUMMARY: Undocumented residents who lost everything in the fires deserve equal financial assistance as citizens - they're human beings with families who contribute to our community.

CONTENT: Overall out community has been left devastated because of insurers pulling out of plans. There needs to be steps taken to help people rebuild their homes.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurers abandoning coverage has devastated our community. We urgently need support and solutions to help residents rebuild their homes after the wildfire damage.

CONTENT: Remember to make sure these grants are going to local businesses and not scammers/fraudsters.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about grant money distribution - emphasize verifying recipients are legitimate local businesses, not scammers trying to take advantage of wildfire recovery funds.

CONTENT: The City does not have money to give out and is terrible at managing large-scale projects. Before creating a new spending program, focus on cutting the egregious waste that led to our billion-dollar deficit. Let charitable Angelenos and the community charities we support care for people who need help.
LLM_SUMMARY: City should focus on eliminating wasteful spending and deficit rather than creating new aid programs. Let private charities and community organizations handle support for those in need.

CONTENT:
Tenant support is essential.  Undocumented workers have to be a low
Priority unfortunately.  Red tape is a killer anyway yo help with that is vital.  Using an online forum would be a good start for people to use
LLM_SUMMARY: Need better support for tenants and less bureaucracy in getting assistance. An online forum would help people navigate the complex aid process more easily.

CONTENT: We need to provide both immediate and long-term support for individuals and families impacted by the fires. It should be culturally appropriate and include access online and in person.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need culturally-sensitive mental health support, both immediate and ongoing, with flexible access options for fire-affected families. In-person and online services are essential.

CONTENT: Fire victims will not be able to make well-considered decisions about how to move forward if they are traumatized and hurting. We need to make people whole -- mental health services, support groups, somatic therapy, all of this needs to be available at low or no cost to people affected by the fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need accessible, affordable mental health services and support groups to help fire victims heal from trauma before we can expect them to make clear decisions about recovery.

CONTENT: Let the market take care of the buildings! The government is inefficient. Reduce red tape, allow more and denser buildings, give more buildings permit. It is supply-demand! It will decrease prices for everyone. If Houston can do it, so can we!
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with government inefficiency and red tape in rebuilding. Advocates for market-driven solutions, increased density, and easier building permits - similar to Houston's approach - to address housing supply an

CONTENT: People are confused with what a Disaster Recovery Centers is and what a Disaster Assistance Center is. These names need to be vastly different so people know what is what.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by similar-sounding names of emergency centers. The terms "Disaster Recovery Center" and "Disaster Assistance Center" are too confusing - they need clearer, more distinct

CONTENT: YES. YES. YES. Education, fire audits, financial assistance for community immunity.
LLM_SUMMARY: Strongly advocate for community education, fire safety assessments, and financial support to build collective resilience against wildfires.

CONTENT:
People need money to put food on their table and a roof over their head. But any business recovery needs to be cognizant of the needs of the community. It would be a shame if pure market interests are what dictated the kind of business and industries that get created and not the interests of the people who live there.
We don't need anymore extractive business's like mining, real estate speculation, and warehousing but more restorative/regenerative business like food coops, watershed protection , and habitat restoration.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want economic recovery that prioritizes community needs over pure profit - we need restorative businesses like food co-ops and habitat restoration, not extractive industries like mining or real estate speculation.

CONTENT: This right here. What am I investing this time and money in, if the property is then uninsurable?
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated about investing time and money into property that may become uninsurable after wildfire damage, questioning if it's worth the financial risk.

CONTENT:
Renters were the most badly hurt while landlords claimed insurance money.  

More education about need for renters insurance is needed.  Earthquake policy is available from the state for homes (landlords). Loss of use policy should be offered to all renters.
LLM_SUMMARY: Renters suffered most financially while landlords had insurance coverage. We need better education about renter's insurance and state-backed coverage options for renters, similar to earthquake policies.

CONTENT: The government did not do their job yet they require all of us to jump through hoops to get back on the land that they let burn. Fire hydrants didn’t work, why do we need fire sprinklers and the extra permit for that when they wouldn’t have save our homes anyway.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that officials failed to maintain basic fire infrastructure like hydrants, yet now burden us with costly sprinkler requirements and permits to rebuild on our own burned property.

CONTENT: The fact that Fire Aid took so much money and there is no clear path to seeing that money is beyond frustrating. There should be a czar to oversee the funds and community members should have a voice.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by lack of transparency with Fire Aid funding distribution. Want oversight through appointed czar and community input on how recovery money is spent.

CONTENT:
The Army Corps is not funded nor has a mandate to help commercial properties, churches and other non residential properties.  

How can we say our communities are safe if all the commercial district cleanup efforts are handled by commercial property owners.  

There must be support for this, if we want economic recovery to return to these affected communities.  

Phase 2 of the cleanup may be complete by Jan 6th 2026, but if the commercial zones are not cleaned, we will have large areas that will continue to contaminate the rest of the community. 

Why did the State of California not ask FEMA and the Federal Government for assistance in this type of aid?
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that commercial property cleanup falls solely on owners, with no government support. Without aid for business districts, community recovery is incomplete and contamination risks remain high.

CONTENT:
Promoting the PACE-Property Assessed Clean Energy program and  encouraging residents to rebuild with solar roof tiles would be helpful These materials are more fire resistant & widespread deployment would reduce the strain on the grid

If not solar tiles, other roofing materials that are inherently fire resistant and manufactured using a circular process should be used

LA Rises or another PPP should be assigned the task of bundling the orders  for the materials  They could acquire them @ wholesale prices & distribute them @ cost

PACE could lower costs by using blended finance vehicles incorporating grant $ & concessionary capital to fund projects

These discounts along with fed/state incentives & grants would significantly reduce cost
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to rebuild with fire-resistant solar tiles and other sustainable materials, using PACE financing and bulk purchasing programs to make it affordable through grants and incentives.

CONTENT: There are many resources available to address trauma support, but what the public needs right now is tangible rebuilding assistance and services. Providing these will have a lasting positive impact on their mental health in the long term.
LLM_SUMMARY: Mental health resources exist but aren't the priority - we need practical rebuilding help first. Getting our lives back together will do more for our emotional wellbeing than trauma support.

CONTENT: Where to start - a lot of people were being dropped by their insurance, and had a hard time getting other insurance. Some are uninsured or underinsured. People are having a hard time dealing with insurance. People need resources to know what proper fire related insurance coverage should look like and literally a how-to of navigating insurance if you have a full loss, partial loss, smoke.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with insurance companies dropping coverage and confusion around claims. Need clear guidance on proper fire coverage and help navigating the complex insurance process for different types of losses.

CONTENT: Yes! Offer hefty rebates for those who fire harden their homes.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to see more financial incentives and rebates offered to homeowners who take steps to make their properties more fire-resistant.

CONTENT: Make insurance a non-profit industry. Nobody should be profiting off of disasters. Grants should go to ALL homeowners and not just to single family residents or people who didn't pay for insurance. Why limit legal aid just to tenants & undocumented residents? Everybody else needs legal aid to deal with the insurance companies. Plus, we could all use some free financial planning to know how we are going to pay for this perfect storm of  failed infrastructure.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies shouldn't profit from disasters. Financial and legal assistance should be available to everyone affected, not just specific groups. We all need help dealing with insurance and recovery costs.

CONTENT: Homes that survived the fires, but with smoke damage, fall into this gray area for $ coverage from insurance. There is no enforcement arm from the Department of Insurance to make carriers do anything. We have little guidance on knowing when it is safe to return to our homes or our neighborhood. Dept. of Health seems to be the only agency addressing this but again, no enforcement pathway from them to the insurance carriers who more or less want us back in our homes as soon as possible.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies provide no clear guidance on smoke damage coverage and when it's safe to return home. There's no agency enforcement to make them help, leaving us in limbo.

CONTENT: Clean the lots near standing homes first so they can get back to the community!!
LLM_SUMMARY: Prioritize debris cleanup near occupied homes to help residents return to their communities faster.

CONTENT: The plain fact is that NO ONE can afford this. Altadena residents who lost their homes need money, we need grants marked for individuals and families, not agencies/charities (where the donated funds go God knows where). We can't do this alone. My family is in a relatively privileged position where we had insurance and did not lose our jobs, but we don't know if we will be able to afford to rebuild. If we can't afford it, who can? What will our town be if it's just turned over to deep pocketed developers? We need help, and direct financial assistance to residents is the only way to preserve this town.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need direct financial assistance for residents to rebuild - even with insurance, costs are overwhelming. Worried that without grants to individuals, only developers will be able to afford rebuilding in Altadena.

CONTENT: Renters were really left out in the cold. This was such a shame.
LLM_SUMMARY: Felt excluded and neglected as a renter during the disaster response and recovery process.

CONTENT: Eliminate the need for personal property inventory to get one’s entire personal property coverage! Studies show creating that list is the most traumatic part of recovery. We didn’t pay 75% of our insurance premium, why do we only get 75% of our coverage without being forced to do something so traumatic?!
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that insurance requires traumatic itemized inventory of lost belongings to receive full coverage. Want automatic full personal property payout since we paid full premiums.

CONTENT: a reserve fund for rebuilding and restructuring the area.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need a dedicated reserve fund set up specifically for rebuilding and restructuring our fire-damaged areas.

CONTENT: For those who are under insured, the gap to rebuild relative to insurance proceeds is very large. There needs to be some form of assistance for those who are on the CA Fair Plan.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance coverage through CA Fair Plan is inadequate for rebuilding costs. We desperately need additional financial assistance to bridge the massive gap between insurance payouts and actual expenses.

CONTENT: My house is still standing with some minor damage, however, what I want to know is will there ever be grants to upgrade our old homes to code or for features that retard fires for example, fireproof roofs, siding, vents and windows?
LLM_SUMMARY: Seeking information about potential grants to upgrade older homes with fire-resistant features like fireproof roofs and vents, even though my house only sustained minor damage.

CONTENT: Making resources available and how to find them.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need better awareness and access to mental health resources - it's not clear where to find the support services that are available.

CONTENT: Many schools in the surrounding areas have closed down. Consider buying those lots and building affordable housing, like little communities around green spaces for those impacted by fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Suggests converting closed school properties into affordable housing developments with green spaces to help those displaced by wildfires rebuild their communities.

CONTENT: I wish there was a team to help people find apartments. This is another headache!
LLM_SUMMARY: Need dedicated support teams to help fire victims find housing - the apartment search process is overwhelming and frustrating to handle alone.

CONTENT: Support for orgs that are already in this space, access to grants and funding for the continuing of their current missions. The community teams and grief brought on by these fires is overwhelming and needs to be addressed.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need more funding for existing mental health organizations to help communities cope with overwhelming grief and trauma from wildfires. Current support systems are stretched thin.

CONTENT: Must be open and transparent process with competitive bidding.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to ensure economic recovery efforts use transparent, competitive bidding processes rather than closed-door deals.

CONTENT: The entertainment industry, along with a lot of Los Angeles, has lost jobs over the past five years. We should focus on returning these individuals to work in our community whenever possible. While I get we have an outside contractor with expertise in this area, why don't we require them to hire people who have lived in LA for an extended period? Let's support those who have lost their jobs and those who currently reside here. We have a community in the know in the future, then.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should prioritize hiring local LA residents who lost jobs, especially in entertainment, for recovery work - even when using outside contractors. This builds community expertise for future challenges.

CONTENT: An over-abundance of temporary housing will just lien wealthy people’s pockets will making it more difficult for people to acquire permanent housing.
LLM_SUMMARY: Temporary housing solutions mainly benefit wealthy property owners while making it harder for residents to secure permanent homes in the aftermath of the fire.

CONTENT: We've got to take care of our neighbors, especially the ones who had their insurance dropped in the months leading up to the fires with no good alternative. But for anyone who could get insurance and decided not to, knowing they were in a fire zone? They should be on the hook for that bad decision, not the rest of us.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance coverage should help neighbors who lost it through no fault of their own, but those who chose not to insure despite known fire risks shouldn't get community support.

CONTENT: Everyone is financially stressed by this. Being self-employed is tough but especially when the documentation for assistance is based on paperwork that you wouldn't normally have. Adjust the requirements. I can't prove paychecks, or - as requested - prove lack of paychecks (impossible to prove a negative) to get assistance. Or provide a named location for work when I worked from home (and computer doesn't recognize that as a location) SoCal is known for its entrepreneurialism but then focuses on paperwork of employee status.
LLM_SUMMARY: Self-employed people struggle to get wildfire assistance due to documentation requirements designed for traditional employees. Need system that recognizes home-based businesses and alternative proof of income loss.

CONTENT: There are hundreds of charities in the state that support this. There is a shortage of funding for those charities. There is also a shortage of people availing themselves to the services.
LLM_SUMMARY: Plenty of mental health charities exist, but they're underfunded and underutilized. People aren't taking advantage of available services despite the need for support.

CONTENT: Money should be going straight to the people affected by the fires and those in the city that are already housing insecure. Not to small businesses or non-profit middlemen that sap funding for their own gain. Funds should be used to build new affordable housing and fund direct relief to low-income/migrant families. Without affordable and safe housing and stable finances people do not have a chance to obtain employment or start their own businesses.
LLM_SUMMARY: Direct financial aid should go to fire victims and housing-insecure residents, not businesses or nonprofits. Focus on affordable housing and helping low-income families achieve stability.

CONTENT: Broaden the C.C.C. mandate to take in more people, pay them, and help the community with cooperative neighborhood efforts.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to expand the California Conservation Corps to employ more people and support community-based recovery efforts through paid neighborhood cooperation programs.

CONTENT:
These are two distinct policy questions. 
1) Local and state government should lead in the simplest way- Stand aside to allow private sector do it's expertise. 
2) Undocumented residency should not have been asked. Minimal, essential government works regardless of documentation.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should minimize interference and let private sector handle recovery efforts. Immigration status shouldn't be a barrier to receiving essential disaster assistance and support.

CONTENT: Mental health care is over burdened, especially compared to our already burdened health systems. A key to mental health is feeling safe, so mental recovery can’t begin until displaced members of our community have stability.
LLM_SUMMARY: Overwhelmed mental health services can't properly help fire victims. We need stable housing first - people can't begin emotional healing until they feel physically secure in their living situation.

CONTENT: Citizens are intelligent and will be empowered if government steps aside. They will find sources without government marketing.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should let citizens take initiative in finding emergency information rather than controlling the flow of communication. We're capable of finding reliable sources ourselves.

CONTENT: The free market can and will resolve personal and business financial and employment issues. Government should allow general liberty to work naturally.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government intervention isn't needed - let the free market handle business recovery and employment naturally through individual liberty and choice.

CONTENT: Financial assistance needs to be made available for people with standing homes located in or near the burn areas. Our homes suffered extensive damage and/or were covered in toxic ash and debris. Many of us have to pay for expensive environmental testing and remediation out-of-pocket, up to and including replacing dry wall, flooring, a majority of our furniture, clothes, etc., but we are not currently eligible for most of the existing financial assistance.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need financial aid for homes near burn zones that weren't destroyed but suffered toxic ash damage. Can't afford testing and repairs ourselves, but we don't qualify for existing assistance programs.

CONTENT:
An eviction moratorium should go into effect for two months in a county whenever there is natural disaster. Then it can be fine-tuned and continued more specifically after the first 2 months. We had 3 fires going at once, hundreds of thousands getting displaced and evictions were still going on. Ridiculous.

ADUs should be allowed. 

Those of us in apartments are just getting forced out. The ash remediation was just not done and we had no help addressing it. AS tenants we had no ability to handle this ourselves. We were reliant on ownership who were so busy seeing dollar signs for potential rent they just didn't care.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that evictions continued during fires despite mass displacement. As renters, we were powerless to address ash problems while landlords ignored issues, focused only on potential profits.

CONTENT:
We need you to extend the mandate that insurance companies not drop us. We have always paid our premiums and this loss had nothing to do with any of the insureds. But we risk having fully uninsured homes due to the fires. 

People with standing homes need clear guidance on the safety of living amongst and near burned structures. We need financial assistance- so many people not within the burn map boundary are just as displaced and have lost just as much but cannot access aid because of the map boundaries which weren’t drawn to facilitate aid, but that’s how it’s being used.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance coverage and aid access are critical concerns - we need extended insurance mandates and support for all affected residents, not just those within official burn map boundaries.

CONTENT: Individuals and businesses both need grants to support their transition.  After seeing how larger NGO's have managed these funds in the past, I've little to no support for them.  Both the city and the county should have an established list of people and businesses affected by the fires, and should be able to directly reach out to them for that effort.  If not, then that's a failure on their part.  Families and individuals both need businesses in the area to restart their lives, just as businesses needs them.
LLM_SUMMARY: Local government should directly support affected residents and businesses with grants, rather than routing aid through large NGOs. We need both to recover - businesses need customers and residents need services.

CONTENT: We need federal assistance no strings attached just like in every other disaster. We need FEMA!
LLM_SUMMARY: Demanding direct federal disaster aid and FEMA support, without conditions, to help with economic recovery - just like other disaster responses.

CONTENT:
If all of the homes that will be rebuilt are required to have sprinklers and water systems, then the State of California needs to subsidize the added cost of that for rebuilding survivors of the fires.  

Or, waivers need to be given so that the County of LA can allow its communities to rebuild many of the historic homes that were lost, without adding to the burden of the rebuild.  

This can be addressed in many ways, via grants, tax rebates and tax amnesty programs.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to rebuild our historic homes but can't afford mandatory fire safety upgrades. State needs to help with costs through subsidies, waivers, grants, or tax programs.

CONTENT: Ensuring that people with disabilities and seniors be a targeted priority outreach, evacuation, and support population for all natural disasters, such as wild fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must prioritize disabled people and seniors in our disaster planning - from outreach to evacuation to support services during wildfires and other emergencies.

CONTENT:
I am writing to bring attention to a critical gap in the recent executive order issued by Governor Gavin Newsom to expedite rebuilding efforts for residents affected by the current Los Angeles County wildfires. While this order offers a lifeline to those impacted by the Palisades and Eaton Fires, it excludes countless residents who have been struggling to rebuild their lives and homes after previous disasters, such as the Woolsey Fire (2018), Franklin Fire (2024),Mountain Fire(2024) Bobcat Fire (2020), Creek Fire (2017), Sand Fire (2016), La Tuna Fire (2017), and Saddleridge Fire (2019). I am sure there are others that I am missing.


These past fires left thousands of Californians grappling with complex permitting processes.
LLM_SUMMARY: The governor's rebuilding order only helps recent fire victims, ignoring those of us still struggling to rebuild from numerous previous wildfires. We need support for all fire survivors dealing with permits.

CONTENT: Yes, grants to business owners who lost everything is essential as they are an essential part of any community and keep the communities running.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small business grants are crucial - we need them to help owners who lost everything rebuild, since they're vital to keeping our communities functioning.

CONTENT: We have learned, the hard way, that the California insurance industry to irretrievably broken.  Something has to change.  Homeowners insurance is a scam, it is too complicated, no one understands what their policies mean until it is too late, the carriers have inadequate resources to meet a huge crisis like this.  As best I can tell, the carriers are using the money that we paid them in premiums to hire people whose job it is to deny claims.  Some people need to go to jail to wake up this industry.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance system is completely broken - policies are confusing, carriers lack resources, and they use our premiums to hire people just to deny claims. The industry needs major reform.

CONTENT: I would like the government to put funds(or free trees) to replacing the loss of vegetation.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want government funding or free trees to replace vegetation lost in the fire - this would help restore our natural environment.

CONTENT: This will be money wasted on something that people can access through insurance, a plethora of online services/apps.
LLM_SUMMARY: Don't waste money on mental health services - people already have access through insurance and plenty of online options.

CONTENT: Restaurants and small businesses everywhere in LA, not just the burn zones, need help.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses across all of LA need assistance with recovery, not just those directly in wildfire-affected areas.

CONTENT: We need help with insurance claims. State Farm and other insurance companies are blatantly violating the law by issuing blanket denials of many types of claims. We shouldn't all need to hire attorneys to get the insurance companies to honor our policies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are wrongfully denying wildfire claims and forcing us to hire lawyers to get coverage we're entitled to. We need support dealing with these unfair insurance practices.

CONTENT: The insurance market is a disaster. I was told days before the fire that my insurance carrier no longer met the rating requirements of my mortgage lender so I cancelled my insurance policy effective 1/10/25 while my wife and I were getting quotes with other companies. We were going to be underwritten on 1/10/25 but the moratorium after the fires stopped that process and we couldn’t reinstate our previous policy because I cancelled it before the fires but it wouldn’t fulfill my mortgage requirements anyways. After 10 days of no insurance immediately after the fires, we joined the FAIR plan and then got charged an insane amount from our lender for the lapse in insurance coverage. My house didn’t burn and still no word from other insurers!
LLM_SUMMARY: Caught in insurance limbo when switching carriers right before the fire. Couldn't get new coverage due to moratorium, couldn't reinstate old policy. Forced into expensive FAIR plan,

CONTENT: Attention to roadblocks due to Trump's tariffs and deportations. Please provide a safe place for undocumented immigrants who want to help us rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about how immigration policies and tariffs are hindering rebuilding efforts. Want protection for undocumented workers who could help with post-fire reconstruction.

CONTENT: The DRCs are a great resource, but people are overwhelmed and some have trouble getting to them. We need some form of community outreach that potentially goes to people as opposed to requiring them to come to the DRC.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need better outreach beyond just Disaster Recovery Centers - some residents can't easily get there. The centers should come to us instead of making everyone travel there.

CONTENT: We still need tax revenue for essential services like disaster recovery. Raising taxes on worker classes while dropping taxes on business has been proven to hurt the state of CA in the long run. We should not go back.
LLM_SUMMARY: Oppose tax breaks for businesses while raising worker taxes - this hurts California and reduces funds needed for disaster recovery and essential services.

CONTENT: FEMA-like trailers parked in public lots with help nearby
LLM_SUMMARY: Need temporary housing like FEMA trailers in public areas with support services close by.

CONTENT: Debris removal, absolutely.  habitat restoration, that can wait.  Take care of the immediate needs first.
LLM_SUMMARY: Just focus on clearing out the debris right now - that's the urgent priority. Habitat restoration is important but can come later after immediate cleanup needs are handled.

CONTENT: We live in a place that has fire vegetation that needs to have fire in order to replant. The more suppression you do, the worse the consequence. We need to find a way to balance. We need to ensure that housing goes to people and not corporations. We need to put the human back in humanity. No one should have to go bankrupt to sleep somewhere. Remove the double rents for renters affected by the fires. So many people are going to be sick and die from the toxins, we need to be ready.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must balance natural fire cycles while protecting housing affordability. The system needs more humanity - stop double-charging fire-affected renters and prepare for health impacts from toxic exposure.

CONTENT: Provide private adjusters at no cost for people with the holdout companies on personal property. There are not enough reputable affordable adjusters and many are scammers.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need free, trustworthy private adjusters to help deal with difficult insurance companies. Too many scammers out there and legitimate adjusters are hard to find and expensive.

CONTENT: Support that can be utilized online and that is not connected to church organizations feels incredibly necessary. I know people who didn't go to certain outreach/donation locations because of church affiliations. So private counseling options or ones offered by broad-based community organizations would be incredible.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need secular mental health support accessible online. Some people avoid church-affiliated services, so private or community-based counseling would be more helpful and inclusive.

CONTENT: Watch Duty should be publicly funded
LLM_SUMMARY: We need public funding for Watch Duty - it's an essential emergency communication tool that everyone relies on during fires.

CONTENT: I donate my time going around pick up garbage people dump I get paid nothing to me that's fine when kids on the bus come and thank you and when kids are in a safe clean place they can explore it more to me than any amount of money in the world.however it would be great to be able to go to a house that you can call home and shower without worrying about if you have to go.thank you wanda.
LLM_SUMMARY: I volunteer cleaning up trash to keep areas safe for kids, which means more than money. But having stable housing and basic needs would help me continue this community work.

CONTENT: A route to ownership should be available for all renters. Passive income landlord arrangements hurt communities by building cheap, flippable homes, overcrowding lots, building in a manner that isn't sensitive to the needs of families and children. If people owned their own property because they had assistance to purchase we'd all be better off.
LLM_SUMMARY: Rental properties prioritize profit over quality and community needs. If renters had assistance to become homeowners, we'd have better-built homes and stronger neighborhoods that work for families.

CONTENT:
Insurance companies should be held responsible for paying the claims on the policies that they willingly sold to residents in the affected areas.  But we also have to acknowledge that they are beholden to their shareholders and will non-renew or exit CA if they can't make a profit.

It could help to require insurance companies to offer incentives for more fire-resistant construction.  Loosening regulations on the insurance industry is something I'm hesitant to support, but if insurance rates are determined by market forces and not a government commission, it could lead to more companies entering the market which would keep prices in check.  Rates will still be higher, but CA rates are lower than many other states with lower disaster risk.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies must honor policies but need incentives to stay in California. Market-based rates and rewards for fire-resistant construction could help, even if it means higher premiums.

CONTENT: Practice the preparedness training.  Offer monetary incentives to those who participate and practice the preparedness drills.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need incentives to get people to actually participate in emergency preparedness drills and training. That would help our community be better prepared.

CONTENT:
They needs to be one stop
Shop to assist all victims with counseling housing monetary support and job opportunities!!
LLM_SUMMARY: We need a centralized resource center that provides all essential support services - from counseling to housing to jobs - for wildfire victims in one place.

CONTENT: Lets choose the best alternatives in shot AND long run, on the topics we covered specially on the residential-commercial structures AND in the thermal exterior walls coverings. AND work on the grants.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need better options for rebuilding both homes and businesses, especially regarding exterior wall materials. Want help accessing grant funding for reconstruction.

CONTENT: should not be assessed for ADU will assist folks to move back to neighborhood faster and/or could assist housing some of the trades needed to rebuild
LLM_SUMMARY: Want ADU permit fees waived to speed up neighborhood recovery - could help both returning residents and house workers needed for rebuilding efforts.

CONTENT: Please offer generous assistance programs to homeowners/entities who are confirmed to have lost their homes in the fires. I understand that not everyone can be fully compensated (California does not have the $ for that), but maybe a base, across-the-board $25000-30000 compensation check?
LLM_SUMMARY: Need base-level financial compensation for confirmed home losses - suggest $25,000-30,000 per household, even if full compensation isn't possible given California's budget constraints.

CONTENT: Allowing residents to have ADU's on their property would support transition from interim housing (i.e., hotels, temporary rentals, etc.) to their own property whereby they can then manage their own property again and the rebuilding project of their main home.  Transitioning to the main home upon completion.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to build ADUs on our properties so we can live there while rebuilding our main homes, instead of staying in hotels. Would help us manage reconstruction better.

CONTENT: I'm happy to chip in my share of taxes towards rebuilding, especially in Altadena where the residents are not nearly as rich as in the Palisades. But the lion's share of the costs need to be paid by the people who want to live in these dangerous fire zones.
LLM_SUMMARY: Willing to contribute tax money for rebuilding, especially in less wealthy Altadena, but believe primary financial responsibility should fall on those choosing to live in high-risk fire areas.

CONTENT: Please hire local people in Los Angeles for available jobs. The job market is challenging right now, and our tax dollars should be used to help our own community find work while recovering.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want recovery funds to prioritize hiring local LA residents for available jobs, since our community is struggling and our tax dollars should support local employment opportunities.

CONTENT:
Insurance is the main financial driver in recovery. our insurance department, in the last decade has done very little to refine and make the claims process better for citizens.

Making claims more transparent, making policies which make more sense, it isn't rocket science.

90% of folks end up underinsured. Not an accident. A failed system.

When HO3 policies are approved in this state - the Dept should force companies to reveal their claims process and then hold them to it after a disaster.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with insurance system's lack of transparency and reform. Claims process is difficult, policies are confusing, and most people are underinsured. Insurance companies need more oversight and accountability.

CONTENT: People lost their homes, jobs, and were displaced. This country gives MILLIONS OF DOLLARS to other countries. We can use some of that money!
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that government sends millions in foreign aid while fire victims struggle with displacement and losses. That money should help our own communities recover instead.

CONTENT: new code requirements.  go back to the 2010/2012 code requirements.  we can't afford today's requirements and they don't work for this massive rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that current building codes are too expensive for wildfire rebuilding efforts. Want to revert to 2010/2012 codes, as newer requirements are financially burdensome and imp

CONTENT: The entire insurance system in California should be completely reimagined. There must be a system that is accessible, cannot be canceled or reduced based on statewide costs and mandates and is sustainable over time.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance system needs total overhaul to be more accessible, stable and sustainable. Current system isn't working for California wildfire victims with its cancellations and cost issues.

CONTENT: We need help. We got no help on January 7th when our town burned down and we are receiving little support now. Banks should be forced to let everyone in these communities to have a safe out and a forbearance for at least 6 months or a year with the balance going on at the end of the loan term. We have been told by chase bank that we will owe 4 months in May, how is this helpful?! The state needs to speak up on our behalf! We pay so much in taxes and for what??
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by lack of support after losing home. Banks should be required to offer loan forbearance for 6-12 months. Chase demanding four months' payment - it's unfair given

CONTENT: People were impacted differently. It would be good to review the different segments such as renters, smoked out but still standing, and total loss (among others). Each are experiencing different obstacles and the government could be better prepared in future wildfires by understanding the unique concerns of each.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need better understanding of how different groups (renters, smoke-affected, total loss) face unique financial challenges after fires. Would help government provide more targeted assistance in future disasters.

CONTENT: I agree that money should not be spent on the monopolization of internet providers like Spectrum or AT&T. Money should go towards local and government infrastructure where able.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should prioritize funding for local and government infrastructure improvements rather than supporting large internet service providers who already dominate the market.

CONTENT: The government should be helping homeowners that have homes that are standing to retrofit for fire safety. Codes need to be updated with fire safety at the forefront without any red tape.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need government support to retrofit existing homes for fire safety, with streamlined building codes that prioritize fire protection without bureaucratic obstacles.

CONTENT: Small business owners should be able to qualify for grants and local business assistance. Government must be critical of tracking the funds and making sure it's going to the correct hands.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need grants and assistance for small businesses affected by fires, but with strict oversight to ensure funds reach legitimate business owners who truly need help.

CONTENT: We need expertise and help to fire harden our whole community, not just encouraging a few people with the money to do it. Also we can't insure our way out of this. Insurance companies will leave if they don't make a profit and the state can't afford to take their place with the pace and severity of disasters. Education, fire audits, financial assistance. Community immunity.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need community-wide fire hardening, not just individual efforts. Insurance isn't sustainable with increasing disasters. We need education, fire audits, and financial help for collective protection.

CONTENT: Invest in Community Land Trusts. Rebuild affordable housing for all. Protect the most vulnerable. Housing is a human right.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need Community Land Trusts and affordable housing to protect vulnerable residents after fires. Everyone deserves a safe place to live.

CONTENT: Standing aside doesn't seem to be working. These insurance companies don't want to pay out anything and someone has got to twist their arm.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are refusing to pay claims and need to be pressured to provide proper compensation - we can't just stand by and let them avoid payouts.

CONTENT: Connecting residents with resources is clearly a huge gap in the current landscape. Support and safety net services are siloed and difficult to follow and access
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that emergency resources and support services are disconnected and hard to navigate. The system is too fragmented to effectively help residents during crises.

CONTENT: There should not be so many road blocks for a tax paying citizen that has lost EVERYTHING to remove the toxic ash from their property!! Why is the city sitting on so many ROE firms and denying permits for private companies??
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that city bureaucracy and permit denials are preventing me from clearing toxic debris from my property, despite being a taxpayer who lost everything in the fire.

CONTENT: There should be more grants and employment opportunities for people who have been displaced and lost jobs. We are struggling and no one seems to care. The state seems to have moved on.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by lack of financial support and job opportunities after wildfire displacement. Feel abandoned by state government that has moved on while we're still struggling to recover.

CONTENT: This was needed even before the fires! Realtors won't help.
LLM_SUMMARY: Housing assistance and realtor support were problems before the fires and remain a major concern now - we need better systems in place.

CONTENT:
It is especially concerning for people who are of retirement age and/or elderly.

For a company to abandon a customer of so many years like you have been must almost feel like getting caught up in a Ponzi scheme.

We can all understand, the risk/reward profile is not favorable for them and why they want to divest themselves of California policies.

Special consideration should be made for those who have been loyal customers and are past the age where they can start over.
LLM_SUMMARY: Elderly and retired customers deserve special consideration after years of loyalty. At our age, we can't just start over when insurance companies abandon California due to risks.

CONTENT: City (Palisades) & County (Eaton) Fire Websites AND one-stop office for those not on Internet.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need both online and physical locations for fire information - websites aren't enough since not everyone has internet access.

CONTENT: state farm is trying to resist paying out and is claiming that in order to get 50% payout now we have to sign a form that in 36 months they are no longer liable to pay more. they also are requiring a list of all private property even if house is complete loss.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance company forcing us to sign away future claims to get partial payout now, and demanding detailed property lists despite total home loss. They're making this unnecessarily difficult.

CONTENT: Legal aid to help those affected navigate the overly complex world of insurance and permits for building is incredibly important and necessary to support community and prevent investors from controlling the market.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need legal support to deal with complex insurance claims and building permits - this helps our community rebuild and keeps predatory investors from taking over.

CONTENT: My own grandmother lost her home in the Palisades Fire, so this is hard to say. But if people decide to rebuild in the exact spot their house burned down, the financial risk of repeat fire should should be borne by communities who rebuild in high risk areas. Skyrocketing insurance rates should not be distributed throughout the state to areas that have very low risk of wildfire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance costs for rebuilding in high-risk fire zones should be shouldered by those communities, not spread across low-risk areas. It's personal - my grandmother lost her home.

CONTENT: More incentives for businesses to come back. We are still destitute in Paradise CA
LLM_SUMMARY: Desperately need incentives to attract businesses back to our area. Our community remains economically devastated, similar to what happened in Paradise, California.

CONTENT: Coordinate better with the home owners
LLM_SUMMARY: Need better coordination between officials and homeowners during debris cleanup efforts.

CONTENT: Test the soil for every property. Find the money to do this. Not everyone can afford soil testing for contaminants, but this will affect everyone’s health long term. Plus it will affect the ground water as contaminants seep into the soil.
LLM_SUMMARY: Soil testing for contaminants is crucial but expensive. We need funding to test all affected properties since contamination threatens everyone's long-term health and groundwater quality.

CONTENT: We used FEMA debris remove, but they didn't take away the damaged driveway or damaged walkway or burned trees and we are going to spend our money to finalize the debris removal.  Insurance company's coverage is so limited for Coverage B.  I feel this is not right.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that FEMA debris removal excluded damaged driveways, walkways, and burned trees. Having to pay out-of-pocket for remaining cleanup due to limited insurance coverage under Coverage B

CONTENT: We need our small businesses to be made whole.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses must receive full compensation and support to recover from wildfire losses.

CONTENT: Fireaid gathered so much money, but much less individual contribution.  They gave organization, but not individual.  We lost our home and we have 2 children and one is a special need...we are the one suffering mentally, financially and physically.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that FireAid collected substantial funds but prioritized organizations over individual families like mine. As parents of a special needs child who lost our home, we're struggling on multiple levels.

CONTENT: Better coordination is needed between insurance companies and state agencies, so that residents of threatened areas can receive $ for temporary housing BEFORE evacuation is mandatory and can continue to receive it until essential services are restored to their homes. Right now, most people only receive assistance as long as evacuation is mandatory and only until the order is lifted, regardless of whether power, water and other essential services have been restored.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance and government agencies need to provide temporary housing funds before mandatory evacuations and continue support until homes have essential services restored, not just during official evacuation periods.

CONTENT: We are ONE CA and All utility caused wildfire victims need to be treated equally.
LLM_SUMMARY: Demanding equal treatment for all California wildfire victims affected by utility-caused fires, regardless of location or specific incident.

CONTENT:
We need direct help with rebuilding. Seems like only non profits are getting any money, but people who actually need help are being left out. 

LA county needs to address why emergency personnel were told to stand down during the fires. No help with putting out fires nor with helping to evacuate people from their homes. emergency personnel were on the side watching Altadena burn.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that recovery funds go to nonprofits instead of impacted residents. Concerned about emergency response - personnel watched Altadena burn without helping with firefighting or evacuations.

CONTENT: One massive issue we had here in Northern CA is that insurance coverage for temporary housing only kicks in when the evacuation order is mandatory. This means that people with fewer financial resources (including seniors) are forced to wait until the very last minute to leave--putting themselves in great danger and making the situation more difficult and dangerous for first responders, as well. And because lodging coverage stops as soon as evac orders are lifted, people here were forced to return to unsafe situations, with no running water, no power and no internet (at a time when kids were still doing remote learning due to COVID). The state needs to be aware of this issue and work with insurance providers to resolve it.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance only covers temporary housing during mandatory evacuations, forcing low-income residents and seniors to delay leaving until the last minute. This puts lives at risk and rushes people back to unsafe conditions.

CONTENT: About half of all residents are renters and they are disproportionally affected by disasters and are financially burdened by a system that is designed to extract as much money as possible out of them. Many pay more than 50% of their income just in housing alone. With horrendous policies coming from the federal government, undocumented residents are unfairly targeted and exploited even more than other residents. We should be focusing efforts on equity, social and environmental justice to ensure those who are on the verge of homelessness don't end up being unhoused. We need to promote more low-income and no-income housing in every neighborhood.
LLM_SUMMARY: Renters face unfair financial burdens during disasters, especially undocumented residents. The system exploits vulnerable people who already struggle with housing costs. We need more affordable housing and equitable

CONTENT: Need a solid plan for rebuilding. If the people are there business are more likely to reopen. Again low interest rates for business as well as homeowners.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want clear rebuilding strategy to bring people back to the area, which will help businesses reopen. Low-interest loans needed for both businesses and homeowners.

CONTENT: CA get it together! Why is it always a surprise when a fire takes place? CA government should be required to meet preventative FIRE measures and I am not referring to decades to develop.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fed up with CA's reactive approach to fires. Government needs to implement immediate preventative measures instead of dragging out planning for years.

CONTENT: Issues if the residents weren't insured/ underinsured. Making sure they receive timely support for rebuilding/ limited redtape. CA may have more strict building codes based on earthquake/ fire concerns. Ensuring the costs/ codes to build appropriately are still accessible based on the incomes/ avoiding exploitation from real estate corporate entities (Blackrock).
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about underinsured residents getting timely rebuilding support without excessive bureaucracy. Worried that strict building codes and corporate exploitation could make reconstruction unaffordable for many homeowners.

CONTENT: this isn't just for govt officials, it should be baked into building code, zoning, and planning. but not in the typical, gross, broad stroke kinda stupid way the county usually does everything, but in a really smart, focused, well considered way.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need smarter, more targeted wildfire prevention built into local building codes and planning - not the county's usual broad, ineffective approach to regulations.

CONTENT: people should absolutely be allowed to live on their properties while they rebuild. it's crazy to be paying a mortgage on a property that you can't live on while you figure out how to rebuild your home. there should also be clear public information about what is permittable in the area and the county should be educated about it and required to expedite it. they often give wrong information. last, permitting fees for building new ADU (that weren't there before the fire) should be permanently waived. the cost of permits is often 50% of the total ADU budget.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with paying mortgage while unable to live on property during rebuild. Want clear permitting info, faster processing, and waived ADU permit fees since they're so expensive.

CONTENT: Need to test soil before rebuilding
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about soil safety and contamination before reconstruction can begin.

CONTENT: Don't need tax relief as much as streamlining approvals to get businesses back open, and densifying neighborhoods to make small businesses more profitable. Best way to assist local businesses is to get them back open again and as easily accessible as possible.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need faster business reopening approvals and denser neighborhoods to help small businesses recover and thrive, rather than just tax relief. Getting businesses operational again is the priority.

CONTENT: Listen. To. The. Insurance. Companies. When a business is reliant on predicting a property's risk of fire damage, and they charge exorbitantly to insure it (or don't insure it AT ALL), people should not be permitted to build housing there. Period.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies' risk assessments should determine where housing is allowed. If they won't insure or charge extreme rates due to fire risk, that's a clear sign building shouldn't be permitted.

CONTENT: Think inline with holding agencies accountable extends to after wildfires. We are seeing little to no approvals for housing reconstruction or repair. Beaucratic lallygagging post-crisis, when people have lost their homes and possessions, is entirely unacceptable
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by slow bureaucratic response after the fire. Agencies need to be held accountable for delays in housing reconstruction approvals when people have already lost everything.

CONTENT:
The government's attacking insurance, as someone from the southeast US, is strange. Governmental agencies let the city of LA develop and sprawl into high fire-risk areas.
