Insurance companies, like when people build beachfront homes in hurricane country, jacked up the insurance rates. When an insurance company says an area is dangerous, believe them.

Forcing other taxpayers to supplement a "wood home in a tinderbox" is ludicrous. Saying it's the homeowners' fault for having a home in a tinderbox is likewise insane; they aren't fire experts.

The blame for the Palisades fire's destruction lays at the feet of the negligent county, city, and state level officials who allowed people to build/buy homes and root their lives in the line of fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government officials are responsible for letting development occur in high-risk fire zones, then blaming insurance companies and homeowners when rates spike. We shouldn't have been allowed to build here.

CONTENT: I believe people should be allowed to live onsite in trailers while they rebuild for practicality reasons
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to stay in trailers on our property during rebuilding - it's just more practical than being displaced somewhere else while trying to manage construction.

CONTENT: It seems like a misnomer and false lead to say that wildfire, rather than wildfire risk reduction, can be prevented in the current way we build infrastructure, where land uses are sited, or how humans behave. Effective approaches such as managed retreat and undergrounding of electrical infrastructure are either too costly, too politically charged, or other "too" that prevents long-term effective change. It takes some strong political will along with a growth plan (with growth limits) to say that some areas, like repeated burn communities, are off limits to development.
LLM_SUMMARY: We can't truly prevent wildfires without addressing development in high-risk areas and making costly infrastructure changes. Political will is needed to limit growth in repeatedly burned communities.

CONTENT: This is a unique opportunity to plan infrastructure in an older part of the city. Might as well do it properly since we have to do it. In addition to the power lines being buried, I'm wondering what thought is being given to runoff to prevent flooding, mudslides, etc. I know there are some sidewalk/street materials that allow water to percolate through them (Tree People would be a great resource) and rain water catchment systems under landscaping (like at Santa Monica College).
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to rebuild infrastructure smartly since we have to do it anyway. Beyond burying power lines, we need permeable surfaces and water management systems to prevent flooding and mudslides.

CONTENT: Engage all fire victims so they can help create their community. Offer support, listen. Allow them to build a temporary shelter if they want or need to live on their property while rebuilding.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need more community engagement and emotional support for fire victims. Want flexibility to stay on our property during rebuilding, even in temporary shelter. Important to feel heard.

CONTENT: ADUs may allow homeowners to recover an economic loss, but more residents will add to the evacuation problem.   It is not practical or safe to keep adding residence to a community that only has two roads in and out.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned that allowing ADUs for economic recovery will worsen evacuation challenges in our area, which already has limited road access for the existing population.

CONTENT: Bury all the utility lines!
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to put utility lines underground to prevent future fire risks and outages.

CONTENT: Rebuilding is important - and should be required to reflect the changed nature of our environment and be as resilient as possible
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to rebuild, but must ensure new construction meets higher standards for fire resilience to match our changing environmental conditions.

CONTENT: agree about the haste. I also think city leaders are being motivated significantly by a desire to get things cleared for hosting the LA Olympics. We must not let that desire to be 'ready for  2028' mean that we miss this opportunity to  regenerate and build a healthy city for our children.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned that Olympic preparations are rushing debris removal and recovery efforts. We shouldn't sacrifice long-term environmental regeneration and our children's future just to meet 2028 deadlines.

CONTENT:
Regarding insurance claims and premiums, no one should have any issues at all with insurance claims. Insurance companies should be lowering cost and premiums vs. raising them. When it's a known fact that insurance companies have more money than banks and are collecting around the clock; I find it hard to believe that they are somehow living paycheck to paycheck. Besides, this is the business they chose. If insurance companies want to raise cost, they should be required to provide something more like free legal assistance for tenants and undocumented immigrants. 

New requirements before permitting building of homes and buildings, fire prevention methods and materials required before issuing any permits. City, County, and State level.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should lower premiums instead of raising them since they're extremely profitable. They should provide free legal help to tenants and immigrants, while requiring better fire prevention in new construction.

CONTENT: Related to the future of water systems as similarly described above - all water systems in fire prone areas should be re-engineered including hydrants and water distribution lines.  Specifically for the protection of homes; all homes should be equipped with roof type sprinkler systems that can be activated to water down roofs and property. Such a system may have prevented the extent of fire damage inflicted. To put that in perspective, no one should ever have to water down their house with a garden hose to prevent a fire from burning it down.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need better water infrastructure in fire-prone areas, including upgraded hydrants and mandatory roof sprinkler systems. Using garden hoses to protect homes from wildfires is unacceptable.

CONTENT: It would be nice to have the power lines installed underground.  What I've heard is the heavy equipment needed for the debris removal is going to leave the streets and sidewalks damaged.  There should be an effort to rebuild the roads and sidewalks.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want power lines moved underground. Concerned about heavy equipment damaging streets during debris removal. Need commitment to repair roads and sidewalks afterward.

CONTENT: Please simplify all of this. I never wanted to figure out how to build a home. This needs to be overhauled for all the people you failed. Waive all the fees. Why are we paying you more? What does it go towards? Fire protection lol?? (Sorry to be spicy, but dude.)
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by complex rebuilding process and fees. Don't understand why we must pay more to the same system that failed to protect us from fire damage.

CONTENT: In the Palisades having a staging area for lumber and supplies, possibly having a temporary cement factory etc giving the amount of materials that will be needed.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need designated staging areas in Palisades for construction materials and supplies to support rebuilding efforts, including possibly setting up temporary material production facilities.

CONTENT:
Be sure to underground power.
Be sure to map out speed bumps through out all the communities at the time of redoing all the streets.
Be sure the city does they part in removing all the burnt trees and to trim the remaining ones since they have not done that in years.
Start programs to train high school graduates and others to be plumbers, electricians etc.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need underground power lines, better street planning, proper tree maintenance by the city, and vocational training programs to build skilled workforce for infrastructure repairs.

CONTENT: In times of emergency, we often fall back on the same inefficient routines simply because they’re familiar. But crises should push us to rethink—not repeat—our processes. This is the moment to evaluate, and rebuild smarter on all levels in LA. By focusing on the shortest path to effective solutions, we can not only respond faster but also come out stronger. Let’s not waste this tragedy by defaulting to same ole same ole; now is the time to evolve and emerge better. Change our government inefficiencies, hire locals and build better. I love LA!
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to use this crisis to rethink and improve our emergency response systems, not just repeat old routines. Let's hire locally and create more efficient processes.

CONTENT: Underground utilities without delay
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to move power lines underground immediately to prevent future fire risks.

CONTENT: Power lines should be below ground
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are needed to prevent future fires and outages.

CONTENT: Yes, more bike lanes and pedestrian infrastructure could act as a natural fire break.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want more bike lanes and walking paths - they could serve double duty as firebreaks to help protect our community.

CONTENT: Expedited permitting time and the cost of permits for rebuilds should be waived - these rebuilds are not being done by choice but by necessity and a result of government not being prepared and letting an entire community burn to the ground overnight.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that rebuilding permits are costly and slow after losing home to fire. Government should waive fees and speed up process since this wasn't our choice but their failure.

CONTENT:
County or city building processes have to be streamlined and charges kept manageable
For people
To recover successfully.  Plans and permits can’t be mired in municipal offices for undue amounts of time.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by slow municipal processes - building permits and plans need to be expedited and fees kept reasonable so fire victims can rebuild their homes without excessive delays.

CONTENT: There should be zoning, codes, permitting and other policies that limit or eliminate building in fire-prone areas unless customers are willing to pay for the materials to be fire resilient and willing to forego the protection from standard services in the case of an emergency.
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't allow building in fire-prone areas unless homeowners use fire-resistant materials and accept they may not get emergency services during disasters.

CONTENT: Local residential electric lines should never have been above ground.  They should have been below ground from the start.  The literature on this is 50 years old.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines would have prevented outages and fire risk. Above-ground lines were a poor choice from the beginning, despite decades of research showing better alternatives.

CONTENT: Ensure rebuilt infrastructure is climate resilient, including underground power lines, upgrading to support full electrification of buildings and battery storage, and micrograms. Make transportation infrastructure prioritize active forms of mobility like walking, cycling and public transit. Utilize green and natural infrastructure that helps manage stormwater, provide shade and heat resilience, and health benefits.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want rebuilt infrastructure to be climate-resilient with underground power lines, battery storage, and microgrids. Prioritize green solutions for transportation, stormwater management, and heat protection.

CONTENT: Both our electric systems and water systems should make more use of local supplies -- micro-grids for the electric system and water capture and grey water for the water systems.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need more localized utility systems - micro-grids for electricity and local water capture/grey water systems - rather than relying on large centralized infrastructure.

CONTENT: Permit process needs to expedited without delay and costs need to be minimal for residents to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with slow rebuilding process - want expedited permits and reduced costs to help residents rebuild their homes more quickly after the fire.

CONTENT: Rebuild homes that are climate resilient, all electric, and are certified green homes and buildings. Ensure communities are replanned and redesigned to prioritize equity in housing everyone; providing infrastructure that focuses on enabling public transit, cycling, and walking; ensuring access to parks, green space, urban forestry and tree canopy; and local business opportunities that supports the clean economy.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to rebuild better with climate-resilient, green-certified homes and redesign communities to prioritize equity, sustainable transportation, green spaces, and clean economy business opportunities.

CONTENT: Needless to say, this is essential and non-negotiable, especially in the face of worsening climate conditions.  We need to be as preventive as possible going forward, facing the reality of climate change currently, and planning for more constrained and catastrophic climate futures.  We need to make choices about where NOT to rebuild.  We need to have fire departments that are fully funded and trained for emergencies.  This is a global emergency, and we need to treat it as such and plan for it as such.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must prioritize prevention given climate change realities. Need fully funded fire departments, smarter rebuilding decisions, and emergency preparedness. This is a global crisis requiring serious planning.

CONTENT: Don’t just throw this on the residents trying to rebuild manage the land that is prone to fire better
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that burden falls on residents. Want better land management practices from authorities to prevent fires, rather than focusing solely on homeowner responsibilities.

CONTENT: Bury the utilities and mandate solar
LLM_SUMMARY: We need underground power lines and required solar panels to prevent future fire risks.

CONTENT: Communities in WUI (wildland urban interface) environments should have high-powered sprinkler systems installed along their perimeters and/or throughout the community to give it extra protection in advance of a fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need high-powered sprinkler systems installed around and within WUI communities to provide better protection before fires hit. This preventive measure could save our neighborhoods.

CONTENT: Budget constraints should not impact whether or not these mitigations are completed.
LLM_SUMMARY: Prevention measures and safety mitigations must be fully funded and implemented, regardless of budget limitations. This can't be something we cut corners on.

CONTENT: We need to better manage the brush lands, but they evolved to burn, so we also have ensure that our built environment can live with fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must balance natural fire cycles with protecting development through both brush management and fire-resistant infrastructure. Nature will burn, so we need to adapt our communities.

CONTENT: County needs to expedite all permits for building houses.  We absolutely can't afford to rent and pay mortgage for as long as this is going to take so don't want permits delayed for months costing us tens of thousands of dollars we don't have to waste.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by dual housing costs while waiting to rebuild. County must speed up permit process - delays are costing us money we can't afford to waste on temporary housing.

CONTENT: Underground power lines are a necessity
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are essential to prevent future fire disasters.

CONTENT: Get out of the way, stop wasting our time and money, and let Los Angeles prosper.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fed up with bureaucratic obstacles slowing down recovery efforts - just want efficient action so LA can move forward and thrive again.

CONTENT: Power lines should be UNDERGROUND
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are essential - this needs to happen to prevent future fires.

CONTENT: Rebuilding to specific “like-for-like “ criteria that the Assessor will agree with and that passes Building & Safety and other code checks will cut the time to rebuild way down by clarifying the path to a design and ultimately a rebuild that will serve homeowners affected. I want a chance to rebuild. I need help getting that information straightened out and available NOW!
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by complex rebuilding requirements. Want clear "like-for-like" criteria from Assessor and Building & Safety to speed up reconstruction process. Need this information immediately to start rebuilding

CONTENT: Power lines under ground please
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are needed to prevent future fire risks.

CONTENT: Failing to properly test and remediate now will lead to serious health consequences in the future and could also negatively impact property values. This process must be prioritized, but it cannot delay the rebuilding timeline.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about health risks and property values if debris testing and cleanup isn't done right. Want thorough remediation but without slowing down rebuilding efforts.

CONTENT: Underground the power lines; Water system needs to be updated. More plans for saving water for times of drought. Sidewalks would be great in Altadena.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need major infrastructure upgrades - underground power lines, better water systems for drought, and basic amenities like sidewalks in our community.

CONTENT: We need climate resilient landscaping, native plants, trees that don’t burn like oaks, remove palms and eucalyptus. We need real brush clearance in high risk places next to houses. We need to remove non native brush. We need revised building codes. I have been hardening my house with roof sprinklers, 1/8 inch wire mesh covering all vents, brush clearance, etc.
LLM_SUMMARY: I'm focused on making our community fire-resistant through native landscaping, removing hazardous vegetation, and upgrading homes with protective features like mesh-covered vents and sprinklers.

CONTENT: Power lines are so vulnerable.  How is it that, at least in the hillside areas with very high fire risk, we still have above-ground power lines?  Obviously the water delivery system is antiquated and unreliable for a major fire such as this.  This will happen again (and again) and when the earthquake comes, this entire city will be on its knees.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that high-risk hillside areas still rely on vulnerable above-ground power lines and outdated water systems. These infrastructure weaknesses will keep causing problems during fires and earthquakes.

CONTENT: Altadena needs underground power lines to protect the rebuilt community from future disasters. Water systems need to be improved to be able to handle every rebuild requiring sprinklers!  Sidewalks, bike lanes, and fiber internet are investments that can easily implemented now that will improve the quality of life for residents for decades.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need underground power lines and upgraded water systems to support rebuilding. While we're at it, let's add sidewalks, bike lanes, and fiber internet for long-term community benefits.

CONTENT: With this economic obsolescence, we need to hire train engineers and environmentalists to make sure it’s safe and secure for rebuild!! Also monthly soil test to ensure residents are properly protected from any possible contamination.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about safety during rebuilding - we need expert engineers and environmentalists to oversee debris removal and conduct regular soil testing to protect residents from contamination.

CONTENT:
Admittedly don't know enough here. Eaton fire started well outside of normal pedestrian infrastructure.  Only thing I can add here is that given that good fraction of the community has to start from scratch, now is a good time to revisit infra related issues such as underground power and better broadband.

The water utilities I have less info on. They seem to have bounced back pretty quickly but obviously lessons learned from this one should be considered.
LLM_SUMMARY: Since we're rebuilding from scratch, it's a perfect opportunity to improve infrastructure like underground power lines and better broadband. Water utilities recovered quickly, but we should learn from this experience.

CONTENT: It's something to look at but it should be behind rebuilding.
LLM_SUMMARY: Mental health support is important but shouldn't be prioritized over physical rebuilding efforts - that needs to come first.

CONTENT: Abolish the Coastal Commission, accelerate permitting for new building, remove government red tape, offer incentives for new builds
LLM_SUMMARY: Fed up with slow rebuilding process due to excessive regulations. Want Coastal Commission eliminated, faster permits, reduced bureaucracy, and incentives to encourage new construction.

CONTENT: Housing has been incredibly tough, expensive, and hard to find. Then the fires happened. Now we need housing more than ever and we need housing here so people don’t have to move away and they can still stay in the general area while trying to pick up where they left off. People need to rebuild and live in their homes and sell to families, not corporations. We need to remove barriers to rebuild but also ensure that people don’t get ripped off by bad contractors and that the new houses they build are safe, strong, and resilient, and some properties that were immediately above Eaton Canyon should consider not rebuilding because it is just a matter of time.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need affordable local housing so fire victims can stay in the area while rebuilding. Want homes sold to families, not corporations. Some properties near Eaton Canyon too risky to rebuild.

CONTENT: should not waste time and money widening roads, not necessary and not feasible; could put power lines underground if this does not delay construction and if it is feasible; need to work 24/7 to meet building demands and lesson congestion
LLM_SUMMARY: Prioritize 24/7 construction to meet demands and reduce congestion. Road widening is wasteful and impractical. Consider underground power lines only if it's feasible without causing

CONTENT: REALLY speed up the approval process. Also, strongly encourage bungalow courts for multi-family housing-- basically groupings of 4 to 10 ADU-type buildings. They suit the Alta/Pasadena aesthetic, are affordable, are much better looking than flat, generic boxes, and will help bring renters to our community.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want faster building approvals and support for bungalow court-style developments - they're affordable, match local aesthetics, and would help bring more renters to our area.

CONTENT: We need to be proactive and clear brush/trash, bring back the brush eating goats and allow those that owe parking tickets to clean the freeways, like they used to. It should be illegal to start fires on the streets, public parks/forests (unless allowed to BBQ). Taxpayers should NOT be paying for the infrastructure upgrades of for profit electrical companies. When new communities are built, require power lines to be underground or have other safety measures in place that will prevent fires. Electrical companies can also educated the public and if they see something off with a powerline to say something.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need proactive brush clearing, stricter fire regulations, and underground power lines in new developments. Utility companies should fund their own infrastructure and educate the public about fire prevention.

CONTENT: Strickter code requirements in regards to materials should be enforced.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building codes need to be tougher and better enforced, especially for construction materials.

CONTENT: Remove all bottlenecks. I am sure there were some lessons learned here.
LLM_SUMMARY: Streamline the rebuilding process by eliminating administrative barriers and applying lessons learned from past experiences.

CONTENT: As above, all permitting and zoning needs to be updated aligned with current housing, transportation and bike-pedestrian-friendly construction.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to modernize all permitting and zoning regulations to better align with current housing needs and support more sustainable transportation infrastructure.

CONTENT: For those neighborhoods zoned as "very high fire risk", the city and/or utilities needs to also be held accountable on underground transmission lines, along with reviewing all city trees which are highly flammable and replace them (regardless if tress are "protected" or not), along with ensuring overgrown vegetation are trimmed back on our hillsides/mountain areas close to residents.
LLM_SUMMARY: City and utilities must take responsibility by undergrounding power lines, removing hazardous trees regardless of protected status, and managing overgrown vegetation near homes in high-risk fire zones.

CONTENT: I think this will take many generations. It's a long term strategy, not a short term one.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to understand this is a long-term challenge that will span generations - there's no quick fix for building resilience.

CONTENT: Businesses are critical to providing goods to the community. Without 3rd places, a community cannot thrive. Also, set backs should be increased like after the Paradise fire, reduces spread rate of fires AND entices fire insurance companies to return.
LLM_SUMMARY: Local businesses are vital for community wellbeing, but we need larger setbacks like Paradise implemented to reduce fire spread and bring back insurance companies.

CONTENT: That would be the insurance market telling you that the place you're living is dangerous and likely to burn down again. You're right that we should be able to find out before trying to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are signaling fire risk through their policies. We need better transparency about these risks before investing in rebuilding efforts.

CONTENT: We need more housing not less. We should pull out all the stops to build back with more units not less.
LLM_SUMMARY: Strongly advocate for increasing housing density during rebuilding efforts, rather than simply replacing what was lost in the fire.

CONTENT: If anything, this is an opportunity to apply lessons learned from here and other cities around the world and to modernize infrastructure.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should use this as a chance to learn from other cities' experiences and upgrade our infrastructure with modern solutions.

CONTENT:
We know from scientific experts that the buildings were the fuel for the fire NOT the trees and bushes. Create pocket parks on lots that homeowners wish to sell. These parks will provide fuel breaks for future fires and also enhance the neighborhoods. 
Plant oak trees!! Oaks catch flying embers and can protect structures.
Do NOT add housing density to this area. It is a high fire zone and cannot carry the density nor can the infrastructure.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about fire safety, suggesting pocket parks as fuel breaks and planting oak trees to catch embers. Against increased housing density in high-risk areas due to infrastructure limitations.

CONTENT: Let the market take care of the buildings! The government is inefficient. Reduce red tape, allow more and denser buildings, give more buildings permit. It is supply-demand! It will decrease prices for everyone. If Houston can do it, so can we!
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with government inefficiency and red tape in rebuilding. Advocates for market-driven solutions, reduced regulations, and increased density permits - similar to Houston's approach - to address housing supply issues

CONTENT: Have you seen what's happening with rent lately? Of course we need more housing. Otherwise rent is going to keep going up up up. We've got to build somewhere, and since homeowners have been opposing density in safer areas for decades, communities grew outwards instead. That's how we ended up with so many people in fire zones like Altadena and the Palisades. But yeah, we've got to have better sewer, road, power, and water planning too.
LLM_SUMMARY: Housing shortages pushed development into fire-prone areas. While we need more housing to control rent costs, it must come with proper infrastructure planning for utilities and services.

CONTENT: One area of enormous opportunity, with relevance to building codes, zoning, insurance and more, is seeking to systematically leverage the incredibly exciting advancements happening in the material sciences.  The news and announcement webpages of most (if not all) of our major goverment research labs, and many, many of our major research universities, are regularly peppered with summaries of material developments or breakthroughs in these fields having potential application to the built environment; whether for durability, for ability to sequester carbon, for ability to withstand high temperatures (i.e., fire resistent).  These pages often end with contact information to learn more and/or seek technology licensing.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should leverage new materials science breakthroughs from research labs and universities to improve building codes and fire resistance. There's so much untapped potential in these innovations.

CONTENT: The agencies Hazard planning as part of the General plans are a joke. Bike lanes and roadway reductions with no plan to evacuate. Most say shelter in place.  Overbuilding and no plan to evacuate.  Big tragedy and then the problem is ignored.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that hazard planning prioritizes bike lanes over evacuation routes. Concerned about overdevelopment without adequate emergency exit plans, while officials default to "shelter in place" recommendations.

CONTENT:
Underground ALL power lines. 
Funnel rain water to your underground cisterns for fire fighting and city landscaping. Each home being rebuilt could also add an underground cistern that would fill with rain water and act as a source for landscaping and fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to put power lines underground and create water storage systems - both citywide and at individual homes - to collect rainwater for firefighting and irrigation purposes.

CONTENT:
Allow to build in an Off the Grid type of solar or wind power supply for a residential 
That way in case of emergency or heavy winds power can be shutdown without affecting a lot of customer.
Edison doesn't allow to be off the grid in the city that my understanding?
Allows us to build of the grid with a hybrid system not to depends so much on the grid.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to install off-grid solar/wind power systems at home for backup during emergencies, but Edison restricts this. A hybrid system would reduce grid dependence during outages.

CONTENT: The government did not do their job yet they require all of us to jump through hoops to get back on the land that they let burn. Fire hydrants didn’t work, why do we need fire sprinklers and the extra permit for that when they wouldn’t have save our homes anyway.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that officials failed to maintain basic fire infrastructure like hydrants, yet now burden us with costly permits and sprinkler requirements to rebuild on our own property after the fire.

CONTENT: The county will be the largest barrier to rebuilding and they need to be honest with the people. It will be their fault people sell.
LLM_SUMMARY: County bureaucracy will be the biggest obstacle to rebuilding, and their lack of transparency will force people to give up and sell their properties.

CONTENT:
One area where resources should be consolidated is the tax incentives, grants and rebates available from federal, State & local government entities for sustainability measures in rebuilding.  

This is an important part of a multi-layered cost reduction strategy that will make sustainable rebuilding accessible to all property owners.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need better coordination of government tax incentives and rebates for sustainable rebuilding. Having these resources scattered across different levels makes it harder for property owners to access them.

CONTENT: Restrict subdivisions in very high and high fire zones.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to stop allowing new housing developments in high-risk fire areas to prevent future disasters.

CONTENT: Fire prevention should be at its core built into the home thru various construction strategies such as air-tight construction, less flammable building materials and the removal of flammable gas line hookups
LLM_SUMMARY: Building codes need to prioritize fire-resistant construction methods, including airtight designs, non-flammable materials, and elimination of gas lines to prevent home fires.

CONTENT: Code changes must be adopted and enforced to reduce the future conflagrations that will otherwise happen. Get home owners and community groups to take on what should happen to make homes safer from the threat of fire. Listen to them, work with them. Present the policies and codes that will make a difference AND SELL THEM TO THE VOTERS!
LLM_SUMMARY: We need stronger building codes to prevent future fires, but officials must collaborate with homeowners and community groups to develop and gain support for these safety measures.

CONTENT: We can't rebuild in the same old fashion, with the same materials and the same landscaping.  It is possible to design a house that is resistant to fires - there was at least one good example in the Palisades that demonstrated how thoughtful adaptation can save a home.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to rethink how we rebuild, using fire-resistant designs and materials. One house in the Palisades proved that smart adaptation works - it's the way forward.

CONTENT: In fire prone areas, the public needs to not only have regular reminders they live IN a high-hazard area, but they should be required to participate in annual or semi-annual exercises with emergency management, first responders, etc.  CERT exists for this effort.  Frankly, I was surprised and dismayed that there aren't any future rebuilding requirements to use fire-resistant technologies or building materials or landscaping.  Sounded to me like all of that is waived to expedite the rebuilding/recovery process; meaning, lessons NOT learned.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need mandatory emergency response drills and CERT participation in fire-prone areas. It's concerning that rebuilding requirements don't enforce fire-resistant materials - we're not learning from these disasters.

CONTENT: Bury the power lines. DO NOT make the citizens pay for it.
LLM_SUMMARY: Demanding that power lines be buried underground but opposing passing those costs onto residents through fees or rate increases.

CONTENT: This is the perfect opportunity to bury all power lines. The cost of this should be shouldered by the utility companies and not by increasing fees to the consumer.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want utility companies to take responsibility and bury power lines while rebuilding, but don't pass those costs onto residents through higher rates.

CONTENT: Clean the lots near standing homes first so they can get back to the community!!
LLM_SUMMARY: Prioritize clearing debris from lots next to surviving homes to help residents return to their community faster.

CONTENT: My house is still standing with some minor damage, however, what I want to know is will there ever be grants to upgrade our old homes to code or for features that retard fires for example, fireproof roofs, siding, vents and windows?
LLM_SUMMARY: Seeking information about potential grants to retrofit my home with fire-resistant features like fireproof roofs and vents, even though my house only sustained minor damage.

CONTENT: Require SCE to bury ALL power lines. Make utilities publicly owned.
LLM_SUMMARY: Strongly advocate for underground power lines and public ownership of utilities to prevent future fire risks and service disruptions.

CONTENT: Bury the power lines… seems like fires often start with exposed lines
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to bury power lines underground since they're frequently the source of wildfires when exposed above ground.

CONTENT:
New homes to be built, could be solar equipped,  landscaping planted to minimize danger to structures, environmentally safe etc…
We need to lessen our reliance on power companies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want new construction to prioritize solar power and fire-resistant landscaping to reduce environmental impact and dependence on utility companies while improving community safety.

CONTENT: Underground authority needs to be given to the County/City so that there is not a statewide/utility/personal property owner fight over where these lines go. The political cost of comprimising will be prohibitively expensive and too slow to make a lasting difference. Reducing future risk of and to infrastructure should be priority #1.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need local control over underground utility placement, not state/utility battles. The current political compromises are too costly and slow to effectively reduce infrastructure risks.

CONTENT: Yes, keep people updated with what is going on and be as transparent as possible.  People need to see continuous progress.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need constant, transparent updates about what's happening with the fire response. Show us the ongoing progress being made - that's what the community needs.

CONTENT: One immediate need is definitely financial support/grants/tax credits for home building and to address new code requirements. Instead of trying to waive the new code requirements to rebuild faster, let's give the community the chance to build back better
LLM_SUMMARY: Need financial support through grants and tax credits to meet new building codes, rather than waiving requirements. This would help us rebuild safer, stronger homes after the fire.

CONTENT: Clear the business areas that burned. Army Core is not contracted to do this and we must clear in order to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need to clear burned business areas before rebuilding can begin, but Army Corps isn't contracted for this cleanup work. We're stuck waiting and can't move forward.

CONTENT: not necessary to widen roads nor restrict parking in the alphabet streets, no fire for 100 years, emergency vehicles went up and down our streets without issue for the 30 years we lived there, Hartzell is a wider street and cars would fly up and down the street creating safety issues, will be too expensive to widen the streets, will slow down construction to widen the streets that only benefits those with ample resources to wait to build their homes for 4-5 years.
LLM_SUMMARY: Widening roads is unnecessary and problematic - emergency vehicles managed fine for decades. It would be expensive, delay reconstruction, and create new safety issues with faster traffic.

CONTENT:
Fire resistant building materials, consistent audits of defensible space. (Individual buy in to the intrusion that an audit requires, for the greater good) audits of power companies to ensure they are not at risk for causing a fire.
Sincere attempts to reduce factors contributing to climate instability
LLM_SUMMARY: We need fire-resistant materials, defensible space audits, and power company oversight. Everyone must accept these measures while working to address climate change's underlying causes.

CONTENT: I have seen numerous agencies offering free testing for soil. The city needs to make this a priority. Our children, elderly, and immune compromised neighbors deserve their safety to be prioritized. We do not want to hear stories years from now about Altadena residents who are now suffering from medical illnesses due to the city’s quick response to “back to business as usual” without taking the proper steps and precautions to ensure our community’s safety.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about rushed recovery efforts. Want city to prioritize soil testing and safety precautions to protect vulnerable residents from potential long-term health impacts from fire debris contamination.

CONTENT: I see prior comments on all these proposed regulations-  at what cost?
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about the financial burden of new housing regulations and rebuilding requirements being proposed after the fire.

CONTENT: Reduce red tape.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need less bureaucracy and paperwork to get help.

CONTENT: Must balance mean time to repair (MTTR) measures with quality measures to ensure we are not just building back faster but that we are building back better.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned that rushing infrastructure repairs could compromise quality. Want to ensure restoration efforts focus on both speed and implementing better, more resilient systems.

CONTENT: We must have a more robust infrastructure that includes a publicly funded Watch Duty, up to date water systems, a reliable Emergency Response System, an accountable public utility that takes a People First vs profits first POV (undergrounding power lines)
LLM_SUMMARY: We need stronger public infrastructure - Watch Duty funding, modern water systems, reliable emergency response, and utilities that prioritize safety over profits by undergrounding power lines.

CONTENT: The safety of residents should be the highest priority during the debris removal and rebuilding process. We’re seeing experts reporting on the poor air quality, toxins in the soil, and other hazardous issues that will impact residents’ longterm health. A more solid plan for how this will be addressed is crucial.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about health risks from toxic debris and poor air quality. We need a better plan to protect residents' safety and long-term health during cleanup and rebuilding.

CONTENT: let's work to ensure these communities meet the strictest of standards for fire resistance.  government needs to use taxpayer money to invest in our communities.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need strict fire safety standards in our communities, and the government should invest taxpayer money to make this happen.

CONTENT: Again, this would be great, but I predict it would get so tied up by various interest groups I almost would rather you not bother. Please just slash regulations, stop trying to control prices, and let people get to work.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by bureaucracy and overregulation - just want government to reduce restrictions and price controls so businesses can rebuild and operate freely without interference.

CONTENT: We have so many empty buildings downtown, need to find a way to use them for housing, faster.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should repurpose vacant downtown buildings to quickly address housing needs instead of waiting for new construction.

CONTENT:
Insurance companies had been moving out of this market, cancelling policies and raising the cost of premiums to the point of being unaffordable.

Rebuilding with fire, earthquake and storm resistant materials along with structure strengthening measures should be promoted as one way to help reduce insurance costs.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are abandoning our market and making coverage unaffordable. We need incentives for fire-resistant rebuilding to help bring down these skyrocketing insurance costs.

CONTENT: Why can't we just make homes fire proof?
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to focus on making homes more fire-resistant - it seems like a straightforward solution to prevent wildfire damage.

CONTENT: We need better infrastructure but NONE of the items listed above are important. All those infrastructure items are obsolete. With decent Personal Rapid Transit, you don't need roads or sidewalks or street lights. With solar on each building and passive building design, you don't need power lines. With efficient appliances you don't need (many) water lines. Proper local wastewater recycling &  management can get rid of the need for sewer. Don't have big companies control internet. Use mesh networks in everybody's phone.
LLM_SUMMARY: Infrastructure solutions should be completely reimagined with modern alternatives like personal rapid transit, solar power, efficient water systems, and decentralized utilities, not just rebuilding outdated systems.

CONTENT: We're already in a rent crisis, and the wildfires are just fanning the flames. Everyone is being exploited; not just residents, but also small business owners! (You want to know why tacos are so expensive? RENT! Why doctors are so expensive? RENT! Why so few community spaces exist? RENT!) If we want our economy to recover from COVID and the fire, we need high-density housing, and we need LOTS of it FAST. Even if it's not financially sensible for developers. We ought to stop pouring money into subsidies that just make the housing market rise even faster; let's build high quality public housing and roll back our ridiculous zoning laws. Let's do whatever it takes; even give a housing agency right of first refusal on all real estate sales.
LLM_SUMMARY: High rent was already crushing us before the fires. We desperately need more housing density and public housing options, even if developers don't profit. Current subsidies just drive prices higher.

CONTENT:
Fire is a part of the landscape and our land use policies need to reflect that. It's not just about current accountability but historical accountability. We displaced people from the land and from there ability to tend to the landscape with fire. We have a fire debt that must be paid.
Taking that to account new construction must be fireproof. The use of hempcrete, and recycled concrete and other materials must be allowed going forward.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must acknowledge historical displacement that disrupted traditional fire management practices. Moving forward, building codes need to mandate fire-resistant materials like hempcrete to create resilient communities.

CONTENT: ADUs are a way to get people living on their properties sooner than later. Make the permitting process quick and easy for ADU and I may consider living there while I rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to live in an ADU while rebuilding my home, but permitting process needs to be streamlined. Would seriously consider this option if made easier.

CONTENT: I believe regulations do not aid in using money effectively and quickly, but we also should avoid repeating past mistakes. Let’sexample, not a repeat of history. use this as an
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned that regulations slow down effective use of funds, but want to ensure we learn from past mistakes to build better community resilience going forward.

CONTENT: First, this is not very necessary now. Second, I do not have faith it would be executed properly, and would again end up just wasting resources. Focus on cutting red tape, and getting out of the way so the residents can rebuild their lives.
LLM_SUMMARY: Skeptical of emergency communication initiatives. Believe they're unnecessary and would be poorly executed. Resources better spent reducing bureaucracy to help residents rebuild after fires.

CONTENT:
The fires were & are a continuing catastrophe
The faster we organize & implement recovery measures the long-term economic damage will be

To achieve this will require an innovative and comprehensive plan which addresses present, short & long term challenges all at once

 We MUST take into consideration the increasing demand for limited water & power resources as the population continues to grow.
Think for a moment of the consequences if we ignore this...

We have all of the resources we need to make an outstanding accomplishment, to rise from the ashes like the Phoenix

Extreme & erratic weather events are increasing around the globe.

Who will take the initiative & show the world how to overcome these disasters quickly?

Let it be  L.A.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need a comprehensive recovery plan that addresses immediate and long-term challenges, especially water and power resources. LA can show leadership in disaster recovery despite increasing extreme weather events.

CONTENT: I will not commit to rebuilding until I see a plan from DWP that includes Chautauqua Blvd, North of Bestor, in underground utility installation. This area has been severely neglected by the City: road in poor shape and not paved for about 30 years, power lines transversing my property from the pole to connect to neighbor and has not been updated for decades. Bad system for a known high fire prone/high wind prone area.
LLM_SUMMARY: Refusing to rebuild until DWP commits to underground utilities on Chautauqua Blvd. Current overhead power lines and neglected infrastructure are dangerous in this high-fire,

CONTENT: It should be legal to live for an indefinite amount of time on a property, in a trailer or other mobile unit where the structure of record is uninhabitable or was removed.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to be allowed to live long-term in a trailer on my property while my home is uninhabitable or gone. Current restrictions shouldn't prevent this temporary housing solution.

CONTENT: This is a hard one but, I think the homeowners, communities and the state need to reconsider rebuilding in areas that are known to burn over and over. Some areas have burnt multiple times and people just rebuild. Isn't this the definition of insanity?
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to stop rebuilding homes in areas that repeatedly burn. It's insane that we keep reconstructing in the same high-risk fire zones over and over again.

CONTENT: Need to suspend coastal commission and CEQA  for all fire victims not just these recent fires. The Franklin, Mountain and Woolsey fires and more.
LLM_SUMMARY: Urging suspension of Coastal Commission and CEQA regulations for all fire victims, not just recent ones - should include Franklin, Mountain, Woolsey fires and others.

CONTENT:
Preventing future disasters should be 1st priority. Get power lines underground, create highly accessible documentation around how to build a fire-resistant home, enforce new landscaping regulations to minimize spread potential.

Refining our ability to respond should they arise again should be 2nd. Provide LA residents with a 5-minute video explaining what to do in case of a future fire, perform an in-depth postmortem analyzing the emergency team response and determine any process changes that should be made.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to prioritize prevention through underground power lines, fire-resistant building guides, and landscaping rules, while also improving emergency response protocols and public education.

CONTENT: This is a reality of California whether you believe in climate change or not.  Home owners should build back better. But also we need to hold utilities accountable.  In Altadena the brush near the power lines fueled the destruction. How that was allowed to happen is truly baffling.  Homeowners alone should not bear the brunt of being responsible for wildfire preparation.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need both individual and systemic action - homeowners should build resilient homes, but utilities must be held accountable for maintaining power lines and clearing dangerous brush around them.

CONTENT: Don’t go crazy on regulations that significantly increase costs to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Just want to rebuild without excessive regulations driving up costs - keep it simple and affordable for those of us trying to recover.

CONTENT: Ensure there are fire safe community resilience centers throughout rebuilt communities - places that people can walk to and access close to their homes that will be safe for sheltering in place. New neighborhood schools or recreational centers could serve this purpose.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need fire-safe community centers within walking distance that can serve as emergency shelters. New schools and rec centers could fulfill this role in rebuilt neighborhoods.

CONTENT: Sprinklers inside and out.  Rules for removing all flammable materials from house perimeter. Vents at chest level so they can be sealed conveniently as necessary. Instructions and training on how to do this for homeowners and renters.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need clear rules and training for fire prevention measures like sprinkler systems, removing flammables, and managing vents. Both homeowners and renters should know proper safety procedures.

CONTENT:
Altadena doesn't have a local government to speak of. 
More safety regulations are better, but they should be made convenient to implement rather than bureaucratic brick walls.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need safety regulations for recovery, but they must be practical and easy to implement, especially since Altadena lacks local government infrastructure to manage complex processes.

CONTENT:
And the cellular/wifi system needs to have local power backup, and redundancy in case nodes go down.

We need fire shelters in every at risk area... and these might as well be ultra fast track permitted little unit ADUs - affordable housing and fire shelters in one solution. With pressurized air. Also could serve as wifi/cel backup nodes to be in communications. Accessible to first responders and especially to residents in conditions that move to fast... 

Places like Topanga in the 'urban-wilderness interface' were considered high risk. As we just learned, any neighborhood with trees - at least HALF of LA - is now as higher or higher risk because closer structures are susceptible to conflagration
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about unreliable emergency communications during fires. We need backup power for cell/wifi systems and multi-purpose fire shelters that could serve as communication nodes and safe spaces in at-risk

CONTENT: The power lines MUST be buried, and the cost should be absorbed by the power companies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities should be forced to pay for undergrounding power lines to prevent future fires. This isn't something residents should have to fund.

CONTENT: We know why there wasn't enough water. DWP never built the water system to fight a wildfire. Now we know we have to rebuild the water system to support delivering more water faster. Make the communities who chose to live in the high risk areas pay for the upgrades.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that inadequate water infrastructure failed during fire. Believes DWP should upgrade systems but wants high-risk communities to bear the costs of necessary improvements.

CONTENT: Update systems, water reclamation, underground power, solar powered street lights, break up the monopoly of the utilities. SCE is irresponsible and has shown a considerable lack of care for its customers and the land.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with SCE's poor service and environmental neglect. Want modernized infrastructure with underground power lines, sustainable utilities, and an end to SCE's monopoly control.

CONTENT: I was stunned to hear how many homes likely burned because of the mesh over the venting areas in roofs/attics. It seems clear this was a known issue -- instead of insurance companies canceling people, why not spend money on homeowner safety education? If people knew replacing that mesh might save their home, you're telling me more people wouldn't do it? Yet I never heard of that until these terrible fires. And if we don't do the work ahead of time -- firebreaks, education, and routinely evaluating the readiness of our agencies, then another disaster will happen, and I'm not sure how much more this state can take.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that critical safety information like roof mesh risks wasn't shared proactively. Insurance companies should focus on prevention education rather than cancellations. We need better preparation through firebreaks and agency

CONTENT: Easy access to fire-safe building plans would help people tremendously, I think. I know some homeowners will struggle because they want to rebuild THE house, but many of those houses had outdated materials that are no longer up to code. But helping people see how they can rebuild with the proper materials will get some people over that hump quickly. Additionally, ADUs are a great way to help people earn extra income to cover their mortgages/insurance -- or to bring loved ones in when they need housing. This should be something that can be fast-tracked immediately. Long-term we all know that affordable housing is a challenge -- I'm not sure how we ever overcome the NIMBY mentality and make room for those who can't afford $3000 studio apts.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need easier access to fire-safe building plans and fast-tracked ADU permits. People want to rebuild their old homes, but updated materials are crucial. Affordable housing remains a major challenge.

CONTENT: Consider alternative home-building techniques. Maybe utilization of brick/mortar construction or more flame-resistant, non-cancerous materials. Of course, remember that this must be balanced against being earthquake-resistant as well, given the location/geography.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to explore fire-resistant building materials that are also earthquake-safe. Traditional brick and non-toxic materials could work, but must consider our area's unique geographic challenges.

CONTENT: Modify zoning in the impacted areas to rebuild in a sustainable way, while also keeping the characters of the neighborhood still intact. Streamline the process for building.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to rebuild sustainably while preserving neighborhood character, but need simpler zoning and permitting processes to make it happen efficiently.

CONTENT: The state needs to be purchasing land from homeowners or doing parcel swaps to get people out of the WUI.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need the state to buy out properties or swap land parcels to relocate residents away from wildland-urban interface areas.

CONTENT: Eliminate new code requirements, residents are dealing with enough and they don't have unlimited funds for new code upgrades. Let residents build at a minimum to what they had before without all the bureaucracy. The city and county already provide massive amounts of 'legal aid' for tenants and illegals there is no need to reinvent the wheel.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by costly new building codes and bureaucracy. Just want to rebuild what we had before without extra requirements. Existing legal aid programs are sufficient - no need for more.

CONTENT: We ought to rethink and streamline regulations for everyone. Obviously we need regulations for things like fire resistance and sprinkler systems, but there must be lots of other things we can cut. If fewer regulations are good enough for rebuilding right now, why aren't they good enough for rebuilding all the time?
LLM_SUMMARY: Regulations for rebuilding after fires should be permanently streamlined. If reduced regulations work for post-disaster reconstruction, they should work for regular building projects too.

CONTENT: Soil of all properties must be remediated and tested afterward.  This includes both soil of properties with standing structures and the entirety of properties with destroyed structures, not just within the ash footprint.  Also, people should be strongly encouraged to remove toxic substances, such as lead and asbestos, from their homes and properties rather than encapsulating them.  If they are merely encapsulated, these substances will become part of the toxic aftermath of the next fire...and there will be more fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about soil contamination beyond just ash footprints. Want comprehensive testing and remediation, plus removal rather than encapsulation of toxins to prevent worse contamination in future fires.

CONTENT:
Los Angeles is a desert marsh-land. Part of our issues in retaining water in our aquifers is the fact that we covered the entire watershed in concrete and asphalt. As much as we require roads to walk and drive on we need water more. The future of transport is not in the private automobile but in careful planning and construction of public transit systems. This would lesson the need for roads for cars and allow more of the land mass to be permeable enough for water to fill our aquifers more efficiently then anything we can construct artificially. 
Infrastructure built needs to abandon the philosophy of trying to tame nature and instead we need infrastructure that works with nature and not against it.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to reduce paved surfaces and car infrastructure in LA, replacing them with public transit. This would help natural water absorption and work with nature instead of fighting it.

CONTENT: The major lifelines of water, electricity, natural gas, and broadband/internet are absolutely required.  The pedestrian infrastructure was likely not impacted by the fires, but the rest obviously have been.  In addition to burying electrical, there should be separate standpipes between homes, in addition to standard hydrants, for fire department (or even homeowner) access, to support mitigation of any future events.  Better reservoir water management and better water infrastructure would help, but in the event of this particular incident, as we would say in the fire service 'is like trying to stop a train with a water hose'.  Just not possible. Which is why, better rebuilding with fire resistant materials is required.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need reliable utilities restored, especially water and power. While this fire was unstoppable, we should improve infrastructure with buried power lines, more hydrants, and better water systems for future events.

CONTENT: Immediately clear the properties on PCH on reopen the road. Cal Trans wants to put in bike lanes and sidewalks before opening. We do not need that. We need a wider road for safety, not narrower lanes. We also need an emergency permit for a sewer in east Malibu to handle the rebuilds.  600 or more new individual septic systems makes no sense whatsoever.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with CalTrans prioritizing bike lanes over reopening PCH quickly. We need wider roads for safety and a proper sewer system for rebuilds, not individual septic systems.

CONTENT: Lets choose the best alternatives in shot AND long run, on the topics we covered specially on the residential-commercial structures AND in the thermal exterior walls coverings. AND work on the grants.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need better options for rebuilding both homes and businesses, especially regarding exterior wall materials. Want help accessing grants to support the recovery process.

CONTENT: Underground utilities!
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to move utilities underground to prevent future fire damage and outages.

CONTENT: Rather than tax, tax, tax to create subsidies, let's make it easier for businesses to operate. Cut the red tape. Incentivize them to stay in Los Angeles.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want less taxation and bureaucracy, more incentives to keep businesses in LA. Simplifying operations would help more than subsidy programs funded by higher taxes.

CONTENT:
Deploy a streetlight design wrapped in PV w/ a small vertical axis wind turbine on top would feed clean energy to the microgrids being developed in reconstruction zones

V-axis wind turbines on power towers

Widespread deployment of point of use atmospheric water condensers acquired @ wholesale & distributed @ cost by LA Rises would foster water security

The financial ecosystem developed for the recovery should be employed to build a desalination plant for LA like the Claude Lewis facility in Carlsbad would go a long way towards establishing water security in our city
Or it could be funded w/ a water purchase agreement

Prolonged drought & increasing pop indicate that the water supply issue will only get worse as time moves 4ward
LLM_SUMMARY: We need innovative infrastructure solutions - solar streetlights, wind turbines, water condensers, and desalination plants - to ensure reliable power and water security during our post-fire rebuilding efforts

CONTENT:
When it comes to managing dollars, people want to see the overall dollars being distributed via programs. 

If there's 10,000 homes and businesses burnt, and we have $6B collectively raised for every single program from mental health to temporary housing, to environmental cleanups...

That's nearly $600,000 per structure on top of their insurance payments. If that's the case, just give them the bulk of the money and let the communities self organize and solve their repair. Pool a portion of the money into local government accounts for things like rebuilding schools and repairing sidewalks. 

If the number is much much less, like $1B, mostly not cash, and not all available today, then fine build it all out slowly with programs.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should know the total aid money available. If it's substantial, give it directly to affected property owners to manage recovery themselves, with some pooled for infrastructure. If limited, then structured programs make

CONTENT: Bury power lines underground! Prevent damage from the wind every year, and extra wear-and-tear by being exposed to the elements all year long.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are needed to prevent wind damage and reduce wear from weather exposure - this would help avoid outages during fires.

CONTENT:
Reduce permit fees 
Assist in the rebuild reduce cost of supplies to help
LLM_SUMMARY: Need financial relief through lower permit fees and rebuilding costs - the community needs direct assistance to recover and become resilient again.

CONTENT: Given the common occurrence of high winds in the area, it is irresponsible that any utility lines are still allowed above ground. Power and other utilities should not have to be shut off to protect people during storm events when they may be the most needed. Companies which have chosen to allow their infrastructure to grow so out of date should not be allowed to pass the high cost of now updating them to customers.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that outdated above-ground utility lines require shutoffs during storms when most needed. Utility companies should bear responsibility for infrastructure upgrades instead of passing costs to customers.

CONTENT: A lot of us want to clear brush and trees but are told we cannot because of ESHA. Suspend to Coastal act and ESHA with it.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that environmental protection rules (ESHA and Coastal Act) prevent us from clearing vegetation for fire safety. These regulations need to be suspended for community protection.

CONTENT: Expedite PCH redesign, while the opportunity exists, and a boulevard instead of a speedway will ensue. Underground all utilities throughout Malibu. Allow controlled burns around neighborhoods in Malibu.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need faster PCH redesign to make it safer, plus underground utilities and controlled burns around Malibu neighborhoods to prevent future disasters.

CONTENT: Build and invest in infrastructure that is resilient to natural disasters and fires due to extreme climate activities - fires, flood, wind, etc.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need infrastructure built to withstand extreme weather and natural disasters. Current systems aren't resilient enough against fires, floods, and other climate-related threats.

CONTENT: Bury the lines.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to put power lines underground to prevent future fire risks.

CONTENT: The government should be helping homeowners that have homes that are standing to retrofit for fire safety. Codes need to be updated with fire safety at the forefront without any red tape.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need government support to retrofit existing homes for fire safety, with streamlined building codes that prioritize fire protection without bureaucratic obstacles.

CONTENT: Fire-resistant construction materials exist. Require their use in fire-prone areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need mandatory requirements for fire-resistant building materials in high-risk zones - it's a simple solution that already exists.

CONTENT: Removing the devastation in the fire areas will restore peoples hope of an expedited recovery and will minimize people from moving away or leaving land untouched.  Soil and water quality assurance that we will all be safe is essential.
LLM_SUMMARY: Clearing fire debris quickly will give people hope and prevent abandonment of properties. We need assurance that soil and water are safe for recovery to move forward.

CONTENT: Clean the debris FAST. Waive permit fees for the people who are rebuilding, whether that means like for like or smaller or bigger than what they had. Direct GRANT to homeowners.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need rapid debris removal and permit fee waivers for rebuilding, regardless of new home size. Direct grants to homeowners should be prioritized for recovery.

CONTENT: This could be a strategic community effort rather than each individual homeowner having to go at it alone, which also strains the insurance systems, which in turn raises costs down the road.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should tackle insurance and recovery as a coordinated community effort, not individually. Working alone overburdens the system and drives up everyone's future costs.

CONTENT: Power lines need to be underground.  Europe has them, why doesn't California? This, and controlled burns, using goats to clear brush around urban-wildlife interface areas needs to be a priority for the state, county and city, and all water systems should be audited before the fire season begins. Leadership should be held accountable for not maintaining fire hydrants and reservoirs. There should be more budget dollars allocated to these preventative measures vs incurring billions in losses and the horrific trauma of our people. We should NOT be taxed through more bond measures for losses that were preventable or at least not a disaster of epic proportions.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines and preventative measures like controlled burns should be prioritized over costly disaster recovery. Leaders must be accountable for maintaining fire infrastructure instead of passing costs to taxpayers.

CONTENT: Having been non renewed by my insurance company I think it is critical to assist homeowners rebuild their homes through a grant program. To keep the community flavor it will require getting year old owners back in their homes. Otherwise the old neighborhood will be replaced with money hungry developers with no thought of community only profit. Tenants will need access to new apartment building so assisting the owners rebuild in a timely fashion with also be critical
LLM_SUMMARY: Worried about losing community character after insurance non-renewal. We need grants to help original homeowners rebuild quickly, preventing developers from taking over and displacing tenants.

CONTENT: look at rebuilding homes with fire resistant materials.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to see homes rebuilt using fire-resistant materials to better protect against future wildfires.

CONTENT:
Coop's and land trusts can be instruments to keep land within the hands of the people who have historically lived there but they can also be abused to keep people out. How these different entities are constructed will be important not for recovery today but adaptability into the future.
On the matter of construction there needs to be flexibility in the building codes to allow for the construction of future proof housing. There needs to be building codes in place that allow for hempcreate construction, recycled material construction, earthships, etc. Methods of constructing housing that try not put additional load on our already overstretched earth resources.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need flexible building codes that allow for sustainable construction methods like hempcrete and recycled materials, while ensuring land trusts and co-ops help preserve community ownership without becoming exclusionary.

CONTENT: The beading of the roads AND streets must be with sturdy materia to prevent that the concrete or asphalt break apart. Defenitetely sidewalks infraestructura musk have handy CAP Ramos AND accesos , streets lights mus be use photo cells to avoid the wiring. Aldo we need to reduce the high tención suspensión wire by Runing those wires underground to every Lot.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need stronger road materials to prevent breaking, better sidewalk access, solar-powered streetlights, and underground power lines instead of suspended wires to make infrastructure safer and more resilient.

CONTENT: Although the EPA came by my house already and cleaned up the army Corp has been by the house multiple times but haven't started in their cleanup. I realize there are 15,000 structures needing cleanup but I think more contractors should be brought in to assist.  As far as habitat restoration as critical as that is, getting the houses restored I think should be a higher priority. Restoring water should also be a very high priority.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with slow debris cleanup despite multiple agency visits. Want more contractors hired to speed up process. Housing restoration and water service should take priority over habitat restoration.

CONTENT: All landscape must be completed to reduce the risk as much as possible. If an area is prone to fire, perhaps don't rebuild there?
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to fully maintain landscapes for fire prevention. We should also question whether rebuilding in fire-prone areas is wise in the first place.

CONTENT: Debris removal is going pretty quickly between private contractors and the ACE's federal efforts.  Soil and Water quality plus open space and habitat restoration are efforts where community members and local universities will jump (or are already jumping!) at the chance to be involved, so as to save the county having to hire more staff to handle it all and instead our tax dollars can remain focused on upping the budget for outsourcing of the permitting process.
LLM_SUMMARY: Community appreciates quick debris removal by contractors and federal teams. Excited about local volunteers and universities helping with environmental restoration, which saves money for other recovery priorities.

CONTENT: You have the bury the power lines.
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines need to be buried underground to prevent future fire risks.

CONTENT: I’m so tired of having to use our county tax dollars to rebuild Malibu due to either fires, flooding, or high water damage. Regulations need to be into place whereby people cannot just be allowed to rebuild yet again, and have the rest of the county help them rebuild yet again. With climate change, it will continue to happen probably much more frequently. Let’s try to be proactive now in a positive way.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fed up with repeatedly funding Malibu rebuilds after disasters. We need regulations preventing endless reconstruction in high-risk areas, especially with climate change making these events more frequent.

CONTENT: I think it's really important to consider where to rebuild, and where not to rebuild. My grandmother's home burned down, and everyone in her community wants to rebuild in the same place. But does it really make sense when we know that the Palisades Highlands is in an extremely high fire risk area? To the extent that folks want to rebuild in high risk areas, should the entire state of California shoulder that risk through our tax dollars and insurance payments?
LLM_SUMMARY: Questioning whether rebuilding in high-risk fire zones like Palisades Highlands makes sense, especially when the financial burden falls on all California taxpayers and insurance holders.

CONTENT: Fire resistant design is a community effort.  Everyone needs to be a part of it.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need the whole community to participate in fire-resistant design - it's not something that works unless everyone commits to it.

CONTENT: In our rural area, we've discovered the hard way that key equipment for landlines, cable/internet and cell service often shares a power pole. Which means literally every means of communication most people have access to goes down at the same time if the fire takes out that ONE pole. There ought to be a mandate for undergrounding ALL of those services and separating them where undergrounding is not possible. A grant program to equip rural residents with satellite phones for emergency use would also help, as would establishing local emergency radio frequencies we could tune into for updates. Also, cell phones should be able to connect to ANY available tower for ALL CALLS (not just 911) and alerts (nixle, watch duty, etc) during emergencies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about communication failures during fires when all services share single power poles. Need underground utilities, backup systems like satellite phones, emergency radio frequencies, and expanded cell coverage during disasters.

CONTENT:
1.  Requirement for confirmation sampling after debris removal; 
2. City of LA DBS to apply existing residential standards of soil condition as a prerequisite of issuing building permits in the burn zone.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want proper soil testing and sampling after debris cleanup, and city needs to enforce residential soil standards before allowing rebuilding in burned areas.

CONTENT: The permit process needs to be improved
LLM_SUMMARY: The permit process is too complicated and needs to be streamlined.

CONTENT: Home owners should be able to use Natural gas. It's more reliable and affordable than all electric mandates. Not allowing apartments in single family areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with electric mandates, I want natural gas options for reliability and affordability. Keep single-family zoning intact.

CONTENT: Affordable fire resistant building supplies for all. bi-monthly meetings for residents with officials to provide new improvements to help those who live in fire prone areas
LLM_SUMMARY: Need affordable fire-resistant materials and regular community meetings with officials to better protect fire-prone neighborhoods and keep residents informed of safety improvements.

CONTENT: We need to know that the state is prioritizing fire mitigation so that we can feel good about rebuilding in the same areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want assurance that state is taking fire prevention seriously before committing to rebuild in fire-prone areas. Need confidence in mitigation efforts.

CONTENT: All power should be underground AND not at the expense of the rate payer.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are essential for safety, but utility companies should bear the costs instead of passing them on to customers through higher rates.

CONTENT: The state & many cities are planning for more growth & density, w/o paying attention to flood plains & fire prone areas. Even if the area is a "high opportunity area" if it's a flood plain per FEMA, it's highly irresponsible to put more people in the path of danger. We're now having more 100-year and 500-year storms and we must adapt to climate change, not ignore it. Same goes for tsunami zones, sea level rise & erosion, we should stop advocating for false solutions like sea walls & advocate for managed retreat instead. The city must have real community engagement and conduct drills so residents can be prepared for natural disasters. Language access is crucial, not only simple to understand, but translate messages to languages people speak.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned that urban growth ignores natural hazard zones. We need proper disaster planning with community involvement and multilingual communication, not band-aid solutions that put more people at risk.

CONTENT: Consistency for One California is a must. My community of Paradise Ca had substantial costs with permits, surveys, septic, architect costs. Fleeced by our own town.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by excessive rebuilding costs in Paradise, including permits, surveys, and architectural fees. Feel taken advantage of by local government during reconstruction process.

CONTENT: Undergrounding powerlines should be done now, before roads are repaved.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to prioritize putting power lines underground before repaving roads - it's the logical order for infrastructure improvements.

CONTENT: 6 of the 10 most costly fires in California have been caused by power lines. Its way overdue to put them underground. If Europe can do it, so can we.
