LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that power lines cause major fires in California. Underground power lines, like in Europe, are long overdue and would prevent these costly disasters.

CONTENT: Too many laws and regs from too many layers of gov to make any real progress.
LLM_SUMMARY: Excessive regulations and bureaucracy from multiple government levels are preventing meaningful progress on rebuilding efforts after the fire.

CONTENT: Use Strong Towns principles in the rebuilding process. Prioritize the lowest-income households first. Deprioritize owners with second-homes. Establish clear process and timelines for residents to gain access to aid. Do not bypass environmental concerns.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want rebuilding to follow Strong Towns approach, helping low-income residents first. Need clear aid process and timelines while maintaining environmental standards. Second homeowners should be lower priority.

CONTENT: Need to have realistic evacuation routes and communications given the densities of people or restrict building to reduce the density.  Mandatory training drills might be useful.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about overcrowding affecting evacuations. Want better evacuation planning that accounts for population density, plus mandatory drills. Consider limiting new development to manage risk.

CONTENT: Must clean before anything. Do clean-up at the neighborhood or at minimum at the block-level, not individual building site, to be more more efficient and cost effective. Require home owners and insurance companies to bundle efforts/$$.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need coordinated neighborhood-wide debris cleanup instead of individual property efforts. Bundling resources between homeowners and insurance companies would be more efficient and cost-effective.

CONTENT: I would see this as an area where state and federal monies, along with $$$ from the utilities,  can be used to rebuild smartly.  Roads and sidewalks can be rethought to increase the probability of being able to leave in time.  Unsafe, above ground lines can be eliminated.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want government and utility funding used to rebuild infrastructure intelligently - focusing on evacuation-friendly roads and putting power lines underground for better safety.

CONTENT: The removal of potentially toxic and hazardous waste is a huge undertaking, and may be beyond what local government can do on their own.  It is also an opportunity to look at the balance of open space and building, and to restore at least some of the habitat that has been taking over by human.  Again, opportunity to build better.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need help beyond local government to handle toxic debris removal. This is a chance to restore natural habitat and rethink the balance between development and open space.

CONTENT: I don't know if I would classify it as a "theme," but I believe that using a disaster as a time to do better, to improve the situation, as well as addressing the immediate needs is important.  Coming to agreement on some of the "facts" is also important.
LLM_SUMMARY: Recovery efforts should focus on both immediate needs and long-term improvements. We need to use this disaster as an opportunity to build back better, while establishing common ground on facts.

CONTENT:
I prefer to stay focused on where we go from here, rather than debate why stuff didn't happen in the past. We know what we need to do (e.g, utility under-grounding, firebreaks, fire prevention, fire hardening when (re)building, etc.). It will cost money (private, government). We know we have not had basic* transparency in past on government action (including our IOU monopolies), so let's design that differently from hereon too, perhaps leveraging 311 that we already use. All this can be piloted/tested in LA, but needs to be designed for statewide rollout, adapted for situations elsewhere. 

*basic in sense of: clear, accessible, responsive, and timely to average citizen - not in terms of endless dense reports commissioned by CPUC etc.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to focus on implementing known solutions like undergrounding and firebreaks, while ensuring transparent government oversight. Let's pilot these programs in LA before expanding statewide.

CONTENT: Building and zoning laws should be reviewed annually, and updated as needed.  They need to reject the current needs.  We need to take into account all the science and facts at our disposal and then come up with collaborative changes to be made.  Everyone should be allowed to have a voice.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to regularly update building codes based on current science and community input. Everyone should have a say in making these important changes to protect our homes.

CONTENT: Mitigation efforts with to reduce wildfire risks. Using prescribed grazing approaches by contracting with businesses that have animals (goats, sheep) to reduce overgrowth of brush/ invasive plants (mustard grass, especially in Southern CA). It seems this was already proposed in CA with Senate Bill 675 - gathering support from LA county stakeholders is essential especially since it covers a large area with hills/ overgrowing brush.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to implement prescribed grazing with goats and sheep to control brush overgrowth. SB 675 proposed this solution - getting LA County support is crucial given our terrain.

CONTENT: This fire was unprecedented in that the winds created a very fast moving fire.  I think the city did a good job alerting people to high fire risk prior to the windstorm, as long as residents were signed up for the city's NotifyLA system and looked at NOAA reports ahead of time.  I don't know how best to get alerts to all citizens, especially the elderly who may be technology averse.  Maybe start with a cell phone push to alert citizens of fire risk, and I think it is also the responsibility of the residents to prepare adequately too for rapid evacuation.
LLM_SUMMARY: Alerts through NotifyLA and NOAA worked well for those signed up, but we need better ways to reach everyone, especially tech-averse elderly. Both city notifications and resident preparedness

CONTENT: if we don't address the root causes, this will happen over and over and over. it's physics. we need to address the root causes and focus on prevention.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must tackle the underlying causes of wildfires through prevention, or they'll keep recurring. It's simply physics - these events are inevitable without fundamental changes.

CONTENT: this isn't just for govt officials, it should be baked into building code, zoning, and planning. but not in the typical, gross, broad stroke kinda stupid way the county usually does everything, but in a really smart, focused, well considered way.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need smarter, more targeted wildfire prevention integrated into building codes and planning - not the county's usual broad, ineffective approach to regulations.

CONTENT: partially, the new code requirements should be evaluated by DISINTERESTED 3rd party experts to make sure they actually do something. so much code is basically lobbied into existence by people and companies who gain from requiring expensive, spurious non-sense. there should be significant legal aid for that effort.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want third-party experts reviewing building codes to prevent unnecessary expensive requirements pushed by special interests. Legal aid should support this oversight process.

CONTENT: Building code needs to emphasize fire safe
LLM_SUMMARY: We need stronger building codes focused on fire safety.

CONTENT: Tax relief for fire hardened houses and neighborhoods. The more contiguous houses that are fire hardened the more tax relief/house. So we encourage NEIGHBORHOODS to communicate and cooperate
LLM_SUMMARY: Want tax incentives for fire-hardening homes, with bigger breaks when multiple neighbors participate. This would promote community-wide preparation and cooperation for wildfire resilience.

CONTENT: Train community groups like town/neighborhood councils and CERTs on defensible space/structure hardening and have them conduct community-wide property reviews and education. Does not have to be an enforcement or narc approach but rather an offering of information specific to the property; it can even be a checklist on a trifold that checks off items that need to be retrofitted and specific instructions for the retrofit inside. It takes a village to educate but there's heavy reliance on the few in the government.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need trained community groups to educate neighbors about fire safety and property protection. Instead of enforcement, provide personalized guidance and checklists. Don't just rely on government officials.

CONTENT:
The government's attacking insurance, as someone from the southeast US, is strange. Governmental agencies let the city of LA develop and sprawl into high fire-risk areas. Insurance companies, like when people build beachfront homes in hurricane country, jacked up the insurance rates. When an insurance company says an area is dangerous, believe them.

Forcing other taxpayers to supplement a "wood home in a tinderbox" is ludicrous. Saying it's the homeowners' fault for having a home in a tinderbox is likewise insane; they aren't fire experts.

The blame for the Palisades fire's destruction lays at the feet of the negligent county, city, and state level officials who allowed people to build/buy homes and root their lives in the line of fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government officials are responsible for allowing development in high-risk fire zones, then blaming insurance companies and homeowners when rates spike. We shouldn't have been allowed to build here.

CONTENT: prevention, prevention, prevention. this was a preventable disaster. that's where all focus should be.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to prioritize prevention above all else - this disaster could have been avoided if we'd focused on preventive measures from the start.

CONTENT: Smart habitat restoration. Not clearing out debris etc. that create fuel for fires should not be an option
LLM_SUMMARY: We need intelligent habitat management - there's no excuse for letting debris accumulate and create fire hazards. Proper clearing is essential for prevention.

CONTENT: We need clear guidance on fire resistant best practices. Most of the guidance is tailored to homes in rural areas.  It does not apply to homes that are 10 feet apart in a city suburb.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that fire safety guidelines don't address suburban realities - need specific recommendations for closely-spaced homes in urban areas, not just rural properties.

CONTENT: Fire hardening is a good idea. Give us suggestions and guidelines,
LLM_SUMMARY: We want guidance on fire hardening measures to better protect our community. Tell us what specific steps to take.

CONTENT: Fireburns in open space to keep fireload low. Increase staffing during high winds/dangerous period.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need controlled burns in open areas to reduce fuel loads, plus more fire personnel on duty during high-risk weather conditions.

CONTENT:
Over the last few years, as a private property owner, I have received Brush Clearance notices for my property. At one point, I was substantially fined - although I had documentation my lot was clear. No matter what had been happening in my life (a parent passing, Covid, a sick child) I was required to clear brush on my property. Why isn’t the City, County, State held to these same requirements? 

I also think basic services that prioritize the safety of our communities - the police, fire department, schools, infrastructure - need to be funded first. We pay too high of taxes in LA and CA for these services not be available to residents when they are needed (ie; firefighters to put out fires, fire hydrants that work, etc)
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that private property owners face strict brush clearance enforcement and fines while government entities seem exempt. Our high taxes should prioritize basic safety services and infrastructure for fire prevention.

CONTENT: This needs to be treated as a priority for attention at city level, especially in the wildlands/urban interface, where fire is an ongoing and increasing experience. Everyone is affected by fire and this can be used proactively to encourage direct community engagement through neighborhood groups education, training, widespread introduction of goats for vegetation clearance, prescribed burning practices.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need city-level focus on wildland-urban areas where fire risk keeps growing. Let's build community resilience through education, training, and smart prevention like goat grazing and prescribed burns

CONTENT: Of course, firebreaks should be mandatory in all fire prone areas. Specifically, all agencies responsible for enforcing fire and water regulations (both directly and indirectly), should be held the most responsible. This is mostly their jurisdictional areas. Fire and water special emphasis program implementation - including organizations to whom it may concern.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need mandatory firebreaks in fire-prone areas and must hold regulatory agencies accountable for enforcement. They have jurisdiction and should implement proper fire prevention programs.

CONTENT:
We need ACCOUNTABILITY, REFORMS, GRANTS, and TAX BREAKS. We cannot rebuild this community without help for individual home owners.
(And please keep it closed until more debris is cleared and more of the fortunate are able to repopulate standing homes. Remediation lines are long. It’s too soon.)
LLM_SUMMARY: Need financial support through grants and tax breaks to help homeowners rebuild. Want area closed until debris clearing and remediation work is further along.

CONTENT: I am middle class. I’ll pour every cent into this rebuild, but I’m still not sure I can pull it off and I’m not sure I’m going to qualify for any help. Can you please keep that in mind? SEND GRANTS, PLEASE! I’ll follow every fire hardening guideline I can afford.
LLM_SUMMARY: Desperate for financial help with rebuilding but worried I won't qualify for assistance as middle-class homeowner. Will follow fire safety guidelines but need grants to make it possible.

CONTENT: The enormous expense of this fire, and the upset that is has caused for thousands of families, shows that funding fire prevention programs is a good idea.  Someone should be made in charge of fire prevention planning.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need dedicated leadership and funding for fire prevention programs - the huge costs and disruption to thousands of families from this fire proves it's worth the investment.

CONTENT: Government at all levels should be held accountable for fire prevention along with what is being required of homeowners.
LLM_SUMMARY: Officials need to be held just as responsible as residents are for fire prevention measures - it shouldn't just fall on homeowners to meet requirements.

CONTENT: Homeowners should be taking basic fire hardening steps. I live on the edge of the Palisades fire area but happened to be walking in Altadena/Pasadena neighborhoods a month or two BEFORE the fire. I kept shaking my head and repeating to my wife "Is nobody taking fire seriously here?". House after house of attached wood fences, trees branches overhanging houses, unbroken rows of vegetation, etc...
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by lack of fire preparedness in at-risk neighborhoods. Noticed many homes with dangerous features like wood fences and overhanging branches before the fires hit. Homeowners need to

CONTENT: Make LA and LA county a fire-wise community.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need LA County to become a fire-wise community to better protect our homes and neighborhoods from wildfires.

CONTENT: Communities in LA are quite disconnected and vulnerable in the face of emergency.  We need systematic emergency preparedness on the part of citizens, and we need more robust and resilient emergency response systems in government.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need both better community-level emergency preparedness and stronger government response systems. Right now our neighborhoods are disconnected and vulnerable when disasters strike.

CONTENT: Don’t just throw this on the residents trying to rebuild manage the land that is prone to fire better
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that burden falls on residents - authorities need to take more responsibility for managing fire-prone land rather than leaving it to homeowners during recovery.

CONTENT: Focusing on what the City can fund at a time of unprecedented deficits is absurd, and the City is unable to hold its agencies accountable. Angelenos should hold the Council responsible for the City's failures at the ballot box. City government should ensure that fire prevention requirements are clear to allow private citizens and enterprises to implement them without bureaucratic delays.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fed up with city's inability to fund and enforce fire prevention. Want clearer requirements so private citizens can act, and voters should hold City Council accountable for failures.

CONTENT: Codes need to be updated to maintain vegetation perimeters, so the fires can't spread from vegetation to houses.  If the home owner can't afford tree-trimming and so forth, the cities must help pay for this, because the cost of neighborhoods burning down is far worse.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need updated vegetation codes and city support for homeowners who can't afford maintenance. Preventing fires through proper clearance is cheaper than rebuilding burned neighborhoods.

CONTENT: Task Force time needed. Organize the players in this fight and keep on them until a concensus is reached. Then implement the devil out of it! We know pretty much what needs to be done already. Start with the easiest to implement, issue the changes and enforce them. Don’t stop working on the Version 2.0 changes and roll them out. Keep going! RINSE AND REPEAT!
LLM_SUMMARY: We need organized action now. Stop debating and start implementing known solutions, beginning with easy changes. Keep enforcing and improving - it's an ongoing process that requires persistence.

CONTENT:
It is utterly inexcusable that in the 21st century - literally tens if not hundreds of billions invested in tech; drone weapons of all kinds - California doesn't own one Super Scooper. Why not hundreds of drone Scoopers - winged or not? Super infrared detectors with AI intelligence to notice ANY dangerous signs of heat, fire, smoke and signal an immediate response from a 'SWAT' team that is entirely focused and on alert to snuff out any fires or flames before they can spread. Or issue tickets and fines, even prison, for anyone lighting dangerous fires. 
North East and canadian cities divert construction infrastructure to snow removal. We must divert resources & attention to be on hyper alert & vigilance in dry high fire risk.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need modern tech solutions like drone water bombers and AI detection systems for immediate fire response, plus strict enforcement. We're in the 21st century - California should invest like northern cities do for

CONTENT: We need climate resilient landscaping, native plants, trees that don’t burn like oaks, remove palms and eucalyptus. We need real brush clearance in high risk places next to houses. We need to remove non native brush. We need revised building codes. I have been hardening my house with roof sprinklers, 1/8 inch wire mesh covering all vents, brush clearance, etc.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need comprehensive fire-safe landscaping with native plants and removal of flammable non-natives. Already hardening my home with sprinklers and mesh, but we need better building codes and brush

CONTENT: Hold zoom workshops (and record them for future access) on various topics, like fire-resistant design, preparedness, safer landscaping, how to rebuild
LLM_SUMMARY: Want community education through online workshops about fire safety, resilient design, and rebuilding - make them accessible by recording for future viewing.

CONTENT:
Funding for communities to engage organizers and facilitators to act as paid (not volunteer, as is the Topanga Town Council, Chamber of Commerce, Emergency Preparedness (TCEP), elderly support (SAGES) - to bring community leaders together, to interface with govt agencies.
There should be a team specifically dedicated to coordination and communications as soon as a fire or other crisis strikes.
We need a unified 'easy to use' communications system for communities in crisis, including a clear and well organized hierarchy for distributing communications & a neighborhood/zone system that people are already enrolled in prefire. Cellular systems or mesh net wifi should be available for text only communications throughout the city and county.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need paid coordinators and a unified emergency communications system with clear hierarchy, not just volunteers. Pre-established neighborhood networks and backup text systems are essential for crisis response.

CONTENT: All important to a functioning community. As usual, the question begs - who pays for this?  Should the folks in Etna, CA be taxed for the folly of building so many high-dollar homes in an obvious fire zone? Should Modesto be on the hook for wealthy home owners in Marin or Sonoma or LA?
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about fairness in funding infrastructure repairs after fires. Questions why taxpayers across California should subsidize rebuilding in wealthy, high-risk fire zones.

CONTENT: The time to address the above issues is before a disaster.  Ignoring fire hazards then spending money on disaster recovery is a foolish way to solve the issues.   Ask the community why they did not do more to mitigate the fire hazard before the event.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should focus on fire prevention and hazard mitigation upfront, rather than spending money on recovery afterward. The community needs to take responsibility for preparedness.

CONTENT: We need to be proactive and clear brush/trash, bring back the brush eating goats and allow those that owe parking tickets to clean the freeways, like they used to. It should be illegal to start fires on the streets, public parks/forests (unless allowed to BBQ). Taxpayers should NOT be paying for the infrastructure upgrades of for profit electrical companies. When new communities are built, require power lines to be underground or have other safety measures in place that will prevent fires. Electrical companies can also educated the public and if they see something off with a powerline to say something.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need proactive brush clearing, stricter fire regulations, and underground power lines in new developments. Utility companies should fund their own infrastructure and educate the public about fire prevention.

CONTENT: The experts in the insurance industry who assess fire risk need to share their information publicly.  A coordinated effort between the insurance industry, the emergence response planners in the government, and the builders could result in a much better system for everyone.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should share their fire risk data openly. Better coordination between insurers, emergency planners, and builders would create a more effective system for managing wildfire risks.

CONTENT:
Yes! Sign me up for training! Organize me!

Neighborhoods need community fire teams in place who set pumps and hoses out at the pools before evacuating. Maybe we even chainsaw any fuel, if there’s time. Work with us. How long do you need the hoses to be and whose properties do you want to store them at for success?
LLM_SUMMARY: Eager to help form neighborhood fire response teams. Want to learn proper equipment setup, fuel removal, and coordinate storage locations for emergency supplies across properties.

CONTENT: For those neighborhoods zoned as "very high fire risk", the city and/or utilities needs to also be held accountable on underground transmission lines, along with reviewing all city trees which are highly flammable and replace them (regardless if tress are "protected" or not), along with ensuring overgrown vegetation are trimmed back on our hillsides/mountain areas close to residents.
LLM_SUMMARY: City and utilities must take responsibility by undergrounding power lines, replacing hazardous trees regardless of protected status, and managing overgrown vegetation near homes in high-risk fire zones.

CONTENT: Our government failed us on SO MANY LEVELS and need to be held accountable. We as homeowners have the responsibility of clearing our hillsides or we get a fine, meanwhile the city does nothing to clear public land. This is not ok. It needs to be top priority to clear the brush, for our communities, animals and environment.
LLM_SUMMARY: City neglects clearing public land while fining homeowners for not maintaining their properties. Government must be held accountable and make brush clearance a top priority for community safety.

CONTENT: We clearly can not depend on bigger entities like the county. This needs to be a local initiative. How can the city of Pasadena ensure each other’s safety? Creat neighborhood hubs and database so neighbors can look out for neighbors. We were left alone on January 7th/8th. All we have is each other.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with county response during Eaton Fire. We need local, neighborhood-based emergency systems in Pasadena - neighbors helping neighbors since we can't rely on larger agencies.

CONTENT: Most people are too tired and too overworked to find their own sources. Sometimes they don't even have enough time and energy available to KNOW that they need to do so. Government has a role to play in pushing out important, high-quality information.
LLM_SUMMARY: We're all too busy and exhausted to constantly seek out emergency information. The government needs to take responsibility for actively pushing critical updates to residents.

CONTENT: YES. YES. YES. Education, fire audits, financial assistance for community immunity.
LLM_SUMMARY: We urgently need education, fire safety assessments, and financial help to build community-wide protection against wildfires.

CONTENT:
One area where resources should be consolidated is the tax incentives, grants and rebates available from federal, State & local government entities for sustainability measures in rebuilding.  

This is an important part of a multi-layered cost reduction strategy that will make sustainable rebuilding accessible to all property owners.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need better coordination of government incentives and rebates for sustainable rebuilding - would help make these options more affordable and accessible for all property owners affected by fires.

CONTENT: Most of the defendable space requirements are already in the munipal code. How about actually enforcing existing code and fining people whose property are a fire hazard to the rest of us.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that existing defensible space codes aren't properly enforced. Want authorities to fine non-compliant properties that create fire hazards for the whole community.

CONTENT: Fire resistant materials. Landscaping strategies that maximize beauty and safety. Neighborhood-wide mitigation efforts, not just on individual properties. Recognition of adaptation as a community effort, not just home by home. Permeable surfaces, bioswales, rain gardens.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need community-wide approaches to fire safety, from coordinated landscaping to shared water management solutions. Individual property changes aren't enough - this requires collective action.

CONTENT: In fire prone areas, the public needs to not only have regular reminders they live IN a high-hazard area, but they should be required to participate in annual or semi-annual exercises with emergency management, first responders, etc.  CERT exists for this effort.  Frankly, I was surprised and dismayed that there aren't any future rebuilding requirements to use fire-resistant technologies or building materials or landscaping.  Sounded to me like all of that is waived to expedite the rebuilding/recovery process; meaning, lessons NOT learned.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need mandatory emergency response drills and CERT participation in fire-prone areas. It's concerning that rebuilding requirements don't enforce fire-resistant materials - we're not learning from these disasters.

CONTENT: The plain fact is that NO ONE can afford this. Altadena residents who lost their homes need money, we need grants marked for individuals and families, not agencies/charities (where the donated funds go God knows where). We can't do this alone. My family is in a relatively privileged position where we had insurance and did not lose our jobs, but we don't know if we will be able to afford to rebuild. If we can't afford it, who can? What will our town be if it's just turned over to deep pocketed developers? We need help, and direct financial assistance to residents is the only way to preserve this town.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need direct financial assistance for residents to rebuild - even with insurance, costs are overwhelming. Worried developers will take over if homeowners can't afford reconstruction.

CONTENT: My house is still standing with some minor damage, however, what I want to know is will there ever be grants to upgrade our old homes to code or for features that retard fires for example, fireproof roofs, siding, vents and windows?
LLM_SUMMARY: Seeking information about potential grants to upgrade older homes with fire-resistant features like fireproof roofs and vents, even though my house only sustained minor damage.

CONTENT: First two are obvious building code items. Preparedness training can be done individually and in private community groups.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building codes are important, but individual and community-level preparedness training is also key for building resilience against wildfires.

CONTENT:
I've heard stories of homeowners not being able to hire their own cleaning company. If a homeowner wants to hire their own licensed and certified cleaning company they should do so. 

The government should also be working on cleaning the surrounding areas that have been impacted; in this case the beaches. There has been little initiative by city/county to address the environmental impact caused to the Pacific Ocean by the fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that homeowners can't choose their own cleanup contractors. Government needs to take more initiative cleaning affected beaches and addressing fire-related environmental damage to the Pacific Ocean.

CONTENT: We should buy out homeowners in these areas and turn unsafe zones back into wilderness. If they want to stay, they should have to pay for the true cost.
LLM_SUMMARY: Advocate for buying out homeowners in high-risk areas to restore wilderness, or make residents pay actual costs if they choose to stay in fire-prone zones.

CONTENT: prepare by using the practice drills used in schools.  There should be surprise drills in all LA neighborhoods so we can work as a community.  Clear instructions, car exits, walking, public buses should be part of these drills.  This will take a large amount of time but we have expertise. The only way to be PREPARED is to work together in our preparation.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need surprise evacuation drills in LA neighborhoods, just like schools do. Practice different exit methods and work together as a community to truly be prepared.

CONTENT: We've got to take care of our neighbors, especially the ones who had their insurance dropped in the months leading up to the fires with no good alternative. But for anyone who could get insurance and decided not to, knowing they were in a fire zone? They should be on the hook for that bad decision, not the rest of us.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance coverage is crucial - we should help neighbors who lost coverage through no fault of their own, but those who chose not to insure despite fire risks shouldn't get public support.

CONTENT: Homeowners need to take more responsibility for their properties. Defensible space works, but it is not as aesthetically pleasing.
LLM_SUMMARY: Recognize that defensible space is effective for fire protection, but acknowledge the tradeoff between safety and maintaining attractive landscaping around homes.

CONTENT: Brush clearance on city/county/state land. That is THE problem.
LLM_SUMMARY: Lack of brush clearance by government agencies on public lands is the fundamental issue that needs to be addressed for wildfire prevention.

CONTENT: let's work to ensure these communities meet the strictest of standards for fire resistance.  government needs to use taxpayer money to invest in our communities.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need strict fire safety standards in our communities, and government must invest taxpayer funds to make this happen.

CONTENT: We all know what we would prefer our communities "look" like, but recognizing the hazards of where we live and HOW we need to build in preparation for those hazards is more important than our cultural ideal of a neighborhood. People should be willing to accept some change in how we construct buildings and develop larger settlements/communities so that fire protection can take priority.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must prioritize fire-safe construction and community development over traditional neighborhood aesthetics. Our cultural preferences should adapt to acknowledge and address the wildfire risks we face.

CONTENT: Why can't we just make homes fire proof?
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to focus on making homes more fire-resistant - it seems like a straightforward solution to prevent wildfire damage.

CONTENT:
CODE ENFORCEMENT NEEDS TO BE PROACTIVE, NOT REACTIVE. If we scratched the contract with WM for street sweeping in Palmdale, CA- we could replace that with 12 full-time code enforcing agents, and include a comprehensive benefits plan for them too. 

They would be tasked with ensuring compliance from landlords, and home owners. Everyone needs to be responsible for what they own and it's part in creating chaos' potential...

Also, Everyone needs to know their neighborhood's emergency response plan for all types of emergencies.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need proactive code enforcement to hold property owners accountable, not just reactive measures. Everyone should know their neighborhood's emergency plans and take responsibility for safety.

CONTENT: All new construction should be fire-resistant. In times of high threat, we should implement emergency fire-hardening measures and strengthen community preparedness. Additionally, we need to invest in advanced fire suppression technologies and improve our infrastructure to better protect our communities.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need fire-resistant construction standards and better emergency preparedness. Investing in advanced fire suppression technology and infrastructure improvements will help protect our community during high-risk periods.

CONTENT: If there is brush and debris that can ignite, make sure it is removed. It's silly to not to protect the areas where rebuilding will take place
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to clear brush and debris before rebuilding - it's common sense to remove these fire hazards to protect new construction areas.

CONTENT:
If all of the homes that will be rebuilt are required to have sprinklers and water systems, then the State of California needs to subsidize the added cost of that for rebuilding survivors of the fires.  

Or, waivers need to be given so that the County of LA can allow its communities to rebuild many of the historic homes that were lost, without adding to the burden of the rebuild.  

This can be addressed in many ways, via grants, tax rebates and tax amnesty programs.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to rebuild our historic homes but can't afford new fire safety requirements. State needs to help with costs through subsidies, waivers, grants, or tax programs.

CONTENT: I'm sure there are already countless brochures on fire-resistant design.  Have them made available for contractors to present to customers.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to better distribute existing fire-resistant design information to contractors so they can share these resources with their customers during projects.

CONTENT: There were too many articles being written about how severely understaffed the L.A. Fire Department is in regards to the area they serve. Staff appropriately. This seems like a no brainer seeing as we already passed the 1.5C threshold of global warming, which means our fire seasons will only get worse. Create an actual physical emergency system (like the ones they built in areas of the country that experience tornadoes). We need a better way. Also - the state needs to make a concerted effort to GET RID OF LAWNS. Stop using up all our water to water grass lawns. We need to educate people about the importance of planting NATIVE PLANTS. They are adapted to the region, save water, and provide fire resilience. It's a win for everyone!
LLM_SUMMARY: LAFD is severely understaffed for our area, which is dangerous as fire seasons worsen. We need better emergency systems, and must replace water-wasting lawns with fire-resil

CONTENT:
Preventing future disasters should be 1st priority. Get power lines underground, create highly accessible documentation around how to build a fire-resistant home, enforce new landscaping regulations to minimize spread potential.

Refining our ability to respond should they arise again should be 2nd. Provide LA residents with a 5-minute video explaining what to do in case of a future fire, perform an in-depth postmortem analyzing the emergency team response and determine any process changes that should be made.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to prioritize prevention through underground power lines, fire-resistant building guides, and landscaping rules, while also improving emergency response through better public education and response analysis.

CONTENT: Yes on Firebreaks. Yes, fund community fire prevention programs that fire audit every single property and help property owners meet code -not punitively but to help them not loose their homes-. As for holding government accountable, they can start by answering why a for profit monopoly backed by taxpayer insurance is allowed to be the sole provider of a necessary service such as electricity and not have to upgrade their equipment, invest in monitoring tech, hire more employees and still run hi power lines over bone dry, inaccessible wilderness that borders one of the most densely populated mega cities in the country while being seemingly unprepared for well forecasted red flag events.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need funded fire prevention programs and property audits to help homeowners, not punish them. Edison must be held accountable for running dangerous power lines through dry wilderness near populated areas.

CONTENT: Sprinklers inside and out.  Rules for removing all flammable materials from house perimeter. Vents at chest level so they can be sealed conveniently as necessary. Instructions and training on how to do this for homeowners and renters.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need clear rules and training for home fire prevention - installing proper sprinklers, removing flammables, and managing vents. Both owners and renters should know what to do.

CONTENT:
Altadena doesn't have a local government to speak of. 
More safety regulations are better, but they should be made convenient to implement rather than bureaucratic brick walls.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need safety regulations for recovery, but they must be practical and easy to implement, especially since Altadena lacks local government structure to manage complex processes.

CONTENT: It's essential that we have a water system capable of fighting wildfires and an electric system that doesn't spark them, but the costs shouldn't be borne by utility customers in safer areas. Pay for wildfire upgrades to this infrastructure using higher property taxes on the homeowners who chose to buy and build in dangerous areas. If you want to take the risk by choosing to live in wildfire zones, you'd better pay for it. That would also help people better understand the tradeoffs they're making.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need better water and electrical systems for wildfires, but high-risk area homeowners should pay for these upgrades through property taxes, not all utility customers.

CONTENT: There needs to be coordination across wildfire related strategic plans (WMPs, CWPPs, etc.) so that we have an integrated approach.  We also need to measure our risks and risk reduction tactics in accordance with quality assurance best practices.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need better coordination between different wildfire prevention plans and proper measurement of risk reduction efforts using quality assurance standards to ensure an effective integrated approach.

CONTENT: These are important not because the government is our savior, but because individuals and private sector can do them.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government isn't the solution - individuals and private sector should take the lead on housing and rebuilding efforts after the fire.

CONTENT: I was stunned to hear how many homes likely burned because of the mesh over the venting areas in roofs/attics. It seems clear this was a known issue -- instead of insurance companies canceling people, why not spend money on homeowner safety education? If people knew replacing that mesh might save their home, you're telling me more people wouldn't do it? Yet I never heard of that until these terrible fires. And if we don't do the work ahead of time -- firebreaks, education, and routinely evaluating the readiness of our agencies, then another disaster will happen, and I'm not sure how much more this state can take.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that critical fire safety information, like replacing roof vent mesh, isn't better communicated. Insurance companies should focus on prevention education rather than cancellations. We need proactive preparation to

CONTENT: There is an existing program called California Volunteers, and California Climate Corps. These organizations should be leveraged as a part of many on-the-ground prevention and recovery efforts.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should utilize existing volunteer programs like California Volunteers and Climate Corps for wildfire prevention and recovery work on the ground.

CONTENT: We need more community outreach and education, especially at the grade school level. People should have a firm understanding about the landscape of the land around them and how fire is part of that landscape. More remote monitoring stations and staffed fire lookout towers need to be placed in fire risk zones. And early warning systems that are not reliant on a 3rd party private social media platform.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need better fire education starting in schools, more monitoring stations and lookout towers in risk zones, and reliable early warning systems that don't depend on social media.

CONTENT: The state needs to be purchasing land from homeowners or doing parcel swaps to get people out of the WUI.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need the state to buy out properties or swap land parcels to relocate residents away from wildland-urban interface areas where fire risk is highest.

CONTENT: Fed and State need to give municipalities mandates AND resources to address natural disasters. There need to be timelines and requirements. There needs to be more public awareness. There were a lot of warning signs - the insurance companies cancelling policies was the canary in the coal mine and government should have acted more swiftly. Too many devastating fires have happened in a short span of timeframe to not know there is a problem. Local government needs to be transparent about the shortcomings. A lot of good bills are being introduced this year but there's still a lot of gaps like HOAs. We are in a dire situation which is likely to get worse after these stopgap measures end like moratoriums on insurance carriers dropping insured.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government needs to mandate and fund disaster preparedness with clear timelines. Insurance cancellations were a warning sign. Despite new legislation, gaps remain and the situation will worsen when temporary measures expire.

CONTENT: There should be firebreaks. Clear forest from nearby subdivisions and communities. Clear underbrush from forest floors. Consider prescribed burns.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need proper forest management through firebreaks, clearing vegetation near communities, and using prescribed burns to prevent future disasters.

CONTENT: Watch Duty should be publicly funded
LLM_SUMMARY: We need public funding for Watch Duty - it's an essential emergency communication tool that everyone relies on during fires.

CONTENT: More community involvement in fire prevention, locally....we can all contribute something to the process.  We live in these foothills.  The foothills need us to be good stewards.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need more local community involvement in fire prevention. As foothill residents, we all have a responsibility to be good stewards and contribute to protecting our area.

CONTENT: There is an existing program called California Volunteers, and within that, California Climate Corps. These already funded and populated programs should be leveraged as a part of on-the-ground prevention and recovery efforts including neighbor-to-neighbor networks (so we can look out for each other), and education.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should utilize existing California Volunteers and Climate Corps programs for wildfire prevention, recovery, and building neighborhood support networks, rather than starting from scratch.

CONTENT: Yes all of us need to be aware of the damage and also have accountability for the actions that we do or don't do thank you wanda
LLM_SUMMARY: We all need to take responsibility for our actions and inactions when it comes to preventing wildfire damage in our community.

CONTENT: Grants are essential, but they need to be more accessible to individual people. We’re seeing a lot of money go to “organizations”, but the people need it directly. We don’t need funded services that are difficult to access, we need cash in hand to meet our needs.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that recovery funds go to organizations instead of directly to affected individuals. Want easier access to cash grants so we can address our immediate needs ourselves.

CONTENT: I'm happy to chip in my share of taxes towards rebuilding, especially in Altadena where the residents are not nearly as rich as in the Palisades. But the lion's share of the costs need to be paid by the people who want to live in these dangerous fire zones.
LLM_SUMMARY: Willing to contribute tax money for rebuilding, especially in less wealthy Altadena, but believe primary financial responsibility should fall on those choosing to live in high-risk fire areas.

CONTENT: Expedite PCH redesign, while the opportunity exists, and a boulevard instead of a speedway will ensue. Underground all utilities throughout Malibu. Allow controlled burns around neighborhoods in Malibu.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to take advantage of this moment to redesign PCH as a safer boulevard, put utilities underground, and allow controlled burns to protect Malibu neighborhoods.

CONTENT: Near a city, regular controlled fires when weather is cooperative should be implemented. Cloud seeding should start in December.  All of LA is a dry zone...let's not stand by and watch it burn again and again when we know how to remove fuel for fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need proactive measures like controlled burns near cities and cloud seeding in winter. Can't just watch LA repeatedly burn when we know how to reduce fire fuel.

CONTENT: Yes, when it happens. But if we Make massive fires impossible or near impossible, this isn't even needed.  Unlike earthquakes, hurricanes and mudslides - FIRES ARE ENTIRELY SNUFFABLE AND PREVENTABLE
LLM_SUMMARY: Debris removal isn't the real issue - we need to focus on preventing fires in the first place since they're completely preventable, unlike other natural disasters.

CONTENT: Brush clearance and defensible space around home.  Enforcement is key so that weak links do not put the larger community at risk.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need strict enforcement of brush clearance rules around homes - when some neighbors don't comply, it puts our whole community at risk during fires.

CONTENT: To mitigate the risk of fire, all utilities that can cause ignition must be hardened. The utility companies must be responsible for this without expectations of reimbursement. The utility companies should have these safeguards built in if they want to do business. All new buildings must have fire resistant design, assuring that materials used are not toxic when exposed to fire. Areas prone to wildfire should not be rebuilt without technologies that reduce the danger.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need utility companies to fireproof their equipment at their own cost, and ensure new construction uses fire-resistant, non-toxic materials. High-risk areas must incorporate protective technologies.

CONTENT: Fire-resistant construction materials exist. Require their use in fire-prone areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need mandatory fire-resistant building materials in at-risk areas to better protect our communities from wildfires.

CONTENT: This could be a strategic community effort rather than each individual homeowner having to go at it alone, which also strains the insurance systems, which in turn raises costs down the road.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should tackle insurance and recovery as a coordinated community effort, not individually. Working alone puts strain on insurance systems and drives up everyone's costs.

CONTENT: Habitat restoration can wait. In fact brush clearance needs to happen to keep humans safe not mice and rats.
LLM_SUMMARY: Prioritize human safety through brush clearance over habitat restoration. Wildlife concerns are secondary to protecting people from fire danger.

CONTENT: We should be investing in new ideas for fire mitigation strategies. For example, insuring a home from fire could be cheaper if the home has a built-in (or on) fire protection system that significantly improves its odds of surviving a fire. We could incentivize the free market to explore new technologies or ideas through grants or subsidies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to see insurance companies offer lower rates for homes with built-in fire protection systems. Government should incentivize new fire mitigation technologies through grants and subsidies.

CONTENT: Our utilities keep causing these devastating fires and they are getting worse with climate change. We need to revise building codes, fix our utilities, clear hazard brush while maintaining wild lands and native plants, create mandatory setbacks, remove palm trees and begin to prepare for the reality we now face. We need roof top sprinklers and water agencies with infrastructure with redundancies that can accommodate extreme use in wildfire events. It could be an earthquake that cuts off water next time. We need more firefighting resources and water is critical in this!
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities cause devastating fires, worsened by climate change. We need updated building codes, brush clearing, better infrastructure, and more firefighting resources - especially reliable water systems for emergencies.

CONTENT: Holding homeowners accountable for not clearing their properties or areas around their homes. Having defensible space.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to enforce property owners' responsibility to maintain defensible space and clear vegetation around their homes to prevent fires from spreading.

CONTENT: I strongly believe in shared responsibility. As much as people want to rebuild as quick as possible, it's everyone's responsibility to build back to prevent the next great disaster.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need everyone to take responsibility and not just rush to rebuild. Making our community more resilient against future fires should be our shared priority.

CONTENT: We are middle income family-working class.  We need grants and we need the help.
LLM_SUMMARY: Struggling working-class family seeking financial assistance through grants to help recover from wildfire impacts.

CONTENT: Affordable fire resistant building supplies for all. bi-monthly meetings for residents with officials to provide new improvements to help those who live in fire prone areas
LLM_SUMMARY: Need affordable fire-resistant materials and regular community meetings with officials to better protect fire-prone neighborhoods and keep residents informed of safety improvements.

CONTENT: increased fuel maintenance and removal in non-fire seasons.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need more proactive brush clearing and fuel reduction during safe seasons to prevent future fires.

CONTENT: In my community, drought and beetle infestation have led to tons of dead trees, fuel for wildfires. But tree removal is very expensive, and many residents simply can't afford to cut down and remove the dead trees on their properties. PG&E spent a lot of $ taking down trees near power lines, and that's good (though those lines should all be underground), but there are thousands that need to come down that are not near the lines. FireWise grants have helped, but much more needs to be done.
LLM_SUMMARY: Can't afford to remove numerous dead trees killed by drought and beetles on our properties. While PG&E removed some near power lines, thousands remain as dangerous fire fuel.

CONTENT: Maybe on a community level thru religious affiliations and other community organizations but not the county not city
LLM_SUMMARY: Prefer getting emotional support through religious and community organizations rather than government agencies - feel they're more accessible and trustworthy at the local level.

CONTENT: Hold power companies to strict guidelines and penalties for failure to maintain safety. Hold individuals as well as companies responsible for obvious neglect.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need strict enforcement and penalties for both power companies and individuals who neglect fire safety guidelines and maintenance responsibilities.

CONTENT: Brush clearance requirements should be clearer and mandatory.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need stricter, mandatory brush clearance rules - the current requirements aren't clear enough to help protect our community.

CONTENT: Utilities must be held accountable. Insurance should only be valid for those who follow best fire safe practices.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to enforce accountability for utility companies and link insurance coverage to homeowners' compliance with fire safety measures.

CONTENT: The Electrical Grid is responsible for causing fires. Get rid of it. Generate solar power on buildings. Promote Aptera cars and Personal Rapid Transit which use NO net energy. Zone in passive houses which use 10% of energy of conventional ones. Fund the design of cheaper ways to build them and retrofit existing ones.  Fund the development of low energy, low water appliances. Stop focusing on local issues. LA is the 2nd biggest city in USA. CA is the 4th biggest economy in the world. Develop long term *solutions* for everyone, not just local band-aids.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with power grid fire risks, I want systemic changes: solar power, energy-efficient housing, and sustainable transportation. LA needs large-scale solutions, not just local fixes.

CONTENT: Need community coordination of these efforts and either make it mandatory (part of building code) or offer financial incentives to harden homes against fire. Loosen some aspects of code/standards that are preventing us from staggering homes on lots to reduce structure-to-structure fire risk.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want better community coordination for fire-hardening homes - either mandate it or provide incentives. Current building codes are too rigid and prevent safer home spacing to reduce fire spread.

CONTENT: And not just fire resistant - we need fire shelters in every part of the city because if... Palisades happened after midnight - many people would have died. We can and must avoid a Paradise disaster.
LLM_SUMMARY: We urgently need fire shelters throughout the city to prevent mass casualties during nighttime fires. We can't risk a Paradise-type disaster happening here.

CONTENT:
We already had a shortage of construction labor b4 the disaster

There is an opportunity here to create 1,000s of jobs & numerous small biz's
                               
LA Economic & Workforce Dept needs to implement a strategic workforce development initiative, including the formation of small biz    

Work skill/biz courses could be offered tuition free at LAUSD's 13 adult education/trade schools

Fed/State/NGO small biz assistance, funding/grants can be combined to fund the outfitting of the small companies which will drive the recovery

We don't need master carpenters, but workers who can assemble prefab, install ADUs, living pods, appliances etc. & connect them 2 utilities

Let residents drive the recovery, not big const firms..
LLM_SUMMARY: Need to create local jobs and small businesses through workforce training programs and funding, focusing on basic construction skills to help residents lead recovery instead of large contractors.

CONTENT:
Who pays for this? This isn't a solution. It's playing with knives all day and asking for a box of bandaids.

The solution is to build more housing BEFORE disasters so all citizens have homes. The next step is to harden homes in fire zones. The most important step after that is to have a commitment between govt agencies on managing debris, dried out trees, and flammable fuels from the outskirts and inner parts of communities so these fires don't get so out of control.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building more pre-disaster housing and hardening existing homes is crucial. We need better coordination between agencies to manage vegetation and prevent fires, not just react afterward.

CONTENT: Power lines should be underground.  People have been urging Edison to do this for decades.  Edison has become expert at deflection when asked about this, but no progress has been made.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that Edison hasn't moved power lines underground despite decades of community requests. They keep deflecting instead of making needed infrastructure changes to prevent fires.

CONTENT: Roads must be accessible during low visibility. When a neighborhood is rebuilt, make it pedestrian friendly. ALL power lines should be buried. Water must be easily accessible by firefighters. Metro broadband with power backup should be available for rapid reliable communication.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need buried power lines, accessible roads in poor visibility, and reliable water access for firefighters. New development should prioritize pedestrian safety and backup communications infrastructure.

CONTENT: Long term building efforts have to be fire safe to move forward. That being said, there needs to be MUCH LESS red tape involved for us to get our communities back.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need fire-safe rebuilding standards, but excessive bureaucracy is seriously delaying our community's recovery. The permitting process must be streamlined to help us rebuild faster.

CONTENT: Rebuild the homes and business will follow
LLM_SUMMARY: Basic rebuilding of homes needs to happen first - that's what will naturally bring business activity back to our area.

CONTENT: undergrounding power lines is not the answer.  want to see our rates go up by 3x with little benefit?  we need to realize that living in a high fire hazard zone means more power outages during high wind events.  We should be shutting off major power lines during these events.  back-up power should be widespread via dual fuel homes.
LLM_SUMMARY: Accept more frequent power shutoffs during high winds as part of living in fire zones. Focus on backup power solutions and dual fuel homes instead of costly undergrounding projects.

CONTENT:
The power lines in Altadena MUST BE BURIED. The transmission lines that run along the foothills must be rerouted. 

This Eaton Fire distaster cannot be allowed to happen again because a utility failed to de-energize the transmission lines.  That is no longer a tolerable scenario.  

The County, State and Federal Government must support this.
LLM_SUMMARY: Demanding underground power lines in Altadena and rerouting of foothill transmission lines to prevent future fires. Government must act - we can't risk another disaster from failed utility management.

CONTENT: LA city needs to be creating best practices for restoring basic infrastructure to fire zones *and* applying rebuilding practices elsewhere in the city where streetlights, sidewalks, power lines are in such bad shape the city cannot function.
LLM_SUMMARY: City must improve infrastructure restoration after fires and apply those same standards citywide - our basic utilities and infrastructure are failing everywhere, not just in burn zones.

CONTENT:
Promoting the PACE-Property Assessed Clean Energy program and  encouraging residents to rebuild with solar roof tiles would be helpful These materials are more fire resistant & widespread deployment would reduce the strain on the grid

If not solar tiles, other roofing materials that are inherently fire resistant and manufactured using a circular process should be used

LA Rises or another PPP should be assigned the task of bundling the orders  for the materials  They could acquire them @ wholesale prices & distribute them @ cost

PACE could lower costs by using blended finance vehicles incorporating grant $ & concessionary capital to fund projects

These discounts along with fed/state incentives & grants would significantly reduce cost
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to rebuild with fire-resistant solar tiles and other sustainable materials using PACE financing and bulk purchasing programs to make it affordable through combined incentives and grants.

CONTENT: Fire resistant materials. Landscaping strategies that maximize beauty and safety. Neighborhood-wide mitigation efforts, not just on individual properties. Recognition of adaptation as a community effort, not just home by home. Permeable surfaces, bioswales, rain gardens.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need community-wide approaches to fire safety, from resistant building materials to coordinated landscaping. Individual property changes aren't enough - adaptation must be a collective effort.

CONTENT: I have a significant concern that the resources and labor pool will be heavily impacted when so many of us are rebuilding at the same time and the resulting cost increases will make it impossible for so many.
LLM_SUMMARY: Worried that simultaneous rebuilding efforts will strain available resources and drive up construction costs, making recovery unaffordable for many affected residents.

CONTENT: Undergrounding/hardening infrastructure. Encouraging development in existing urban areas rather than expanding into wildland interface.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to focus on putting power lines underground and strengthening infrastructure, while limiting new development in fire-prone areas near wilderness.

CONTENT: Bury ALL power lines. No overheads. Ensure future safety.
LLM_SUMMARY: Strongly advocate for complete undergrounding of power lines as a critical safety measure to prevent future fires.

CONTENT: Installing more lines underground would help reduce future risks too
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines would help prevent future fire risks.

CONTENT: Underground, underground power lines! 100%
LLM_SUMMARY: We absolutely need to put power lines underground - this is essential for preventing future fires.

CONTENT: Insuring that we don't lose the greenery in the process of recovery (because it is cheaper and easier to cut it all down).  That will make these communities prone to new disasters and would make us less climate resilient (e.g. heatwaves in September and October with no shade and humidity anywhere!!!!!!)
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about maintaining greenery during recovery, as removing it all would make us vulnerable to future disasters and less climate resilient, especially during intense heat waves.

CONTENT:
There are many L.A. residents who would be willing to do the work of creating firebreaks.

The biggest problem we face in disaster recovery is not a lack of resources, but a lack of coordination between federal, state and local agencies.   A public-private partnership like L.A. Rises should be created for this specific purpose.

As of last year, approximately 2,500 of the 18,000+ structures destroyed in the Camp Fire in Northern California had been rebuilt.
This is unacceptable, especially considering the massive amount of government/private human, financial and material resources that we have available.
LLM_SUMMARY: Willing residents could help create firebreaks, but bureaucratic coordination between agencies is the real obstacle. We have resources but need better organization, like a public-private partnership, to improve disaster recovery

CONTENT: don't allow wood as a building material
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to stop using wood in construction - it's too dangerous for fire-prone areas.

CONTENT: Super infrared detectors with AI intelligence to notice ANY dangerous signs of heat, fire, smoke and signal an immediate response from a 'SWAT' team that is entirely focused and on alert to snuff out any fires or flames before they can spread. Or issue tickets and fines, even prison, for anyone lighting dangerous fires. Northern US and canadian cities divert construction infrastructure to snow removal in winter. We must divert resources & attention to be on hyper alert & vigilance in dry high fire risk
LLM_SUMMARY: We need AI-powered early detection systems and rapid response teams dedicated to fire prevention, plus strict enforcement against fire starters. Like snow removal up north, fire prevention should be our infrastructure priority.

CONTENT: ADUs have destroyed neighborhoods and contributed to dense communities and they have not alleviated rising rents or 'housing shortages'. If a homeowner is faced with a catastrophe and have lost their home, the government must not implement harsh and costly upgrades if the homeowner wants to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that ADUs haven't solved housing issues while making neighborhoods more crowded. Government shouldn't burden homeowners with expensive upgrade requirements when rebuilding after losing homes to fires.

CONTENT: We cannot rebuild LA without putting measures in place to mitigate these natural disasters in the future. There will be more fires, flood, earthquakes and no Tsunami's
LLM_SUMMARY: We need preventive measures against future disasters as we rebuild. More fires and other natural disasters are inevitable - we must prepare our community for these challenges.

CONTENT: Our utilities keep causing these devastating fires and they are getting worse with climate change. We need to fix our utilities to prevent these fires from starting again, clear hazard brush while maintaining wild lands and native plants, create mandatory setbacks, remove palm trees and begin to prepare for the reality we now face. We need roof top sprinklers and water agencies with infrastructure with redundancies that can accommodate extreme use in wildfire events. We need water and power to adapt to climate change and build infrastructure that shuts down without starting fires and keeps water running during fires. What happens if there is an earthquake during red flag high winds? I fear for my state.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities must be upgraded to prevent fires and adapt to climate change. We need better infrastructure with redundant water systems, mandatory setbacks, and brush management while preserving native habitat.

CONTENT: We should buy out homeowners in these areas and turn unsafe zones back into wilderness. If they want to stay, they should have to pay for the true cost.
LLM_SUMMARY: Advocate for buying out homeowners in high-risk areas to restore wilderness, or make residents pay actual costs if they choose to stay in fire-prone zones.

CONTENT: Minimize unnecessary bureaucratic obstacles in California while maintaining the integrity of the building process.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want less red tape and bureaucracy in California's rebuilding process, but still need to keep important safety standards and building integrity in place.

CONTENT: Edison must underground power lines
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines need to be buried underground by Edison to prevent fires.

CONTENT: Utilities need to move fast. Should be incentivized with a reduced lawsuit if they move fast.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities companies should be motivated to restore services quickly after fires through reduced legal liability - this would speed up our recovery process.

CONTENT: Needs to be expedited, Phase 2 is only 3% done.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by extremely slow progress of Phase 2 debris removal efforts, with only 3% completed so far. Process needs to move much faster.

CONTENT: As everyone knows, the red tape is insane, permitting costs are insane, construction costs, architects -- if anyone is able to rebuild in Altadena it will be a miracle.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by overwhelming costs and bureaucracy involved in rebuilding - from permits to construction to architects. Doubts whether anyone can realistically afford to rebuild in Altadena.

CONTENT: Let's get rid of red tape and modernize while we are at it.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want officials to cut bureaucracy and use this opportunity to upgrade infrastructure during the rebuilding process.

CONTENT: many are under insured if insured at all, must rebuild rapidly for people to afford to move back
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance coverage is inadequate or nonexistent for many residents. Quick rebuilding is essential so people can afford to return to their homes.

CONTENT: Building back the same houses in the same spaces without adjustments just means our town will burn in the same way in 20 years. Also, all those ADUs people will be living in just mean no parking and a lack of safe roads in another emergency.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned that rebuilding without changes and adding ADUs will recreate same fire risks and evacuation challenges. Want smarter development that considers future emergency access and safety.

CONTENT: Waive unnecessary rules and regulations.
LLM_SUMMARY: Just cut through the red tape and bureaucracy - we need utilities restored quickly without getting caught up in unnecessary regulations and paperwork.

CONTENT: To prevent future wildfires the powerlines should move underground where able and removing gas line infrastructure in the burned-out areas. Those two actions would greatly reduce the ability for future fires to arise in the area. Improvement of the community is also critically important, they went through a tragic time and the community is partially broken. Lets build it back better than ever, by offering equal access to forms of active transportation (biking/walking). Expand the network of walkable streets, add bike lanes and ensure streets are engineered safely.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need underground power lines and gas line removal to prevent future fires. While rebuilding our community, let's improve it with better walking paths and bike lanes.

CONTENT: We all know what we would prefer our communities "look" like, but recognizing the hazards of where we live and HOW we need to build in preparation for those hazards is more important than our cultural ideal of a neighborhood. People should be willing to accept some change in how we construct buildings and develop larger settlements/communities so that fire protection can take priority.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must prioritize fire-safe construction and community development over traditional neighborhood aesthetics. Our cultural preferences should adapt to address the real hazards we face in these areas.

CONTENT: Ensure long-term rebuilding is climate-smart, denser, resilient to future fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to rebuild smarter - with higher density housing that can better withstand future fires and climate challenges.

CONTENT:
Reduce onerous building regulations. California citizens affected homeowners should be given preference 
.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want less restrictive building regulations and priority given to California residents affected by fires when rebuilding.

CONTENT: Make every effort to inventivize updated materials for fire preventions.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need incentives for people to upgrade to fire-resistant building materials to better protect our community.

CONTENT: All new construction should be fire-resistant. In times of high threat, we should implement emergency fire-hardening measures and strengthen community preparedness. Additionally, we need to invest in advanced fire suppression technologies and improve our infrastructure to better protect our communities.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must require fire-resistant construction, enhance emergency preparedness, and invest in better fire suppression technology to protect our communities from increasing wildfire threats.

CONTENT: I'd like to see public support/subsidies for roofing and building materials that resist fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want government help to make homes more fire-resistant through subsidies for protective building materials and roofing upgrades.

CONTENT: Consider using this opportunity to bury all community power lines (as is done elsewhere). Consider sourcing water from the Pacific ocean (via desalination) if the area groundwater aquifers are negatively impacted as a result of the fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should take this chance to improve infrastructure by burying power lines and exploring desalination options in case fire damage affects our groundwater supply.

CONTENT: I'm not sure how much difference fire-resistant design would have made.  If fire-resistant design means infusing building materials with toxic substances that will go up in smoke if the fire is strong enough, then I think that is misguided.  At least in this case, much more effort should have been put into putting the power lines underground.  People have been urging Edison to do this for decades.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines should have been the priority, not fire-resistant building materials that could release toxic chemicals. Edison ignored community requests for this crucial safety measure.

CONTENT: Obviously underground electric is of major importance. The others would be nice but not a necessity to repopulating the area. Soil test should also be done on each property. I don't want to eat fruit and vegetables grown in contaminated soil.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are essential for returning home. Other infrastructure can wait. Concerned about soil contamination affecting home gardening and food safety.

CONTENT: Also, the extreme weather patterns are not new, they have been causing more fires more recently. The most devastating fires in CA have happened within the last 35 years. Cities should be mandated to update their risk models - not using 20 year old data - and updated general plans to include wildfire adaptation.
LLM_SUMMARY: Climate change is intensifying California's fire patterns. Cities need to modernize their risk assessments and planning to properly adapt to this growing wildfire threat, not rely on outdated data.

CONTENT: Underground power! Although it's shockingly expensive. Streetlights need to be subdued to prevent light pollution.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want underground power lines despite high costs. Concerned about excessive streetlight brightness contributing to light pollution.

CONTENT:
Modular, low-cost, ecologically-sound housing, manufactured en masse in our backyard. See SoLA Model Z in South Los Angeles as one excellent example. They are walking the walk and ready to plug in (I toured their factory last week)  

Also would love to see novel ideas for neighborhoods to rebuild together, not only to gain economy of scale and efficiency with materials, etc. but to plan housing layouts in a new way. Perhaps one block with 10 homes each sacrifices 10% of footprint to allow for one communal lot to be used with more of a "village" mentality i.e small farming, open space for kids, etc. This may seem utopic, but I think many people are close to being in this mindset already. If we can rebuild, let's try it differently!
LLM_SUMMARY: Want affordable, eco-friendly modular housing built at scale, with neighborhoods rebuilding together to create communal spaces. We should rethink traditional layouts for a more village-like community approach.

CONTENT:
If all of the homes that will be rebuilt are required to have sprinklers and water systems, then the State of California needs to subsidize the added cost of that for rebuilding survivors of the fires.  

Or, waivers need to be given so that the County of LA can allow its communities to rebuild many of the historic homes that were lost, without adding to the burden of the rebuild.  

This can be addressed in many ways, via grants, tax rebates and tax amnesty programs.
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuilding costs are too high with new fire safety requirements. The state needs to help fire survivors through subsidies, waivers, grants, or tax programs to offset these expenses.

CONTENT: This cannot stand in the way of rapid rebuilding or be abused by interest groups to block rebuilding.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned that environmental regulations and debris removal requirements could delay rebuilding efforts and be misused to obstruct community recovery after the fire.

CONTENT: I'm sure there are already countless brochures on fire-resistant design.  Have them made available for contractors to present to customers.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to make existing fire-resistant design resources more accessible to contractors so they can share these options with their customers during building projects.

CONTENT: In our case we are adding an ADU to stay on our property and avoid having to pay for a mortgage and rent elsewhere at the same time. However we're hearing that permitting is SLOW at the moment so are concerned.
LLM_SUMMARY: Worried about slow permitting process while trying to build an ADU on our property. Need this solution to avoid paying both mortgage and rent during rebuilding.

CONTENT: Yes on Firebreaks. Yes, fund community fire prevention programs that fire audit every single property and help property owners meet code -not punitively but to help them not loose their homes-. As for holding government accountable, they can start by answering why a for profit monopoly backed by taxpayer insurance is allowed to be the sole provider of a necessary service such as electricity and not have to upgrade their equipment, invest in monitoring tech, hire more employees and still run hi power lines over bone dry, inaccessible wilderness that borders one of the most densely populated mega cities in the country while being seemingly unprepared for well forecasted red flag events.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with SCE's monopoly and lack of accountability. Want better fire prevention through property audits and support programs. Utility companies must upgrade infrastructure and improve preparedness in high-risk areas

CONTENT: Comprehensive testing of the soil in and near the burn zones is essential. The state needs to coordinate and pay for this. This impacts those of us who have houses standing as well as those who want to rebuild. We want to ensure that we aren't living in a hazmat site, and without testing, we won't know for sure. Failure to test and remediate properly now will have terrible health impacts later, and will also have negative impacts on our property values.
LLM_SUMMARY: Soil testing in burn zones is crucial for everyone's safety and property values. The state must fund and coordinate testing to ensure we're not living in hazardous conditions.

CONTENT: Incentivize communities to make improvements that will make homes more robust in the face of environmental dangers.
