LLM_SUMMARY: We need incentives for communities to strengthen homes against environmental threats, making them more resilient to disasters like wildfires.

CONTENT: It's essential that we have a water system capable of fighting wildfires and an electric system that doesn't spark them, but the costs shouldn't be borne by utility customers in safer areas. Pay for wildfire upgrades to this infrastructure using higher property taxes on the homeowners who chose to buy and build in dangerous areas. If you want to take the risk by choosing to live in wildfire zones, you'd better pay for it. That would also help people better understand the tradeoffs they're making.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need better water and power systems for wildfires, but high-risk area residents should pay for upgrades through property taxes, not all utility customers. Make people understand the cost of their choices

CONTENT: Developers MUST build in only the right places and create only the right structures -- this is something ordinary people cannot be trusted to determine.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building location and structural requirements for new development should be strictly regulated by experts, not left to individual property owners' discretion.

CONTENT: We have given them billions in subsidies and tax breaks. It's time they bury all the lines since we have paid for them to do it but they always get out of actually doing it because it's expensive. You know what's far more expensive? Getting sued by every resident because the root cause was their power lines.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fed up with utilities getting subsidies but avoiding power line burial. They need to be held accountable - the cost of lawsuits from fire damage far exceeds infrastructure upgrades.

CONTENT: That's too many subjects in one query.  Critical is home rebuilding and long-term solutions.  At the least, relaxed construction limited hours for 2 years will enable round the clock work for those willing to do it -- thus potentially reducing the time for completion to less than 6 months.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want faster home rebuilding after fires. Relaxing construction hour limits for 2 years would allow 24/7 work, potentially cutting rebuild time to under 6 months.

CONTENT: now is the time to pass stricter wildfire and flood protection building codes along with green/sustainable building requirements.  With thousands of structures needing to be replaced, now is the time to set Los Angeles as a model for the nation. Traditional AND alternative methods of power and water collection/delivery must be put into place. Look to other leading nations for best practices - for example there is an area in Japan that has it's own outdoor fire suppression system that can be activated (not like individuals with pools and hoses and generators) like an advanced outdoor high-powered sprinkler system.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need stricter building codes for wildfire protection and sustainability. This rebuilding opportunity could make LA a model city, with advanced infrastructure like Japan's community-wide fire suppression systems.

CONTENT: I don't understand why we have above ground power lines in fire prone areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that dangerous overhead power lines still exist in fire-prone zones, questioning why underground alternatives haven't been implemented for community safety.

CONTENT:
Building methods—


There’s a huge opportunity for LA to rebuild using sustainable fire safe building methods. For the sake of the entire state, proven building methods, using straw bale, hempcrete, etc could be employed to demonstrate that we don’t need to continue in our previously standard methods that burn down so easily and are costing a fortune to insure. 

Let’s think outside the box and not be controlled by monied interests. Let’s promote building practices and accompanying policies that make the insurance companies give major reductions to fire insurance premiums that will last in an increasingly fire prone environment.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should rebuild using sustainable, fire-resistant materials like straw bale and hempcrete, moving away from traditional methods to reduce fire risk and insurance costs in LA.

CONTENT: If it's not safe, people should not be allowed to return
LLM_SUMMARY: Safety must be the top priority before letting residents return to fire-damaged areas.

CONTENT: Debris removal, absolutely.  habitat restoration, that can wait.  Take care of the immediate needs first.
LLM_SUMMARY: Just focus on clearing the debris right now - that's the urgent priority. Habitat restoration is important but can come later after immediate cleanup needs are handled.

CONTENT: More transit-oriented development, prioritization of ecosystem health and fire resistant construction materials/design.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to focus on transit-oriented development while ensuring new construction uses fire-resistant materials and protects the ecosystem.

CONTENT: Purchase Nuccios nursery (80 acre commercial nursery backing into the chaparral hills), make it a fire management site and study the potential of building an emergency reservoir there. Develop an effective plan for managing the chaparral landscape that borders the neighborhood. Train volunteer firefighters. Come up with a plan that ensures water available for wildfire protection. Underground power lines.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to convert Nuccios nursery into a fire management site with reservoir, improve chaparral management, train volunteers, ensure water availability, and underground power lines for better protection.

CONTENT: Not taking this opportunity to improve all infrastructure in Altadena would be foolish and short sighted. I understand it’s enormously expensive, but I have confidence that if considerable effort is invested into procuring funds, this can be accomplished.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to seize this chance to upgrade Altadena's infrastructure. Yes, it's costly, but with dedicated effort to secure funding, we can make it happen.

CONTENT: It is illogical to put more people in these fire areas particularly those who cannot afford insurance or the cost of rebuilding and replacing everything.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building in high-risk fire zones is irresponsible, especially for those who can't afford insurance or recovery costs when disaster strikes.

CONTENT:
I think we should place solar air to water systems in open spaces to provide an irrigation source to make large swathes of historic fuel sources evergreen instead.

I also agree that power lines should be buried whenever possible, or mitigation strategies be devised to defend against errant ignition when equipment fails.  Cutting off power to homes and businesses as a prophylaxis is not the best strategy, since our communication and home defense capabilities suffer as well
LLM_SUMMARY: Want better wildfire prevention through solar-powered irrigation systems to maintain green spaces, plus buried power lines instead of shutoffs that leave us vulnerable during emergencies.

CONTENT: Permitting costs should be waved. We aren’t building an addition, we are rebuilding our lives after a huge tragedy. Give us a break.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that rebuilding permits cost money after losing everything. Want fees waived since we're just trying to recover from disaster, not doing optional renovations.

CONTENT:
The cost of building materials had been rising steadily for years.  With this catastrophe the demand will skyrocket and so will prices.

This is why is it imperative that a multi-layered cost reduction strategy be implemented.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned that already-high building material costs will surge even higher due to post-fire demand. Urging implementation of strategies to reduce rebuilding costs.

CONTENT: On the topic of home rebuilding, I think it is critically important that the new homes are resilient to future disaster and energy efficient. The Passive Housing Standard (being considered by state legislators AB368) would be an excellent fit with super insulation, air-tight construction and better performing windows. This eliminates the pathways the fire used to penetrate houses. Additionally it offers improved air quality, reduced noise pollution, up to 50% energy savings and resilience in power outages. The rebuilds should adhere to reach codes of no gas hookups so the community can again reduce the danger of fires and also greatly reduce emissions/air quality in the community.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to rebuild homes using Passive Housing Standards - it's safer against fires, more energy efficient, and eliminates gas hookups that pose risks. This approach protects our community and environment.

CONTENT: Climate change has made all natural events, including wild fires, more intense. We have to come to grips with the fact that there are places where NO homes should be.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must acknowledge that climate change intensifies wildfires, and accept that some areas are simply too dangerous for residential development.

CONTENT: It is important to consider fire-resistant designs when rebuilding but I think it also needs to be acknowledged that most of the parts of Altadena that burned are not generally considered fire prone. The edges of Altadena that abut wild land are areas with a higher risk but the fire that burned throughout Altadena reached areas that were and are not forested. It's a different kind of fire than we are used to talking about.
LLM_SUMMARY: Traditional fire risk zones don't apply anymore - this fire reached non-forested areas of Altadena that weren't considered fire-prone, showing we need to rethink our understanding of

CONTENT:
Considering all of the electrical batteries in EV's or hybrids that melted into the drainage system (and future ones) along with all of the hazardous materials that when burned cause new toxins to form, in addition to their regular hazardous status when not burned, this needs to be a priority.  It was not well communicated to the NIMBY's that trucks/debris etc., would be traversing their roads and/or that certain locations would be used for packaging of those materials.  Better pre-planning of sites and better communications to the communities at large would reduce these kinds of concerns.

Greater open space between residential areas and wild-land interfaces should be required to support defensible space between the areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned about toxic debris from burned vehicles and hazardous materials entering drainage systems. Better planning and communication needed for cleanup sites. More defensible space required between residential and wildland areas.

CONTENT: should not be assessed for ADU will assist folks to move back to neighborhood faster and/or could assist housing some of the trades needed to rebuild
LLM_SUMMARY: Want ADUs to be exempt from assessments - this would help residents return faster and provide housing for construction workers needed for rebuilding efforts.

CONTENT: I'm happy to chip in my share of taxes towards rebuilding, especially in Altadena where the residents are not nearly as rich as in the Palisades. But the lion's share of the costs need to be paid by the people who want to live in these dangerous fire zones.
LLM_SUMMARY: Willing to contribute tax money for rebuilding, especially in less wealthy Altadena, but believe primary financial responsibility should fall on those choosing to live in high-risk fire areas.

CONTENT: City and county planners should have pre-planned and approved site plans so residents can build back better and safer.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need pre-approved rebuilding plans from city officials so homeowners can reconstruct quickly with improved safety standards after fires.

CONTENT: The State needs to stop requiring jurisdictions to allow buildings in the very high fire zones in LA county. There is no buffer like other counties between woodlands and urban areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to stop allowing new construction in high fire risk zones and create proper buffer zones between developed areas and woodlands, like other counties do.

CONTENT: new code requirements.  go back to the 2010/2012 code requirements.  we can't afford today's requirements and they don't work for this massive rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that current building codes are too expensive for wildfire rebuilding efforts. Want to revert to 2010/2012 codes, as newer requirements are financially burdensome and imp

CONTENT: Quit building structures in places in fire prone areas.  The state and Weiner specifically have gone gun-ho in encouraging building in stupid places and passed laws which leave the local agencies powerless to design their own communities.   The population is barely growing yet there is a housing crisis. First thing OUTLAW Short Term Rental Airbnb's, tax the heck out of second/vacation homes, tax the wealthy so they cannot afford 3 and 4 homes while the rest of us are forced to rent.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated by state overriding local control to build in fire-prone areas. Want restrictions on short-term rentals and multiple home ownership to address housing crisis rather than risky development.

CONTENT: All of LADWP’s/SCE’s power lines should be buried. Access in and out of mountain communities needs to be improved, driving should not be the only option (the problem with driving being the only option for evacuation can be seen by all the abandoned cars on sunset). The state/federal govt funded a Santa Monica mountains bus service back in the 70s that snaked around mountains for a summer season, bringing that back will help alleviate congestion and can provide more evacuation alternatives.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need buried power lines and better evacuation options beyond just driving. A mountain bus service like we had in the 70s would help reduce congestion and provide alternative escape routes.

CONTENT: Study the structures that survived. Adopt these ideas in rebuilding. Don't keep rebuilding in areas that have extreme risks of fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should learn from buildings that made it through the fire and use those design elements when rebuilding, while avoiding high-risk areas altogether.

CONTENT:
1. create a public utilities system, delivering traditional and alternative forms.
2. High speed wifi should be a public utility - not a Verizon over here, AT&T over there, Spectrum in this area... all with different cables and methods of delivery and cost.  enough already.
3. move powerlines underground; zero overhead power lines. make it a law
4.invest in robust water collection and reserve methods
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated with fragmented utilities. Want unified public system, underground power lines, better water reserves. Tired of multiple competing providers for services like WiFi.

CONTENT: Our soils must be tested! This should not be the homeowner’s responsibility. We need to know that we are moving back into a safe place where we can grow food in our backyard and shower without a cancer risk down the road.
LLM_SUMMARY: Soil testing for contamination should be handled by authorities, not homeowners. We need assurance our properties are safe for gardening and daily activities without health risks.

CONTENT: I am currently considering rebuilding our home and desperately need ideas for building a more fire resistant home. I haven't seen much information about new fire retardant materials.  Or landscaping design to reduce fire encroachment. This needs to be addressed to assist survivors rebuild safer structures for the future.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need guidance on fire-resistant building materials and protective landscaping design to rebuild safer after the fire. Haven't found enough resources about these preventive measures.

CONTENT: To mitigate the risk of fire, all utilities that can cause ignition must be hardened. The utility companies must be responsible for this without expectations of reimbursement. The utility companies should have these safeguards built in if they want to do business. All new buildings must have fire resistant design, assuring that materials used are not toxic when exposed to fire. Areas prone to wildfire should not be rebuilt without technologies that reduce the danger.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need utility companies to fireproof their equipment at their own cost, and all new construction must use fire-resistant, non-toxic materials. High-risk areas should only rebuild with proper safety

CONTENT: We need expertise and help to fire harden our whole community, not just encouraging a few people with the money to do it. Also we can't insure our way out of this. Insurance companies will leave if they don't make a profit and the state can't afford to take their place with the pace and severity of disasters. Education, fire audits, financial assistance. Community immunity.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need community-wide fire hardening, not just for those who can afford it. Insurance isn't sustainable with increasing disasters. We need education, fire audits, and financial help for collective protection.

CONTENT: Building resilient energy efficient homes. Reconsidering the materials used, repurposing as much as possible. Sharing tools and resources within communities. Investment in community and School Gardens
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to build more resilient communities through energy-efficient homes, sustainable materials, resource sharing between neighbors, and investing in community gardens to strengthen local connections.

CONTENT: Relax Malibu overprotectiveness and overreach; allow small ADU’s with less code restriction, but with fire resistant materials.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want less restrictive building codes in Malibu to allow ADUs, while still requiring fire-safe materials. Current regulations are too protective and limiting.

CONTENT: There should not be so many road blocks for a tax paying citizen that has lost EVERYTHING to remove the toxic ash from their property!! Why is the city sitting on so many ROE firms and denying permits for private companies??
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that city bureaucracy and permit denials are preventing homeowners from clearing toxic debris from their properties, despite having proper right-of-entry forms and paying taxes.

CONTENT: Bury power lines and prevent costs from being passed to consumer.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want underground power lines installed but concerned about utility companies making residents pay for it through increased rates.

CONTENT: What warning systems?  Palisades had evacuation routes, only there weren't nearly enough of them.  It is shocking to me that there weren't hundreds of people killed in the Palisades.  And yet development continued on, knowing full well that the routes were grossly inadequate to carry the people out fast enough.  Criminal.
LLM_SUMMARY: Evacuation routes in Palisades were dangerously insufficient for the population, yet development continued regardless. It's miraculous there weren't mass casualties. The lack of adequate escape routes was

CONTENT: Our utilities keep causing these devastating fires and they are getting worse with climate change. We need to revise building codes, fix our utilities, clear hazard brush while maintaining wild lands and native plants, create mandatory setbacks, remove palm trees and begin to prepare for the reality we now face. We need roof top sprinklers and water agencies with infrastructure with redundancies that can accommodate extreme use in wildfire events. It could be an earthquake that cuts off water next time. We need more firefighting resources and water is critical in this!
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities cause devastating fires, worsened by climate change. We need updated building codes, brush management, better infrastructure, and more firefighting resources - especially reliable water systems for emergencies.

CONTENT: During recovery regulations must be eased to allow for housing of affected people. Temporary housing will be essential for anyone that loses a home. ADUs can play a part, as well as RVs, FEMA style trailers, etc.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need flexibility in housing regulations during recovery, with options like ADUs, RVs, and FEMA trailers to provide temporary shelter for those who've lost homes.

CONTENT: Allow RVs on property for a fixed period.  Don't create excessive government agencies for temporary issues.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to live in RV on my property while rebuilding, but facing too much red tape and bureaucracy. Need simpler temporary housing rules.

CONTENT: Underground power lines!
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to move power lines underground to protect our community from future fires.

CONTENT: Push insurance companies to simply pay out 100% on total losses, as we are all under insured anyhow.  This has occurred in prior fires, and we are desperately needing to rebuild sooner than later, so knowing a budget is key, and key now.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should pay 100% on total losses since we're all underinsured. We need to rebuild quickly and can't wait - knowing our budget is crucial right now.

CONTENT: Let's bury electrical lines (and internet and other wired infrastructure) underground, to avoid the wires being snapped and sparking in the regular wind storms we have.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want underground utilities to prevent power lines from sparking fires during windstorms - safer than current above-ground wires that can snap and cause problems.

CONTENT: My own grandmother lost her home in the Palisades Fire, so this is hard to say. But if people decide to rebuild in the exact spot their house burned down, the financial risk of repeat fire should should be borne by communities who rebuild in high risk areas. Skyrocketing insurance rates should not be distributed throughout the state to areas that have very low risk of wildfire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuilding in high-risk fire areas should come with financial responsibility. Insurance costs shouldn't burden low-risk communities when people choose to rebuild in known danger zones.

CONTENT: I strongly believe in shared responsibility. As much as people want to rebuild as quick as possible, it's everyone's responsibility to build back to prevent the next great disaster.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to balance quick rebuilding with responsible construction practices. Everyone has a duty to rebuild in ways that protect our community from future disasters.

CONTENT: Require all electrical power lines to be undergrounded in the foothills and Altadena! SCE did a lousy job of protecting the residents along the foothills.
LLM_SUMMARY: SCE needs to put power lines underground in Altadena and foothill areas. They failed to protect residents by not taking this basic safety measure.

CONTENT: Edison should make underground system for Altadena.  It will be costly, but it is necessary.  We cannot make another town like second Altadena.
LLM_SUMMARY: Edison needs to invest in underground power systems in Altadena despite the cost - it's necessary to prevent another devastating fire from destroying our community.

CONTENT: Rebuild to new codes and fire safe is not affordable. Even if you do rebuild to fire safety Insurance lies and does not insure regardless of how safe
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies won't cover homes even when rebuilt to fire-safe standards, and meeting new safety codes is too expensive for most people to afford anyway.

CONTENT: Please expedite permitting and waive the necessary fees
LLM_SUMMARY: Need faster permit processing and fee waivers to help us rebuild and recover from the fire damage.

CONTENT: It would be nice if Altadena were rebuilt to be more walkable and accessible via bike and public transportation. Let's do this right!
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to see Altadena rebuilt with better walkability, bike access, and public transit options - let's take this opportunity to improve infrastructure while rebuilding.

CONTENT: Efforts to streamline the housing re-permitting process for fire victims should be expanded to include everyone else. By making this process more efficient we could increase the supply of housing, reducing cost.
LLM_SUMMARY: The permitting process for rebuilding after fires should be streamlined not just for fire victims, but for all housing development to increase supply and reduce costs.

CONTENT: Have all power lines put underground
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to move all power lines underground to prevent future fire risks.

CONTENT: Streetlights should be solar with small batteries, so there is no copper wire to be stolen. All housing should be built with no gas, we are supposed to be all electric in Los Angeles by 2035 anyway and in California by 2045 (per SB 100) so why invest in repairing gas infrastructure that will be obsolete/stranded assets soon and a source of ignition for fires after an earthquake or other natural disaster. It is also absurd that it is 2025 and we are still flushing our toilets and irrigating our yards with drinking water, if we are rebuilding, we should do so with greywater systems that reuse water from our sinks, showers and laundry  for watering landscapes and flushing.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should rebuild smarter: solar streetlights to prevent wire theft, all-electric homes instead of repairing gas lines, and greywater systems for irrigation and toilets. No point

CONTENT: We must replant NATIVE plants that are by design much less flammable, like the California chaparral and stop cutting it down. Conversely, we must take down all palm trees down, not only they are giant match sticks when we get a wild fire, they provide little to no oxygen, they attract rodents and help the transmission of Leptospirosis, they provide little shade and now the department of sanitation wont take any of the debris from it as it takes a very long time to decompose, so that would go to a landfill to generate methane instead. We also need to consult with Native Tribes who are the original stewards of the land and used to have controlled fires to avoid having these mega fires. Private firefighters must be banned.
LLM_SUMMARY: Native plants and traditional controlled burns are essential for fire safety. Palm trees are dangerous fire hazards and create waste. We should learn from Native tribes' land management practices.

CONTENT: The new reimagined community should be better than the now-burned community.  Use smart planners and experts to implement new ideas for Palisades 2.0.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want experts to use this opportunity to rebuild Pacific Palisades with better infrastructure and modern planning, making it an improved version of the pre-fire community.

CONTENT: Building codes need to be updated to reflect the reality of wild fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to modernize building codes to address the growing wildfire threat in our area.

CONTENT: Expensive yet necessary.  Start in most fire prone areas and move outward.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to prioritize infrastructure repairs starting with high-risk fire zones, despite the costs. It's worth the investment to work outward from there.

CONTENT: Change can be difficult.  I, too, love to have plants near and around my home, but if the reality of fire risk is there...it would be selfish to refuse.  The same applies to building materials.  While I would once have scoffed at the idea of stucco siding, I now look at this as potentially a safer alternative to all wood siding.  That may or may not be true, but if I were building from scratch, I would embrace all I could learn about fire resistant design, just as I look at accessible design needs.
LLM_SUMMARY: I've learned to prioritize fire safety over aesthetics - from replacing wood siding with stucco to rethinking landscaping. We must adapt our homes to face climate realities.

CONTENT: CA get it together! Why is it always a surprise when a fire takes place? CA government should be required to meet preventative FIRE measures and I am not referring to decades to develop.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that California lacks proactive fire prevention measures and takes too long to implement solutions. Want immediate action from government on preventative strategies.

CONTENT: The Mayor of LA needs to be held accountable for the poor management of funds and water distribution. California needs to improve relations with federal government for assistance and come up with a joint plan to mitigate future occurrences. Use AI to determine hot spots and forest Management.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need better accountability from LA's mayor on fund management, improved federal cooperation for prevention, and should utilize AI technology for forest management and hotspot detection.

CONTENT: California needs to call in Federal assistance to manage the entire state. Too much of the forest is left unkept. Need to increase logging of old forest so that areas can be managed with planting of new growth. Open it up the private companies to manage.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need federal intervention and private companies to manage California's forests through increased logging and replanting. Current forest management is inadequate for preventing fires.

CONTENT: government efficiency. and i don't mean in the DOGE sense. i mean real govt efficiency in designing code that makes sense, isn't bloated, but is very focused on smart building. reducing costs. property values in the area have increased by 3x +++ in the last 30 years. has the cost of running the govt increased by 3x? there should be budget surplus. government ineffectiveness in combo with lack of high information civic participation is the root cause. adding better vent covers is important, but will not solve the underlying issues.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need smarter building codes and more efficient government spending. With property values tripling, we should have budget surplus for fire prevention, but bureaucratic inefficiency and low civic engagement are the real problems.

CONTENT: CA should just call the entire state a WUI CA Fire zone. No more pockets where CA Fire WUI regulations are not in place
LLM_SUMMARY: We need statewide wildland-urban interface fire regulations across California, not just in designated areas. The current patchwork approach isn't enough to protect communities.

CONTENT: Using materials that are CA Fire WUI compliant. Material backed by WUI testing, some products such as cement were not tested apparently and rubber stamped as an approved product. However, cement can transfer heat. Any material approved by CA Fire for WUI zones should have to be tested.
LLM_SUMMARY: Concerned that some WUI-approved building materials like cement haven't been properly tested for heat transfer. All materials used in fire zones should undergo thorough WUI testing before approval.

CONTENT: However, the environmental recovery should include a plan to establish and maintain fire breaks in the Santa Monica mountains above and around the town. The area managed by the conservancy and the state parks in the mountains are really wild animal parks, and should be treated and managed as such balancing the needs of the animals against the safety of the surrounding communities. The historical approach is resulting in larger and more frequent wildfires. So something clearly has to change.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need better fire breaks in the Santa Monica mountains and smarter management of wildlife areas. The current approach isn't working - fires are getting worse and more frequent.

CONTENT: Consistent soils testing across the community
LLM_SUMMARY: Need regular soil testing throughout our neighborhood to monitor contamination and ensure safe recovery after the fire.

CONTENT: The state of California has done a horrible job with forest management, firebreaks and accountability.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fed up with California's poor performance on forest management, firebreaks, and lack of accountability in wildfire prevention efforts.

CONTENT: I think local communities, neighborhoods and residents must also expect to be held accountable. We are all in this together.
LLM_SUMMARY: We can't just blame officials - local residents and neighborhoods need to take responsibility too. This is a shared challenge that requires everyone's accountability.

CONTENT: Underinsured homeowners can't afford the new code requirements.  Grants and tax relief should be provided to ease that burden.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that underinsurance leaves homeowners unable to meet new building codes. Want government to provide financial relief through grants and tax breaks to help rebuild.

CONTENT: Make sure every lot is cleared even if it requires imminent domain
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to clear every single affected lot, even if it means using eminent domain to access private property.

CONTENT: There should be zoning, codes, permitting and other policies that limit or eliminate building in fire-prone areas unless customers are willing to pay for the materials to be fire resilient and willing to forego the protection from standard services in the case of an emergency.
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't allow building in fire-prone areas unless homeowners use fire-resistant materials and accept they may not get emergency services during disasters.

CONTENT: Affordable fire resistant building supplies is a necessity. More native plants that aren't extremely flammable
LLM_SUMMARY: We need access to affordable fire-resistant building materials and should focus on planting native species that don't easily catch fire.

CONTENT: We need a community that can live with fire.  As I understand it, the homes built to the latest standards for materials and design, which also had appropriate defensible space, did much better than other homes in the fires.  We need to ensure that the rebuild follows these standards, which includes financing, ensuring that contractors are properly trained, appropriate materials are available, and agreements that communities rebuilt to these standards are insurable in the future.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must rebuild homes using fire-resistant materials and designs with proper defensible space. This requires financing, trained contractors, material availability, and insurance company buy-in for long-term community resilience

CONTENT: What is wildfire adaptation? Fire-resistant design and preparedness training are not the City's role; let Angelenos, their architects, and private organizations do this.
LLM_SUMMARY: Skeptical of government involvement in wildfire adaptation. Believe fire-resistant design and preparedness should be left to private citizens, architects, and organizations rather than city authorities.

CONTENT: Communities in WUI (wildland urban interface) environments should have high-powered sprinkler systems installed along their perimeters and/or throughout the community to give it extra protection in advance of a fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need high-powered sprinkler systems installed around and within WUI communities to provide better protection before fires hit. This preventive measure could save our neighborhoods.

CONTENT: Budget constraints should not impact whether or not these mitigations are completed.
LLM_SUMMARY: Prevention measures and safety mitigations must be fully funded and implemented, regardless of budget limitations. This can't be compromised due to financial constraints.

CONTENT: We need to better manage the brush lands, but they evolved to burn, so we also have ensure that our built environment can live with fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must manage brush while accepting fire's natural role. The key is making our communities more fire-resistant since complete prevention isn't realistic.

CONTENT: Every home with a pool should have a pump that will allow pool water to be accessed! In Rancho Santa Fe it is required. Insurance companies should offer incentives.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need accessible pool water pumps for firefighting, like they require in Rancho Santa Fe. Insurance companies should incentivize this to help protect our communities.

CONTENT: Provide grants to help people fire harden their homes for those who can't afford it to reduce the chances and severity of future fires
LLM_SUMMARY: We need grants to help lower-income residents fire-proof their homes - this would reduce future fire risks and protect our community's most vulnerable members.

CONTENT: Palm trees are a fire hazard, grass lawns are wasteful of water.  Incentivizing replacing both  to safer and more practical alternatives should be a priority for all of SoCal to reduce fire risk and waste of fire-fighting resources.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need incentives to replace hazardous palm trees and water-wasting lawns with safer, practical alternatives across Southern California to reduce fire risks and conserve firefighting resources.

CONTENT: Fire prevention should provide more than a diagram of brush clearance distances from homes. There should be regular communication with residents about latest fire prevention technologies and perhaps incentives built into property tax breaks for brush clearing and landscaping maintenance. Residents also need to be given information on certain trees and bushes that are more flammable.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need more than just basic brush clearance guidelines. Give us updates on new prevention technologies, tax incentives for maintenance, and information about fire-resistant plants.

CONTENT: People should be held to code and standards. I lived next to a hoarder. I reported this many times and got nowhere. I truly believe it was why my house burned down.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that my house burned down because authorities ignored reports about my neighbor's hoarding, which violated codes. Better enforcement could have prevented this disaster.

CONTENT: Strickter code requirements in regards to materials should be enforced.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building codes need to be more strictly enforced, especially regarding construction materials used in fire-prone areas.

CONTENT:
1) Firebreaks are essential no matter how ugly they are. Having a house not burn down is better than the privilege of not living next to a barren strip. 
2) I don't buy into the idea that this fire's terrible consequences were some kind of failure of government. It was a natural disaster. I'm sure we could have done better but honestly, it would have taken leaps in technology, infrastructure and manpower that we couldn't expect at the time. This wasn't governments fault. This fire was fought the way every fire is fought, the system just wasn't cut out for the job.
LLM_SUMMARY: While firebreaks may be unsightly, they're necessary for protection. This wasn't a government failure - even with better resources, this natural disaster would have overwhelmed our existing firefighting capabilities.

CONTENT:
Big yes to all of this. Everyone needs to be held accountable and changes made. 
(We are not all the few difficult ones who’ve resisted this in the past. Clear the brush. Let the community know if you need volunteers.)
LLM_SUMMARY: We need universal accountability and action on fire prevention. Most of us support brush clearance - just tell us when you need community volunteers to help.

CONTENT: We need to return to stewardship and controlled burns during seasonal and atmospheric advantageous periods.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should prioritize proactive forest management through controlled burns when weather conditions are favorable, returning to traditional stewardship practices.

CONTENT: These initiatives should be incentivized to encourage participation, and the public should be educated about their benefits and importance. However, making them mandatory may not be the best approach, as it could lead to resistance or unintended consequences. Instead, fostering voluntary engagement through positive reinforcement would likely yield better long-term outcomes.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need incentives and education to build community resilience, not mandates. People will participate more willingly if they understand the benefits and aren't forced into action.

CONTENT: fire retardant materials, fire suppression units on buildings  regardless of materials used and directed in exposed areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need buildings with fire retardant materials and built-in fire suppression systems, especially in vulnerable areas. These safety features should be mandatory regardless of construction materials.

CONTENT: Ensure brush clearance on properties. Make sure homeowners are educated on steps they can take to be prepared.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need property owners to clear brush and learn proper wildfire preparedness measures to protect our community.

CONTENT: I very much agree that we need more community outreach and education. In addition to providing this for long-time residents, I also think that new residents need better information. I moved to LA recently, and I feel like I was totally unprepared for the situation. I wish I had gotten some sort of "welcome packet" telling me what I needed to know.
LLM_SUMMARY: As a new LA resident, I felt completely unprepared for wildfire emergencies. We need better community education, especially welcome packets for newcomers with essential safety information.

CONTENT: Need community coordination of these efforts and either make it mandatory (part of building code) or offer financial incentives to harden homes against fire. Loosen some aspects of code/standards that are preventing us from staggering homes on lots to reduce structure-to-structure fire risk.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want better community coordination for fire protection - make home hardening mandatory or incentivized. Adjust building codes to allow strategic home placement that reduces fire spread between structures.

CONTENT: On the one hand I'm finding it easy to trust the army core. But on the other the reality of toxic ash covering the area it does leads me to believe that more can be done for testing. Insurance has basically refused it from that I can tell, and it's fallen on individuals to do testing to feel confident.  Still, the broad population with concerns about areas near schools (etc) means there is still a hearts and mind problem the government needs to solve for if they want people aligned with their stance on safety.
LLM_SUMMARY: While I trust the Army Corps, more comprehensive toxic ash testing is needed, especially near schools. Insurance won't cover it, leaving individuals to pay. Government must better address public safety concerns.

CONTENT:
Promoting the PACE-Property Assessed Clean Energy program and  encouraging residents to rebuild with solar roof tiles would be helpful These materials are more fire resistant & widespread deployment would reduce the strain on the grid

If not solar tiles, other roofing materials that are inherently fire resistant and manufactured using a circular process should be used

LA Rises or another PPP should be assigned the task of bundling the orders  for the materials  They could acquire them @ wholesale prices & distribute them @ cost

PACE could lower costs by using blended finance vehicles incorporating grant $ & concessionary capital to fund projects

These discounts along with fed/state incentives & grants would significantly reduce cost
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to rebuild smarter with fire-resistant solar tiles and materials through PACE financing and bulk purchasing programs. Government incentives could make it affordable for everyone.

CONTENT:
More education about fire prevention, such as removing furniture and storage from the house perimeter, not using wood for fences, maintaining fire extinguishers, fireproof vents, etc should be required by the county and inspected by insurance companies. 

Insurance companies already check for overhanging trees, which is a similar risk issue.  Aftermarket sprinklers should be required inside and outside the house.  

A siren alarm system such as that for tornadoes in other states is not costly. Cell phone alerts are not appropriate for middle of the night event.

My neighbors saved their houses by dousing small fires all night long.  When we are ordered to evacuate, the fire dept took the responsibility to save our homes.....and failed.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that fire prevention measures aren't mandatory or inspected. Want required sprinklers and siren alerts. Neighbors who stayed saved homes, while evacuating left properties vulnerable to destruction.

CONTENT: Yes! Offer hefty rebates for those who fire harden their homes.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to see more financial incentives for homeowners to make fire safety improvements through rebate programs.

CONTENT: Code changes must be adopted and enforced to reduce the future conflagrations that will otherwise happen. Get home owners and community groups to take on what should happen to make homes safer from the threat of fire. Listen to them, work with them. Present the policies and codes that will make a difference AND SELL THEM TO THE VOTERS!
LLM_SUMMARY: We need stronger building codes to prevent future fires, but it must be done collaboratively with homeowners and community groups. Get their buy-in and support for effective fire-safety policies.

CONTENT: Attention to contaminants should be a priority for the county's environmental health department. Not left up to individual homeowners. The long-term consequences are a community concern. Funding should exist for remediation if needed. Partnerships with research institutions. Programs to make whole house water purification systems cost effective. If building density increases to fill housing needs, standards for open space on lots. The county or city could buy lots put on the market to create publicly-owned green space.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need county-led environmental cleanup with funding for water purification and remediation. Don't leave it to homeowners. Should partner with researchers and preserve green spaces while managing development.

CONTENT: Super infrared detectors with AI intelligence to notice ANY dangerous signs of heat, fire, smoke and signal an immediate response from a 'SWAT' team that is entirely focused and on alert to snuff out any fires or flames before they can spread. Or issue tickets and fines, even prison, for anyone lighting dangerous fires. Northern US and canadian cities divert construction infrastructure to snow removal in winter. We must divert resources & attention to be on hyper alert & vigilance in dry high fire risk
LLM_SUMMARY: We need AI-powered early detection systems and rapid response teams dedicated to stopping fires immediately. Like how northern cities prioritize snow removal, we must redirect resources to fire prevention and enforcement.

CONTENT: Please consider brush clearance, controlled burns and fines for those who do not properly maintain there brush/trees
LLM_SUMMARY: We need better brush management through clearance and controlled burns, plus enforcement with fines for property owners who don't maintain vegetation properly.

CONTENT: Our utilities keep causing these devastating fires and they are getting worse with climate change. We need to fix our utilities to prevent these fires from starting again, clear hazard brush while maintaining wild lands and native plants, create mandatory setbacks, remove palm trees and begin to prepare for the reality we now face. We need roof top sprinklers and water agencies with infrastructure with redundancies that can accommodate extreme use in wildfire events. We need water and power to adapt to climate change and build infrastructure that shuts down without starting fires and keeps water running during fires. What happens if there is an earthquake during red flag high winds? I fear for my state.
LLM_SUMMARY: Worried about utilities causing fires and worsening climate impacts. We urgently need improved infrastructure with better safety features, brush management, and water systems that can handle extreme fire events.

CONTENT: More funding more grants more education on how to get these resources and agency support services!!
LLM_SUMMARY: Desperately need increased funding, grants, and better education about available recovery resources. We need help understanding how to access support services for our businesses.

CONTENT:
Fire resistant building materials, consistent audits of defensible space. (Individual buy in to the intrusion that an audit requires, for the greater good) audits of power companies to ensure they are not at risk for causing a fire.
Sincere attempts to reduce factors contributing to climate instability
LLM_SUMMARY: We need fire-resistant materials, defensible space audits, power company oversight, and real climate action. Community must accept these measures for our collective safety.

CONTENT:
Private insurers are leaving the state. Fair plan is already at risk of insolvency. We cannot afford to have to rebuild whole towns - and DESTROY whole communities and culture. Insurers, the state and especially RE-INSURANCE co's have every reason to invest substantially to reduce the risk to near zero of fires that spread to any residential area in LA County. 

Every home at the perimeter should have subsidized water and retardant systems, detectors and a wide boundary around these residential areas should have thorough brush clearance (Goats, sheep, fairly paid incarcerated) to inhibit the spread of fire from starting conflagration - where hot burning homes ignite homes from high infrared, not even sparks needed. 

HUGE VALUE & ROI
LLM_SUMMARY: We need major investment in fire prevention from insurers and the state, including subsidized home protection systems and proper brush clearance, to prevent devastating community losses and insurance market collapse.

CONTENT: Kill all lawns. We must change the culture of turf lawns and instead normalize the use of California native plants. They save on water, are already adapted to the environment, provide wildfire resilience, and support local ecology. It is scientific fact that a diverse population thrives - therefore a more biodiverse environment is more resilient to threats. Yes - brush clearance is needed, but education and implementation of native landscapes comes hand-in-hand. In terms of accountability - hold the utility companies accountable. Do not let them get away with their negligence. They must pay.
LLM_SUMMARY: Native plants should replace lawns for fire resilience and water conservation. Utilities must be held accountable for fire prevention, while proper brush management and education are essential.

CONTENT: I would like to see an emphasis on fire suppression technology that could be implemented home by home. Is there a way to get fire suppression materials at the ready? Can there be a push toward sprinkler systems that connect to a grid for fire professionals to utilize?
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to see more focus on home-level fire suppression technology and systems. Would like accessible materials and connected sprinkler networks that fire crews can control during emergencies.

CONTENT: Broaden the C.C.C. mandate to take in more people, pay them, and help the community with cooperative neighborhood efforts.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want to expand California Conservation Corps to employ more people and support community-based recovery efforts through paid neighborhood cooperation programs.

CONTENT: We need to make community based burning more accessible so that we can have burns when it is not fire season to reduce fuels during fire season.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should make controlled burns more accessible during safer periods, allowing communities to reduce fuel loads before fire season hits.

CONTENT: hold them accountable for updating programs/policies/ordinances but them give them the staffing and effective management to enforce. Also, door-to-door information/education (yes it is staff intensive, but there are plenty of people looking for employment).  For example, is there a problem house in the neighborhood who doesn't cut back trees, rake fallen leaves, or otherwise care for their property to the risk of the rest of the community? One warning, steep fines, then the county moves in and remediates using the fine to pay for the work.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need proper staffing and enforcement of fire prevention policies, with door-to-door education. Give warnings for non-compliant properties, then implement steep fines and county intervention to address haz

CONTENT: I'd like to see public support/subsidies for roofing and building materials that resist fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want government help to make homes more fire-resistant through subsidies for protective building materials and roofing upgrades.

CONTENT: Why are we holding the govt accountable for a homeowner's lack of prioritization? The govt should keep people aware, and make sure they comply. It is OUR responsibility and not at the level of the government to baby us through our messes.
LLM_SUMMARY: Homeowners, not government, should be responsible for wildfire prevention on their properties. Government's role is to inform and enforce compliance, not manage individual responsibilities.

CONTENT: This effort needs to be led by the local community.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need our local community to take charge of emergency planning efforts.

CONTENT: This is a reality of California whether you believe in climate change or not.  Home owners should build back better. But also we need to hold utilities accountable.  In Altadena the brush near the power lines fueled the destruction. How that was allowed to happen is truly baffling.  Homeowners alone should not bear the brunt of being responsible for wildfire preparation.
LLM_SUMMARY: Wildfires are inevitable in California, but responsibility shouldn't fall solely on homeowners. Utilities must be held accountable, especially for poor brush management near power lines that fueled the

CONTENT: These code enforcement agents would cost the same as the WM plan's expense in Palmdale, and be 5 times more effective...
LLM_SUMMARY: We should hire code enforcement agents instead of the Wildland Management plan - it would cost the same but be much more effective for community safety.

CONTENT: Incentivize communities to make improvements that will make homes more robust in the face of environmental dangers.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need incentives for communities to strengthen homes against environmental threats, making them more resilient to disasters like wildfires.

CONTENT: Developers MUST build in only the right places and create only the right structures -- this is something ordinary people cannot be trusted to determine.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building development needs strict oversight and regulation - we can't leave these critical decisions about where and what to build up to individual homeowners.

CONTENT: It starts with us. Most homes burn due to embers rather than direct flames, so focusing on preventing ember entry is crucial. How many homeowners follow the guidelines set forth by CalFire and other fire experts? 1/8" mesh over your vents, no wood decks or gates attached to your home, double planed windows, no vegetation within five feet of your home?
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to take responsibility by ember-proofing our homes according to CalFire guidelines - installing proper mesh, removing wood structures, and maintaining defensible space around houses.

CONTENT: I would like to see a publicly funded community led public safety committee  that has the ability to escalate issues of concern to the courts (via seeking a writ of mandate to compel action) if they are not addressed in a timely fashion by local government. Senior public safety officers like the Fire Chief should present to this committee, as they do to the Fire Commission and the Mayor. People who live in the community have a much stronger impetus to address potential fire risk than elected or appointed officials have.
LLM_SUMMARY: Want a community-led safety committee with legal power to force action on fire risks when local government delays. Officials should answer to residents who have more stake in prevention.

CONTENT: There needs to be actual detailed protocols in place with responsible agencies and information dissemination. It is beyond the pale that vulnerable communities were not given consideration. The point of government is to have emergency planning, and cannot say that its up to us as individuals to figure it out!
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that government failed to provide clear emergency protocols and communication, especially for vulnerable populations. We shouldn't have to figure out emergency planning on our own.

CONTENT: Practice the preparedness training.  Offer monetary incentives to those who participate and practice the preparedness drills.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need incentives to get more people participating in emergency preparedness drills and training. This will help our community be better prepared for disasters.

CONTENT: Unground power lines. Pay for it  DO NOT make the citizens pay for it. Use new technology ie drones to asses fire risk on windy Santa Ana days. Pre deploy the Fire Dept. Brush Clearance on city, county, and state land is a MUST.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need underground power lines funded by utilities, not residents. Use drones to monitor fire risk during Santa Anas, position firefighters strategically, and maintain proper brush clearance on public lands

CONTENT: There was a sore lack of preparedness training and we need more resources for that. For example, Pasadena only held a handful of CERT trainings in 2024 - after several year hiatus. They have not had any scheduled since at least fall of 2024. The public emergency preparedness also needs to cover wildfire (and fires in general). I did training, including map my neighborhood before the pandemic and my training and to-go-bag were mostly irrelevant because it was mostly for earthquake disaster. The only design education the public gets is about drought-tolerant/resistance. There needs to be more education on fire-resistant design and mitigation measures. Just like there are tax credits for turf removal, there should be incentives for wildfire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need more frequent disaster preparedness training that's wildfire-specific, not just earthquake-focused. Current CERT programs are insufficient, and we need incentives for fire-resistant home improvements, like

CONTENT: A lot of us want to clear brush and trees but are told we cannot because of ESHA. Suspend to Coastal act and ESHA with it.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that environmental protection rules (ESHA and Coastal Act) prevent us from clearing vegetation for fire safety. These regulations need to be suspended for community protection.

CONTENT: In the Eaton fire, the cause appears to be from the utility. The press has outlined a number of issues known to be high risk that went unattended for years.  If the Government cannot hold utilities accountable and set higher standards, they will default to decisions that benefit profit over public safety.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that utilities prioritize profits over safety, with known risks left unaddressed before the Eaton fire. Government must enforce stricter standards and hold companies accountable for prevention.

CONTENT: The Fire Agencies have enough on their plate so Building Code Enforcement should be used to make defensible space around homes mandatory and open spaces are cutback to allow evacuations.  What happened to all the fire breaks that were in place in the 1970 per Prop 13?    Quit spending money on endless social programs and start spending money on safety and quality of life.  Start enforcing laws and arrest criminals.   CA used to be a great place to live now it's a literal dump.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building code enforcement should handle defensible space requirements and fire breaks. Stop wasting money on social programs and focus on safety. We need better law enforcement like we had before.

CONTENT: The December 2024 Franklin fire burn scar saved the western half of Malibu. Please allow such planned burn scar prevevention/protection for all beach neighborhoods in the future.
LLM_SUMMARY: Support using controlled burns as protective barriers - the Franklin fire burn scar proved effective in protecting Malibu, and similar prevention measures should be implemented in other coastal areas.

CONTENT: The government should be helping homeowners that have homes that are standing to retrofit for fire safety. Codes need to be updated with fire safety at the forefront without any red tape.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need government support to retrofit existing homes for fire safety, with streamlined building codes that prioritize fire protection without bureaucratic obstacles.

CONTENT: Our soils must be tested! This should not be the homeowner’s responsibility. We need to know that we are moving back into a safe place where we can grow food in our backyard and shower without a cancer risk down the road.
LLM_SUMMARY: Soil testing for contamination should be handled by authorities, not homeowners. We need assurance our properties are safe for gardening and daily activities without health risks.

CONTENT: Clean the debris FAST. Waive permit fees for the people who are rebuilding, whether that means like for like or smaller or bigger than what they had. Direct GRANT to homeowners.
LLM_SUMMARY: Urgently remove debris and eliminate permit fees for all rebuilding projects. Provide direct grants to homeowners to support recovery, regardless of rebuild size.

CONTENT: We need expertise and help to fire harden our whole community, not just encouraging a few people with the money to do it. Also we can't insure our way out of this. Insurance companies will leave if they don't make a profit and the state can't afford to take their place with the pace and severity of disasters. Education, fire audits, financial assistance. Community immunity.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need community-wide fire hardening, not just individual efforts. Insurance isn't sustainable with increasing disasters. We need education, fire audits, and financial help for collective protection.

CONTENT: Power lines need to be underground.  Europe has them, why doesn't California? This, and controlled burns, using goats to clear brush around urban-wildlife interface areas needs to be a priority for the state, county and city, and all water systems should be audited before the fire season begins. Leadership should be held accountable for not maintaining fire hydrants and reservoirs. There should be more budget dollars allocated to these preventative measures vs incurring billions in losses and the horrific trauma of our people. We should NOT be taxed through more bond measures for losses that were preventable or at least not a disaster of epic proportions.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines and preventative measures like controlled burns should be prioritized over costly disaster recovery. Leaders must be accountable for maintaining fire infrastructure instead of passing costs to taxpayers.

CONTENT: Having been non renewed by my insurance company I think it is critical to assist homeowners rebuild their homes through a grant program. To keep the community flavor it will require getting year old owners back in their homes. Otherwise the old neighborhood will be replaced with money hungry developers with no thought of community only profit. Tenants will need access to new apartment building so assisting the owners rebuild in a timely fashion with also be critical
LLM_SUMMARY: Desperately need grants to help homeowners rebuild quickly after insurance non-renewal. Without support, developers will take over and destroy our community's character. Apartment owners need help too.

CONTENT: My own grandmother lost her home in the Palisades Fire, so this is hard to say. But if people decide to rebuild in the exact spot their house burned down, the financial risk of repeat fire should should be borne by communities who rebuild in high risk areas. Skyrocketing insurance rates should not be distributed throughout the state to areas that have very low risk of wildfire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance costs for rebuilding in high-risk fire zones should be paid by those communities, not spread across low-risk areas. It's personal - my grandmother lost her home.

CONTENT: Fire resistant design is a community effort.  Everyone needs to be a part of it.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need the whole community to participate in fire-resistant design - it's not something that works if only some people do it.

CONTENT: Coordinate better with the home owners
LLM_SUMMARY: Need better coordination between officials and homeowners on debris cleanup efforts.

CONTENT: Test the soil for every property. Find the money to do this. Not everyone can afford soil testing for contaminants, but this will affect everyone’s health long term. Plus it will affect the ground water as contaminants seep into the soil.
LLM_SUMMARY: Soil testing for contaminants is crucial but expensive. We need funding to test all affected properties since this impacts everyone's long-term health and groundwater quality.

CONTENT: If you are serious about reducing the risk of Fire spreading, remove ALL palm trees from Altadena and other foothill communities. Our house is gone because of palm fronds landing on our roof!
LLM_SUMMARY: Lost my home when burning palm fronds landed on the roof. Palm trees need to be removed from foothill communities like Altadena to prevent fire spread.

CONTENT: More funds are needed to help residents remove dead trees and other fuel on private lands.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need financial assistance to clear hazardous vegetation from private properties - dead trees and other fire fuels are a major risk that homeowners can't address alone.

CONTENT: We need to know that the state is prioritizing fire mitigation so that we can feel good about rebuilding in the same areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Seeking reassurance that state prioritizes fire prevention before committing to rebuild in fire-affected areas. Need confidence in mitigation efforts to make long-term decisions.

CONTENT: We must replant NATIVE plants that are by design much less flammable, like the California chaparral and stop cutting it down. Conversely, we must take down all palm trees down, not only they are giant match sticks when we get a wild fire, they provide little to no oxygen, they attract rodents and help the transmission of Leptospirosis, they provide little shade and now the department of sanitation wont take any of the debris from it as it takes a very long time to decompose, so that would go to a landfill to generate methane instead. We also need to consult with Native Tribes who are the original stewards of the land and used to have controlled fires to avoid having these mega fires. Private firefighters must be banned.
LLM_SUMMARY: Native plants and traditional fire management practices are crucial. Palm trees are dangerous fire hazards and environmentally problematic. We need indigenous knowledge and should ban private firefighters.

CONTENT: Neighborhood councils should be responsible for organizing community meetings with emergency response agencies to develop community plans in an emergency.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need neighborhood councils to take charge of emergency planning by coordinating with response agencies and creating community-wide action plans.

CONTENT: 6 of the 10 most costly fires in California have been caused by power lines. Its way overdue to put them underground. If Europe can do it, so can we.
LLM_SUMMARY: Frustrated that power lines cause major fires in California. Underground lines are a proven solution used in Europe - we need to implement this here too.

CONTENT: Expensive yet necessary.  Start in most fire prone areas and move outward.
LLM_SUMMARY: Support underground power line conversion starting in high-risk fire zones, despite costs. Makes sense to prioritize most vulnerable areas first.

CONTENT: Must clean before anything. Do clean-up at the neighborhood or at minimum at the block-level, not individual building site, to be more more efficient and cost effective. Require home owners and insurance companies to bundle efforts/$$.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need coordinated, block-level debris cleanup instead of individual property efforts. Homeowners and insurance companies should pool resources for more efficient, cost-effective neighborhood recovery.

CONTENT: As many know, in California the vast majority of fire prone areas are the responsibility of the federal government. Our representatives should continue to press the federal government to do their part. The wildland/urban intersections are where state and local jurisdictions should continue to focus their efforts.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to hold the federal government accountable for fire prevention on their land, while state and local agencies focus on protecting where wilderness meets urban areas.

CONTENT: Building and zoning laws should be reviewed annually, and updated as needed.  They need to reject the current needs.  We need to take into account all the science and facts at our disposal and then come up with collaborative changes to be made.  Everyone should be allowed to have a voice.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need updated building codes that reflect current realities and scientific data. The review process should be collaborative and include community input.

CONTENT: Change can be difficult.  I, too, love to have plants near and around my home, but if the reality of fire risk is there...it would be selfish to refuse.  The same applies to building materials.  While I would once have scoffed at the idea of stucco siding, I now look at this as potentially a safer alternative to all wood siding.  That may or may not be true, but if I were building from scratch, I would embrace all I could learn about fire resistant design, just as I look at accessible design needs.
LLM_SUMMARY: I've learned to prioritize fire safety over aesthetics - from replacing wood siding with stucco to rethinking landscaping. We must adapt our homes to face climate realities.
